('66', 0, 1, 2, 44) 1. LETTER TO PREMABEHN KANTAK December 16, 1934
('66', 0, 3, 3, 92) Your letters I shall send on to Narandas.
('66', 0, 3, 4, 134) Today also I got up at 1.45 a.m.
('66', 0, 3, 5, 167) and started writing letters.
('66', 0, 3, 6, 196) It has become a habit with me now to wake up at about 2. I go to bed before 9 p.m.
('66', 0, 3, 7, 279) During the day, I take a nap once or twice and get half an hour to one hour.
('66', 0, 3, 8, 356) That seems to be enough for me.
('66', 0, 3, 9, 388) By writing “not revised” I ensure—and do—justice to myself and to the person to whom the letter is addressed.
('66', 0, 3, 10, 498) If by chance I have written “aaj mar gaya” instead of “Ajmer gaya”, the other party may correct the mistake or, in case of doubt, ask me.
('66', 0, 3, 11, 636) A letter which has not been revised should always be regarded as incomplete.
('66', 0, 3, 12, 713) But I would prefer, and so would you, that I write an incomplete letter to you rather than not write any.
('66', 0, 3, 13, 819) Most probably I shall be going to Delhi on or about the 27th.
('66', 0, 3, 14, 881) Continue to write to me at the Wardha address till you hear from me or you read in the papers.
('66', 0, 3, 15, 976) The atonement for any violation of a vow in a dream is generally greater vigilance and Ramanama on waking up from the dream.
('66', 0, 3, 16, 1101) Such violations of vows or moral rules in dreams are signs of our imperfection.
('66', 0, 3, 17, 1181) Unconsciously we harbour deep in our hearts the desires which we gratify in dreams.
('66', 0, 3, 18, 1265) We should not despair because of such dreams, but should become more and more vigilant.
('66', 0, 3, 19, 1353) Despair may be a sign of the person being attached to the senses; it is certainly a sign of his lack of faith.
('66', 0, 3, 20, 1464) If a person tires of repeating Ramanama— despairs about its usefulness—shouldn’t we say that he has lost faith in it?
('66', 0, 3, 21, 1582) When Columbus’s companions lost faith, they wanted to kill him.
('66', 0, 3, 22, 1646) But with his eyes of faith Columbus could clearly see the coast and he asked his companions to give him some more time, and he reached America!
('66', 0, 3, 23, 1790) If a person dreams that he is eating forbidden food, such a dream also means what I have explained above.
('66', 0, 3, 24, 1896) There may be external causes for such dreams and, whenever we discover any, we should remove them.
('66', 0, 3, 25, 1995) “I am the spotless Brahman that is witness of all the states.” This is what we sing.
('66', 0, 3, 26, 2080) We can sing thus only if we strive ceaselessly to be that.
('66', 0, 3, 27, 2139) The dreams that we get are a signthat we have not succeeded in becoming spotless.
('66', 0, 3, 28, 2221) They are a warning light for us.
('66', 1, 0, 1, 2254) 2 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('66', 1, 1, 2, 2294) Not a leaf can stir without God’s grace, but we cannot dispense with human effort either, which is the means through which God’s grace works.
('66', 1, 1, 3, 2436) Realization means nothing but pure and selfless service of all living creatures.
('66', 1, 1, 4, 2517) It is very good indeed that Kisan 1 has decided to stay with you.
('66', 1, 2, 5, 2583) Blessings from BAPU

('66', 2, 1, 2, 3697) 4. LETTER TO LABHUBEHN A. SHETH
('66', 2, 2, 3, 3729) December 16, 1934
('66', 2, 3, 4, 3747) LABHU, If I had included your name in my letter to Amritlal, I would have been made a fool by your letter, wouldn’t I?
('66', 2, 3, 5, 3866) This is the plight of one who leaves the trodden path.
('66', 2, 3, 6, 3921) Who can tell whether your letter conveys your genuine desire for knowledge or is mere idle prattle?
('66', 2, 3, 7, 4021) But I want to look great in your eyes, hence I must measure up to your yardstick!
('66', 2, 3, 8, 4103) If anything, I am at least four times older than you.
('66', 2, 3, 9, 4157) Am I not?
('66', 2, 3, 10, 4167) How can I tell you where you can find steadiness, as though it were some commodity to be bought in a shop?
('66', 2, 3, 11, 4274) If I were running a grocer’s shop here, this being my ancestral business, I would have sent it over to you without your asking for it.
('66', 2, 3, 12, 4409) You have even sent an advance of one anna.
('66', 2, 3, 13, 4452) You have wasted your years.
('66', 2, 3, 14, 4480) Amritlal is no more worthy of being your father because he has failed to show me something that you have within you.
('66', 2, 3, 15, 4597) But hasn’t the poet said, “The dear ones of the embodied soul are all selfish.” After all isn’t he only your embodied father?
('66', 2, 3, 16, 4723) The one without a body that is your real Father dwells in your own heart.
('66', 2, 3, 17, 4797) Know Him and you will not have to spend even an anna.
('66', 2, 3, 18, 4851) Your learning is illusory if it does not lead you to Him.
('66', 2, 3, 19, 4909) But if you are learning with this aim, you will be able to secure the release of Khan Saheb 1, Sheikh, Jawahar and the others.
('66', 2, 3, 20, 5036) But if you want to indulge in idle talk and play as with dolls then you must cast away the idea of greatness you associate with me or humbly confess that you never had genuine thirst for knowledge.
('66', 2, 3, 21, 5234) Remember in this connection the story of Indra and Virochana.
('66', 2, 3, 22, 5296) If you don’t know it yourself, ask Amritlal and let him also enjoy it and add to your knowledge.
('66', 2, 4, 23, 5393) From a copy of the Gujarati: Pyarelal Papers.
('66', 2, 4, 24, 5439) Courtesy: Pyarelal

('66', 3, 1, 6, 6080) Let it not be said of the city women that they cared not for their millions of sisters living in the 700,000 villages.

('66', 3, 5, 20, 6802) I have glanced through your book 2. It has proved a severe disappointment.
('66', 3, 5, 21, 6877) You have lost yourself in the exuberance of your own language.

('66', 6, 1, 2, 9743) 11. LETTER TO H. L. SHARMA
('66', 6, 2, 3, 9770) December 17, 1934
('66', 6, 3, 4, 9788) SHARMA, I feel apprehensive in writing to you.
('66', 6, 3, 5, 9835) I got your letter just now.
('66', 6, 3, 6, 9863) I had written nothing that could have provoked you to write such a letter.
('66', 6, 3, 7, 9938) How can a son suspect his father?
('66', 6, 3, 8, 9972) Perhaps I am not worthy of being a true father!
('66', 6, 3, 9, 10020) If no one is keeping well in Khurja, why do you stay on there?
('66', 6, 3, 10, 10083) Go to the Harijan Ashram [Delhi] and live in a separate house there.
('66', 6, 3, 11, 10152) It will not be very expensive.
('66', 6, 3, 12, 10183) Or stay in a village here.
('66', 6, 3, 13, 10210) I cannot put up with your falling ill and continuing to be ill.
('66', 6, 3, 14, 10274) Ramdas will not stay with me.
('66', 6, 3, 15, 10304) He no longer has faith in my treatment though he consults me occasionally.
('66', 6, 3, 16, 10379) He has given up eggs and takes ordinary diet.
('66', 6, 3, 17, 10425) Since yesterday he has resumed living withNimu.
('66', 6, 3, 18, 10473) He is preparing to go to Bombay, for which he has my permission.
('66', 6, 3, 19, 10538) He has gained a fair amount of strength and moves about by himself.
('66', 6, 3, 20, 10606) I am not worried on his account.
('66', 6, 3, 21, 10639) In the end it will be all right for him.
('66', 6, 3, 22, 10680) Amtul left for Bombay the day before yesterday and will probably reach Delhi by the end of this month.
('66', 6, 3, 23, 10783) May be I shall be able to go to Delhi only after the 27th.
('66', 6, 3, 24, 10842) Your note appeared in last week’s Harijanbandhu and in this week’s Harijan.
('66', 6, 3, 25, 10918) Owing to an oversight it was delayed for a week.
('66', 6, 3, 26, 10967) As soon as your letter came I sent instructions for a copy of the Harijan to be sent to you.
('66', 6, 3, 27, 11060) I got a letter today from Dr. Ansari and among other things he writes this about you:
('66', 6, 4, 28, 11146) As regards Dr. Sharma, I would like to see him and find out his exact requirements and then I may be able to help him.
('66', 6, 5, 29, 11265) It would be good if you went to Delhi.
('66', 6, 5, 30, 11304) If you wish you may go there after my arrival.
('66', 6, 5, 31, 11351) You yourself told me that you were responsible for your brothers not writing to me.
('66', 6, 5, 32, 11435) Can they be so lacking in manners as not even to reply to me?
('66', 6, 5, 33, 11497) If you have not seen them so far, is it not an instance of your haphazard ways?
('66', 6, 5, 34, 11577) But if you do not yourself realize this, I can hardly make you see it.
('66', 6, 5, 35, 11648) I see nothing but lack of coherence in your talk, your actions and your letters.
('66', 6, 5, 36, 11729) I was under the impression that you were conscious of it.
('66', 6, 5, 37, 11787) Well, we need not
('66', 7, 0, 1, 11805) 8 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('66', 7, 1, 2, 11845) worry about it.
('66', 7, 1, 3, 11861) All will be well.
('66', 7, 1, 4, 11879) Your heart is good and my effort is as vigorous as it can be.
('66', 7, 1, 5, 11941) I always have your good at heart and nothing else.
('66', 7, 1, 6, 11992) I hope to take much service from you.
('66', 7, 1, 7, 12030) Ask Draupadi to write to me in detail.

('66', 8, 1, 2, 13234) 14. LETTER TO HATIM ALVI 1
('66', 8, 2, 3, 13261) December 19, 1934
('66', 8, 3, 4, 13279) Of the many happy memories of the late Maulana, the one that persists most with me, is the gift by him, on the conclusion of my fast of 21 days at Delhi, of a cow as an earnest of his intense desire to see heart unity among Hindus and Mussalmans.
('66', 8, 3, 5, 13526) 2 If he had been with us, he would have raised his voice against the recent deliberate murder of the two Hindus 3 who foolishly criticized the Prophet of Islam.
('66', 8, 3, 6, 13687) Now— alas!—one hears these murders being extolled publicly as if they were meritorious acts.
('66', 8, 3, 7, 13780) I wonder whether you and your League have taken any steps to educate the public along the right path.
('66', 8, 4, 8, 13882) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI
('66', 8, 5, 9, 13912) From the manuscript of Mahadev Desai’s Diary.
('66', 8, 5, 10, 13958) Courtesy: Narayan Desai
('66', 8, 6, 11, 13982) 15. LETTER TO DR.

('66', 8, 7, 13, 14021) December [19] 4, 1934 DEAR DR.
('66', 8, 7, 14, 14052) PATTABHI,
('66', 8, 8, 15, 14062) This is village paper.
('66', 8, 8, 16, 14085) The ink is village made, and the pen is made of village reed.
('66', 8, 8, 17, 14147) Do the villagers manufacture paper there?
('66', 8, 8, 18, 14189) If so, at what price?
('66', 8, 8, 19, 14211) I have your full letter.
('66', 8, 8, 20, 14236) Yes, we must meet.
('66', 8, 8, 21, 14255) Since you have time, you have to be humble enough to ask for the responsibility you can shoulder — work of the highest order, with or without office, whichever is better for your work.
('66', 8, 8, 22, 14440) In this service of the destitute, there is no room for ceremony.
('66', 8, 8, 23, 14505) And this business of rice, flour, gur, oil, ghee, etc., is a vast business.
('66', 8, 8, 24, 14581) You have to revive your knowledge of medicine.

('66', 9, 7, 11, 15740) 17. BYE LAWS OF THE ALL INDIA VILLAGE INDUSTRIES ASSOCIATION
('66', 9, 8, 12, 15801) [Before December 20, 1934] 4
('66', 9, 9, 13, 15830) (1) The ordinary general meeting of the Association shall be held once every year, and at any time an extraordinary meeting may be convened by the Secretary with the consent of the President, and shall be convened upon a requisition being received by him from notless than one sixth of the members on the roll.
('66', 9, 9, 14, 16141) One fifth the num ber of members on the roll, with a minimum of seven, shall form a quorum.
('66', 9, 9, 15, 16233) (2) The first financial year of the Association shall be from the 14th December, 1934 to 31st December, 1935, and thereafter the

('66', 11, 2, 3, 18749) AGENTS’ DUTIES
('66', 11, 3, 4, 18764) The Board of Management has framed a set of rules defining the duties of agents under bye law No.
('66', 11, 3, 5, 18862) 10. They are as follows: (1) To begin with, the agent will be expected to attend to the programme already drawn up by the Central Office.
('66', 11, 3, 6, 19000) After he has made a fair start with the Central Office programme, he will be expected to make a survey of all such industries that may be revived, improved or introduced in his area and shall forthwith report to the Central Office results of his investigations and submit a programme of work based thereon for examination by the Office.
('66', 11, 3, 7, 19337) (2) Every agent will be expected to attend to the sanitation and hygiene of the villages within his area.
('66', 11, 3, 8, 19443) (3) With a view to finding markets for the surplus products of the villages, he should induce reliable merchants to store village products for sale, at prices mutually fixed between the merchants and the agent and so as to ensure the genuineness of such products.
('66', 11, 3, 9, 19707) (4) He should carry on an intensive propaganda to create a favourable public opinion for the programme in his area.
('66', 11, 3, 10, 19823) (5) He may invite and receive subscriptions and donations to meet the expenses in connection with his work and should not expect any financial aid from the Central Office.
('66', 11, 3, 11, 19995) But he shall not utilize any part of the funds so collected by him for his own personal require ments.
('66', 11, 3, 12, 20098) (6) He may appoint, whenever necessary, and if funds at his disposal permit, paid workers needed for his work.
('66', 11, 3, 13, 20209) (7) He shall keep accurate accounts of all receipts and disbursements, which will be subject to audit by the Central Office.
('66', 11, 3, 14, 20334) (8) His work will be subject to the inspection and supervision of the Central Office.
('66', 11, 3, 15, 20420) (9) He shall submit a report of his work and an abstract of receipts and payments for every month so as to reach the Central Office not later than the 15th of the month following.

('66', 14, 1, 2, 24859) 20. EXPANSION OF “HARIJAN”
('66', 14, 2, 3, 24886) Some readers have taken exception to the way in which the columns of Harijan are being occupied with the development of the village industries scheme, and some others have welcomed the change in what they had thought was monotony of presentation.
('66', 14, 2, 4, 25133) Either opinion is probably hasty.
('66', 14, 2, 5, 25167) Any problem connected with the welfare of villages as a whole must be intimately related to the Harijans, who represent over a sixth part of India’s population.
('66', 14, 2, 6, 25328) If villages get good rice and flour, Harijans will benefit by the change as much as the rest of the population.
('66', 14, 2, 7, 25440) But there is a special sense in which Harijans will benefit.
('66', 14, 2, 8, 25501) Tanning and the whole of the raw hide work is their monopoly, and economically this will occupy perhaps the best part of the new scheme.
('66', 14, 2, 9, 25638) Indeed, Harijans, in so far as they have given their opinion, have welcomed the expansion.
('66', 14, 2, 10, 25729) Those who were tired of monotony were also in my opinion wrong.
('66', 14, 2, 11, 25793) The pages of Harijan could not be filled with matters that had no connection, direct or indirect, with those in whose interest it was being published.
('66', 14, 2, 12, 25944) Those who complained of monotony were perhaps not sufficiently interested in the cause.
('66', 14, 2, 13, 26032) No doubt it would be true criticism if I were told that the columns of Harijan were not as interesting as they might be made.
('66', 14, 2, 14, 26158) There are causes for this which are inherent in the movement itself.
('66', 14, 2, 15, 26227) It must be confessed that removal of untouchability is not a popular cause in the sense in which great political movements have been and become popular all over the world.
('66', 14, 2, 16, 26399) Removal of untouchability is a mighty social reform.
('66', 14, 2, 17, 26452) But it cannot furnish sensations.
('66', 14, 2, 18, 26486) It is a plodder’s work.
('66', 14, 2, 19, 26510) And record of the work of plodders requires editorial gifts of a high order to make it interesting.
('66', 14, 2, 20, 26610) Plodders can only attract plodding editors.
('66', 14, 2, 21, 26654) Therefore, the only way before those who are inti mately connected with the Harijan movement is to continue to work with an ever increasing faith in the cause and leave the result to take care of itself.
('66', 14, 2, 22, 26858) A little time ago there appeared in the Press a paragraph that the Gujarati edition of Harijan known as Harijanbandhu was about to be stopped, because it was being run at a loss.
('66', 14, 2, 23, 27037) The news was premature and unauthorized.
('66', 14, 2, 24, 27078) There was indeed a talk about it.
('66', 14, 2, 25, 27112) But when Thakkar Bapa heard of it, he soon smashed it by saying that noneof the three editions, Hindi, Gujarati and English, could be stopped.
('66', 14, 2, 26, 27255) The remedies available for avoiding losses on these weeklies are three:
('66', 15, 0, 1, 27327) 16 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('66', 15, 1, 2, 27368) (1) Raising of subscription; (2) Voluntary reduction by the printing and editorial staff in the remuneration they receive for their labours; (3) An appeal for increase in the number of subscribers.
('66', 15, 1, 3, 27566) The second remedy has been, and is still being, tried.
('66', 15, 1, 4, 27621) Reduction in the expense of publishing the papers is being steadily pursued.
('66', 15, 1, 5, 27698) There is limitless scope for increase in the number of subscribers.
('66', 15, 1, 6, 27766) And now that village industries and general village uplift is to occupy a fair portion of Harijan, there should be an automatic increase in the number of subscribers.
('66', 15, 2, 7, 27933) Harijan, 21 12 1934
('66', 15, 3, 8, 27953) 21. THE NEW BABY
('66', 15, 4, 9, 27970) The much talked of All India Village Industries Association was born amid calm surroundings and without any fuss or ceremony on the 14th instant at Wardha, which will be its headquarters by reason of the munificence of Sheth Jamnalalji, who has set apart ample ground with buildings for the use of the Association.
('66', 15, 4, 10, 28285) Of this, however, here after.
('66', 15, 4, 11, 28315) Let us make the acquaintance of the foundation members who are the first Board of Management.
('66', 15, 4, 12, 28409) Shri Shrikrishnadas Jajooji, the President, is a lawyer who had a distinguished career during his school and college days.
('66', 15, 4, 13, 28532) He left a lucrative practice long ago.
('66', 15, 4, 14, 28571) He has been identified with the philanthropic activities of Sheth Jamnalalji and is the President of the All India Spinners’ Association, Maharashtra Branch.
('66', 15, 4, 15, 28729) Shri Kumarappa, the Organizer and Secretary, is a Chartered Accountant, who years ago left a growing practice in Bombay and took up under Kakasaheb Kalelkar honorary appointment as Pro fessor at the Gujarat Vidyapith.
('66', 15, 4, 16, 28947) He served, with Sjts.
('66', 15, 4, 17, 28969) Bhulabhai Desai and D. N. Bahadurji, ex Advocate Generals, on the Public Debts Committee appointed by the Congress, and has been the financial adviser of the Bihar Central Relief Committee.
('66', 15, 4, 18, 29159) Shri Gosibehn Captain is one of the four indefatigable Naoroji sisters who have for years been completely identified with khadi and been responsible for conducting khadi embroidery classes for poor girls in Bombay started by Shri Mithubehn Petit, who has dedicated herself to the service of the poor in the villages of Gujarat.
('66', 16, 0, 1, 29487) VOL.66 : 16 DECEMBER, 1934 24 APRIL, 1935 17
('66', 16, 1, 2, 29532) Sheth Shoorji Vallabhdas is a well known merchant of Bombay.
('66', 16, 1, 3, 29593) He has been organizing khadi centres and has brought into being the Swadeshi Bazaar, of which the dividend, if any, is to be devoted solely to the promotion of village industries.
('66', 16, 1, 4, 29773) Dr. Khan Saheb (ex I. M. S.) is the elder brother of Khan Abdul Ghaffar Khan.
('66', 16, 1, 5, 29851) He takes the place of his brother who, but for his incarceration, would have been a member of the Board.
('66', 16, 1, 6, 29956) Shri Lakshmidas Purushottam was a well known merchant in Malabar before he gave up his business to join the Satyagraha Ashram at Sabarmati.
('66', 16, 1, 7, 30096) It was he who organized khadi in Gujarat, became the right hand man of Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel during the terrible floods of Gujarat in the year 1927 and has been likewise to Rajendrababu in the earthquake relief work in Bihar.
('66', 16, 1, 8, 30325) Dr. Profulla Ghosh (D. Sc.) is among the favourite early pupils of Dr. P. C. Ray, who, leaving a high post at the Government Mint, has for years been living on a mere pittance and has devoted his life to public service.
('66', 16, 1, 9, 30545) Shri Shankerlal Banker (M. A.) studied advanced chemistry in England and on return entered public life in 1916. He is the Secretary and soul of the All India Spinners’ Association and possesses an all round knowledge of khadi and, therefore, of the condition of villages, possessed, perhaps, by no one in the same extensive manner as he does.
('66', 16, 1, 10, 30888) Thus, with the exception of Sheth Shoorjibhai, the Board contains members who have no private finance or business to look after and whose sole concern would be in one way or another to consult the welfare of the villagers in everything they do.
('66', 16, 1, 11, 31133) They are all on the Board solely to shoulder the tremendous responsibility of striving to carry out the object of the Association.
('66', 16, 1, 12, 31264) The reader will study the simple constitution of the Association.
('66', 16, 1, 13, 31330) 1 If it is assisted by the public in a tangible manner, it will give hope to the millions of villagers; it will turn the city dwellers who are today their exploiters, into real helpers and servants; it will establish a living link between the intelligentsia and the illiterate masses; it will be instrumental in abolishing all distinctions between man and man, and it will turn the villagers from being mere creaters of raw produce, which they have
('66', 16, 2, 14, 31779) 1Vide Vol. LIX, “A.I V.I.A.—Object and Constitution”, 14 12 1934.
('66', 17, 0, 1, 31845) 18 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('66', 17, 1, 2, 31886) practically become, into self sustained units and caterers for most of the requirements of city dwellers.
('66', 17, 1, 3, 31992) In a task such as this, naturally political differences are sunk, all who will assist are invited to join asmembers, agents, workers, associates or advisers, according to their wishes and capacity.
('66', 17, 1, 4, 32190) The task is tremendous.
('66', 17, 1, 5, 32214) Nothing but Divine Grace can fulfill the expectations raised about the work of the Association.
('66', 17, 1, 6, 32310) And Divine Grace only attends intelligent, tireless effort.
('66', 17, 1, 7, 32370) The members of the Board are pledged to such effort.
('66', 17, 1, 8, 32423) Their past record is an earnest of the future.
('66', 17, 1, 9, 32470) The Association, though it is a creation of the Congress, has been deliberately made non political and autonomous.
('66', 17, 1, 10, 32585) Its members are pledged, whilst they remain such, to abstain from any campaign of civil disobedience.
('66', 17, 1, 11, 32687) As its adviser and guide, I can say that the Asso ciation has no further aim than that of bringing about the economic, physical and moral betterment of the villagers.
('66', 17, 1, 12, 32854) The reader will observe that the work of the Board of Management is to be done through honorary agents, at least in the first instance.
('66', 17, 1, 13, 32990) The agents have to select their own areas of operation, and they will be expected to confine themselves to, and to concentrate their attention on, those areas only.
('66', 17, 1, 14, 33155) There may thus be an agent even for one single village.
('66', 17, 1, 15, 33211) The Association may, therefore, have as many agents as there are villages in India.
('66', 17, 1, 16, 33295) Therefore, no honest person, however humble, need be deterred from offering his or her services.
('66', 17, 1, 17, 33392) The idea is to decentralize the work as much as possible.
('66', 17, 1, 18, 33450) Thus alone can intensive work be done with the utmost economy consistent with efficiency.
('66', 17, 1, 19, 33540) I hope that willing and honest workers will be found all over the country to take part in this glorious work of voluntary village reconstruction.

('66', 28, 6, 32, 50317) DEAR SAHEBJI MAHARAJ,
('66', 28, 7, 33, 50339) Your prompt and full reply came in yesterday with the stainless steel nibs.
('66', 28, 7, 34, 50415) They give me pleasure and pride.
('66', 28, 7, 35, 50448) I shall try them.
('66', 28, 7, 36, 50466) But my soul just now resides in the villages.
('66', 28, 7, 37, 50512) The paper on which I am writing is village made and so is the reed village grown from which my pen is made.
('66', 28, 7, 38, 50620) Economic laws like many others appear to be of two kinds, good and bad.
('66', 28, 7, 39, 50692) Good laws should be good for all.
('66', 28, 7, 40, 50726) Just now men, like
('66', 28, 8, 41, 50745) 1 Syed Raza Ali
('66', 29, 0, 1, 50761) 30 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('66', 29, 1, 2, 50802) the cows, seem to be a burden on the land.
('66', 29, 1, 3, 50845) Do the majority need to die, so that the few city people may live?
('66', 29, 1, 4, 50912) My humble attempt is to show that the villagers do not need to die and that they have an inherent capacity to live if they would but shed their laziness and make a corporate effort to live.
('66', 29, 1, 5, 51102) City people have no such inherent capacity.
('66', 29, 1, 6, 51146) Hence like Genghis they have to produce human hecatombs.
('66', 29, 1, 7, 51203) You will forgive me for arguing with you.
('66', 29, 1, 8, 51245) I do, because I want to discover the flaw, if there is one, in my method of approaching the common object—all round happiness.
('66', 29, 2, 9, 51372) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI

('66', 32, 4, 9, 56218) 48. VILLAGERS’ HANDS
('66', 32, 5, 10, 56239) Dr. Ansari’s is the latest reasoned opinion received on unpolished rice, whole wheatmeal and gur.
('66', 32, 5, 11, 56337) I share it with the readers.
('66', 32, 5, 12, 56366) The same kind of categorical replies have been received also from other eminent medical men.
('66', 32, 5, 13, 56459) A digest of these is being prepared by Sjt.
('66', 32, 5, 14, 56503) Kumarappa and will be duly published in these columns.
('66', 32, 5, 15, 56558) Mean while let workers and others ponder over the following: 1
('66', 32, 6, 16, 56621) In the process of polishing rice, all outer coverings of the grain are removed, consisting of the husk as well as the pigmented covering containing Vitamin B, fat and protein, which are necessary for health and growth.
('66', 32, 6, 17, 56840) It has been proved that the absence of Vitamin B from polished rice has been instrumental in causing beri beri.
('66', 32, 6, 18, 56952) Unpolished rice, on the other hand, not being subjected to the boiling process used in polishing rice in the mills, retains Vitamin B as well as the protein, fat and mineral matter.
('66', 32, 7, 19, 57134) The wheat grain consists of bran or outer envelope, mainly composed of cellulose, the kernel consisting of starch and the germ consisting of soluble starch, protein and some fat.
('66', 32, 8, 20, 57313) In the process of milling, the germ and the bran are rejected, and with it undoubtedly are discarded some of the most useful chemical constituent of the wheat, for with the germ a considerable amount of protein and fat are lost, and with the bran are lost mineral matter as well as some protein.
('66', 32, 9, 21, 57609) Gur, jaggery or molasses is produced as by product in the manufacture of crystallized sugar.
('66', 32, 9, 22, 57702) Gur, consisting of cane sugar and fruitsugar in the
('66', 32, 10, 23, 57754) 1 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('66', 33, 0, 1, 57791) 34 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('66', 33, 1, 2, 57832) proportion of 2 to 1, would be assimilated more rapidly than cane sugar alone taken in the same quantity.
('66', 33, 1, 3, 57938) Therefore, the nutritive value of gur is at least 33 p.c.
('66', 33, 1, 4, 57996) superior to refined sugar.
('66', 33, 1, 5, 58023) The truth of the opinion can be tested by everybody for himself by trying pure gur, chakki ground whole wheatmeal and hand pounded unpolished rice.
('66', 33, 1, 6, 58171) Harijan, 28 12 1934

('66', 35, 5, 7, 61296) 53. INTERVIEW TO ASSOCIATED PRESS
('66', 35, 6, 8, 61330) December 29, 1934
('66', 35, 7, 9, 61348) Mahatma Gandhi said that he hoped to leave Delhi on January 28, 1935, as he must be at Wardha positively on the 29th.
('66', 35, 7, 10, 61466) His work here is primarily concerned with Harijan uplift in this area, and also the promotion of village industries nearabouts.
('66', 35, 7, 11, 61594) He wished to make it perfectly clear that his visit had no connection with the work in the new Assembly, which begins on January 21. It was by pure accident that the Assembly work of Congressmen commences at a time when Mahatma Gandhi is here in connection with Harijan and village uplift work.
('66', 35, 8, 12, 61889) Questioned about his proposal to visit the Frontier in view of the Viceroy’s advice against it, Mahatma Gandhi said: It is beyond me and I have nothing to say at present.

('66', 35, 10, 14, 62092) 54. DISCUSSION AT HARIJAN HOME, KINGSWAY CAMP, DELHI 1
('66', 35, 11, 15, 62147) [December 29, l934] 2
('66', 35, 12, 16, 62169) [GANDHIJI:] Is this the hut that I was told was being hurriedly erected for me?
('66', 35, 12, 17, 62249) Why this height of 16 feet, and these heavy pillars and this high plinth?
('66', 35, 12, 18, 62323) A simple cutcha hut with grass thatched roof was the one I had in mind and had expected to find here.
('66', 35, 12, 19, 62425) It should not have cost more than Rs. 500, whereas this has cost Rs. 2,500.
('66', 35, 13, 20, 62501) [MALKANI:] The thing had to be hurriedly arranged.
('66', 35, 13, 21, 62552) We have not had more than two rooms, we thought we should have a small terrace where we could have a little
('66', 35, 14, 22, 62660) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Not Hut but a Palace”
('66', 35, 15, 23, 62716) 2 On this date Gandhiji arrived at the Hariian Home.
('66', 36, 0, 1, 62769) VOL.66 : 16 DECEMBER, 1934 24 APRIL, 1935 37
('66', 36, 1, 2, 62814) shamiana and where you might get plenty of sun and privacy as well.
('66', 36, 1, 3, 62882) We went in for iron beams and rafters, as wooden ones would have taken much time.
('66', 36, 1, 4, 62964) [G.] No excuse at all.
('66', 36, 1, 5, 62987) If you knew that this thing was going to cost so much, why did you not give up the idea altogether?
('66', 36, 1, 6, 63087) I should have been perfectly comfortable in a tent.
('66', 36, 1, 7, 63139) The pity is that you for got that you were the representative of Harijans and villagers.
('66', 36, 1, 8, 63228) You acted as Sjt.
('66', 36, 1, 9, 63246) Ghanshyamdas’s representative.
('66', 36, 1, 10, 63277) If you had engaged some villa gers to put up a genuine, bonafide village hut, you would have had a sample of the work that our villagers can still do, and it would have conformed to our standard.
('66', 36, 1, 11, 63473) And why this spiral staircase?
('66', 36, 1, 12, 63504) You might easily have procured a wooden staircase!
('66', 36, 2, 13, 63555) [M.] No Bapu, it has been borrowed and will be returned as soon as we do not need it.
('66', 36, 3, 14, 63641) In the evening, to cap the tale of our woe, came a newly bought spittoon, and it was placed on his table by an unwary friend.

('66', 36, 7, 23, 64252) Well, send this back at once.
('66', 36, 7, 24, 64282) I should be satisfied with a small earthen cup which costs almost nothing.
('66', 36, 7, 25, 64357) I thought you would instinctively understand these things.
('66', 36, 7, 26, 64416) Well, now let me tell you that if anything is purchased without my permission, I might be driven to non co operation with you.
('66', 36, 8, 27, 64543) It was bed time.

('66', 36, 9, 29, 64616) No bed stead necessary.

('66', 38, 6, 23, 67858) Since you have unshakable faith in the power of Ramanama, you will certainly experience the truth of your faith.
('66', 38, 6, 24, 67971) Go on repeating it even if you see darkness all around.
('66', 38, 6, 25, 68027) If you do that, all will be well with you.
('66', 38, 6, 26, 68070) The small size of land holdings is a big problem.
('66', 38, 6, 27, 68120) It will present difficulties even when we have power in our hands.

('66', 47, 5, 21, 86251) It is a stupendous task, but it has to be done.
('66', 47, 5, 22, 86299) I have said it several times, and shall repeat it today, that, unless we discharge our debt, Hinduism will perish.
('66', 47, 5, 23, 86414) Untouchability must be destroyed, or else it will destroy Hinduism.
('66', 47, 5, 24, 86482) That is why I am giving myself no rest.
('66', 47, 5, 25, 86522) Not that I do not need it.
('66', 47, 5, 26, 86549) I may say that I have several years of arrears of rest to cover, but how can I have rest?

('66', 47, 5, 29, 86799) Not, surely, until the volcano is extinguished.
('66', 47, 5, 30, 86847) In a stupendous task of this character, a gift of Rs. 3,500, like the one given by Ghanshyamdasji today, is as a drop in the ocean.
('66', 47, 5, 31, 86979) Hundreds of millionaires like him will have to empty their treasures for this sacred task.

('66', 47, 5, 33, 87141) There is no lack of money, as Ghanshyamdasji said.
('66', 47, 5, 34, 87192) There will be none.
('66', 47, 5, 35, 87212) All that is needed is the will and passion for it.
('66', 47, 5, 36, 87263) The service of the Harijans is the service of Hinduism, and the service of Hinduism is the service of humanity.

('66', 48, 7, 14, 88175) 67. LETTER TO CARL HEATH January 3, 1935
('66', 48, 8, 15, 88216) DEAR FRIEND, I thank you for your letter of 21st ultimo.
('66', 48, 8, 16, 88273) Your previous letter was read by Mirabehn, Mahadev and later by Andrews.
('66', 48, 8, 17, 88346) All of them puts independently of me, the same construction that I had.
('66', 48, 8, 18, 88418) Of course, I unreservedly accept your correction.
('66', 48, 8, 19, 88468) I simply want to say that it was after carefully reading your letter more than three times that I sent you the reply 2 I did.
('66', 48, 8, 20, 88594) Andrews also read my reply to you, and he hadnothing to suggest by way of alteration.
('66', 48, 8, 21, 88680) Of course, you knew the existence of the repressive laws.
('66', 48, 8, 22, 88738) But you did not know, nor do you know now, what their continuance meant or means to us here.
('66', 48, 8, 23, 88831) A strange confirmation of this comes from Dr. Maude Royden who is reported to have said at Karachi that the people in England knew nothing, through the daily Press or otherwise, of the amazing things which she heard during the two or three days she found herself amongst the very sober women of India.
('66', 48, 8, 24, 89133) Andrews will be able to give you first hand testimony of what he saw and learnt in Bengal.
('66', 48, 8, 25, 89224) You seem to regard the possibility of withdrawal of the
('66', 48, 9, 26, 89280) 1 M. V. Abhyankar died on January 2, 1935.
('66', 48, 10, 27, 89323) 2 Vide , “Letter to Carl Heath”, 10 12 1934
('66', 49, 0, 1, 89367) 50 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('66', 49, 1, 2, 89408) forthcoming Bill 1 as a calamity.
('66', 49, 1, 3, 89442) In my opinion, if the withdrawal comes even at the last moment, it will be a blessing both for England and India, for the simple reason that persistence in the measure in the face of an almost unanimous Indian opposition to it would mean an unbending attitude on the part of the British Parliament and utter contempt for Indian public opinion.
('66', 49, 1, 4, 89786) I hope you have seen the bitter comment made by Rt.
('66', 49, 1, 5, 89838) Sastri, who was at one time a persona grata at the India Office whose complete confidence he enjoyed, and the equally bitter comment of Hon.
('66', 49, 1, 6, 89979) C. Y. Chintamani, who has been regarded as a moderate among moderates and who has, in season and out of season, condemned the Congress attitude in unmeasured language.
('66', 49, 1, 7, 90147) Now for the briefest summary of my own personal objections to the J. P. C. Report.
('66', 49, 1, 8, 90230) I read that Report and the White Paper as one document.
('66', 49, 1, 9, 90286) Whatever new there is in the former is not regarded at this end as an improvement, but quite the contrary, and it is the last straw which has broken the back of the Liberals.
('66', 49, 1, 10, 90461) They had cherished the fond hope that the Joint Memorandum signed under the leadership of the Aga Khan would receive the favourable consideration of the Joint Parliamentary Committee and that some, if not all, of its recommenda tions would be accepted by it.
('66', 49, 1, 11, 90720) The contemptuous dismissal of that Memorandum, beyond a mere courteous reference to it, has extorted the following remark from Sastri:
('66', 49, 2, 12, 90855) No, Sir, it is impossible for the Liberal Party to give an atom of co operation.
('66', 49, 2, 13, 90936) Co operation with friends that wish well of us will be worth while, but co operation with those who have displayed the utmost distrust ofus, who do not care for our views and demands, and who enact a constitution in utter disregard of our wishes, what is co operation with them, I ask?
('66', 49, 2, 14, 91222) I should call it a suicide.
('66', 49, 3, 15, 91250) SUMMARY
('66', 49, 4, 16, 91258) 1. There is no suggestion in the J. P. C. Report that there should be a clause in the constitution providing for automatic advance to complete independence or whatever the elected representatives of India may decide to have.
('66', 49, 4, 17, 91483) 2. The contemplated constitution saddles India with a greater financial burden than she is bearing today without any prospect of economic or political betterment.
('66', 49, 5, 18, 91646) 1 The Government of India Bill on a new constitution for India.
('66', 49, 5, 19, 91710) It received Royal assent and became an Act on August 2, 1935.
('66', 50, 0, 1, 91772) VOL.66 : 16 DECEMBER, 1934 24 APRIL, 1935 51
('66', 50, 1, 2, 91817) 3. At the centre, 80 per cent of the revenue is reserved out of any popular control.
('66', 50, 1, 3, 91902) 4. There is no popular control over the military, whether as to policy or as to expenditure.
('66', 50, 1, 4, 91995) 5. There is no popular control over the currency or the exchange of the country.
('66', 50, 1, 5, 92076) 6. Even the control over the 20 per cent proposed to be left in the hands of the Finance Minister is subject to suspension by the Governor General.
('66', 50, 1, 6, 92224) 7. The provincial autonomy adumbrated in the Report is purely nominal, as the Governors of the provinces have such wide powers that they can, whenever they choose, make an end of responsibility.
('66', 50, 1, 7, 92419) It would be utterly wrong for any Britisher to infer from Colonial precedents that these powers will be rarely, if ever, exercised.
('66', 50, 1, 8, 92551) Indian past experience is quite the contrary.
('66', 50, 1, 9, 92597) 8. Responsible Ministers have no right even to transfer any member, either of the all India service or of the provincial service.
('66', 50, 1, 10, 92727) 9. The so called autonomous legislatures will have no right to amend the Police Acts or even Police Regulations.
('66', 50, 1, 11, 92840) 10. British exploitation is made firmer than ever.
('66', 50, 1, 12, 92891) The overwhelming effect of all the foregoing objections consi dered together leaves an indelible impression upon the mind that, bad as the existing constitution is, the threatened new one will be infinitely worse.
('66', 50, 1, 13, 93105) And what is more, if the threatened new constitution is passed, it would be most difficult for years to come to undo the mischief that will be done under it.
('66', 50, 1, 14, 93263) To clinch the whole of the objections, it is well to remember that the constitution is sought to be imposed upon the people who are already groaning under repression, such as, perhaps, has not been equalled in British Indian history.
('66', 50, 1, 15, 93497) I am making this statement with the full sense of my responsibility.
('66', 50, 1, 16, 93566) I have a vivid memory of Jallianwala Bagh.
('66', 50, 1, 17, 93609) I have read Kaye and Malleson’s volumes on the Sepoy Revolt, as it has been called, of 1857. Both make gruesome reading.
('66', 50, 1, 18, 93730) Then, it was the naked sword.
('66', 50, 1, 19, 93760) The repression represents the gloved fist, but deadlier on that account.
('66', 50, 1, 20, 93833) You may make whatever private use you wish of this letter.
('66', 50, 1, 21, 93892) Nobody else is responsible for the opinion I have expressed in this.
('66', 50, 1, 22, 93961) It has been shown to no friend beyond Mahadev, Mira and the typist.
('66', 50, 1, 23, 94029) My writing may seem bitter; but I would like to warn you against putting any such interpretation upon it.
('66', 50, 1, 24, 94135) The language
('66', 51, 0, 1, 94148) 52 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('66', 51, 1, 2, 94189) represents the truth and nothing but the truth as I have seen and felt it.
('66', 51, 1, 3, 94264) It does not represent the whole truth.
('66', 51, 1, 4, 94303) If I had the time and the capacity to give you the whole truth, the version would be even worse than it is.
('66', 51, 1, 5, 94411) In spite, however, of the black picture that I see in it, I have no bitterness in me against a single Englishman.
('66', 51, 1, 6, 94525) I believe that the English Ministers are pursuing what they believe to be an honest policy to be adopted in the interest of India.
('66', 51, 1, 7, 94656) It is their honest belief that British rule in India has been, on the whole, for her good.
('66', 51, 1, 8, 94747) They honestly believe that under it India has advanced in economic progress and in political capacity, and that if India received the constitution that the vast number of the intelligentsia wish for, it would be a bad day for her.
('66', 51, 1, 9, 94978) It is difficult to combat an honest belief, however erroneous it may be, as, in my opinion, it is in this case.
('66', 51, 1, 10, 95090) But it would also be wrong to be angry over an honest belief of any person.
('66', 51, 1, 11, 95166) Whilst, therefore, I hold the strong opinion that I have expressed in the foregoing summary I would ask you to believe me implicitly when I give you my assurance that, God helping, I shall take no step in haste or in anger.
('66', 51, 1, 12, 95390) I have retired from the Congress because, among other reasons, I want to impose silence upon myself, so far as it is humanly possible, about the political measures of the Government.
('66', 51, 1, 13, 95573) I want, in my volun tary isolation, to explore the yet hidden possibilities of non violence.
('66', 51, 1, 14, 95666) Every action I am taking, no matter in what department of life, is being taken with that end in view.
('66', 51, 1, 15, 95768) The only axe that I have to grind on this earth is to try to understand the ultimate truth of things which, at present, I seem to see only dimly.
('66', 51, 1, 16, 95914) And after a laborious search I have come to the conclusion that if I am to see it in any fullness I can only do so by non violence in thought, word and deed.
('66', 51, 1, 17, 96072) What this search will lead me to, I really do not know myself, nor have I the slightest desire to see it before its time.
('66', 51, 1, 18, 96194) For me, therefore, it is an incessant waiting upon God to show me the next step, and I shall be grateful if any of you friends can, with your full hearts, help me in that search.
('66', 51, 1, 19, 96373) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI CARL HEATH, ESQ.

('66', 53, 4, 7, 98201) 70. NOTES
('66', 53, 5, 8, 98211) A CORRECTION
('66', 53, 6, 9, 98224) In reference to the figures of production and sale given by the Secretary, A.I.S.A., in the self sufficiency report published in our issue of the 9th November, he writes: 1
('66', 53, 7, 10, 98397) In Harijan dated 9 11 34, on page 312, figures of khadi production and sale of A.I.S.A. branches have appeared.
('66', 53, 7, 11, 98509) Therein, with reference to Karnatak and Utkal Branches, it has been stated in the footnote that ‘the production of the branches being inadequate, khadi had to be imported from [other] branches to meet the demand’.
('66', 53, 7, 12, 98723) This remark does not apply to Utkal.
('66', 53, 7, 13, 98760) The purchases of the Utkal Branch from other branches during 1933 amounted to only Rs. 557, and not over Rs. 17,000 as would appear from the remark made.
('66', 53, 7, 14, 98914) We regret the error.
('66', 53, 8, 15, 98935) HARIJAN REPRESENTATION
('66', 53, 9, 16, 98958) At the request of a correspondent, I had asked Thakkar Bapa to tell me how many Harijans there were in Harijan Sevak Boards in all India.
('66', 53, 9, 17, 99096) The returns so far received show, for ten provinces, 171 Harijan members against 1,158 non Harijans.
('66', 53, 9, 18, 99197) I give the figures by way of information only.
('66', 53, 9, 19, 99244) It would be wrong to infer that these figures are a sign of solid work.
('66', 53, 9, 20, 99316) They are undoubtedly evidence of two things: (1) The Boards have tried to take as their co members as many Harijans as they could find to help them.
('66', 53, 9, 21, 99465) (2) There are enough Hindus of standing who are prepared to lend their names to the Boards, whose avowed object is to seek forHarijans equality with the rest of their fellow Hindus in matters social, economical, political and religious.
('66', 53, 9, 22, 99702) I wish it were possible for me to add also that the number of so
('66', 53, 10, 23, 99767) 1 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('66', 54, 0, 1, 99804) VOL. 66 : 16 DECEMBER, 1934 24 APRIL, 1935 55
('66', 54, 1, 2, 99850) many caste Hindus and Harijan Hindus on the Boards is a sign of solid progress.
('66', 54, 1, 3, 99930) Indeed, the large number of members on the Boards adds to the expenses of administration without increasing efficiency or the output of work.
('66', 54, 1, 4, 100072) Means are being devised to increase efficiency and output, even if it should involve reduction of the number of members.
('66', 54, 1, 5, 100193) In the service of the poor and the down trodden, limitation of overhead expenses to a minimum is absolutely necessary.
('66', 54, 1, 6, 100312) For the helpless can exercise no check on the extravagance, be it unconscious, of their helpers, no matter how benevolent, and the latter, unless they would put checks on their unconscious extravagance in the name of better management, are likely to spend more than they need.
('66', 54, 1, 7, 100589) A critical examination of the administration of many charitable organizations would either reveal woeful extravagance or hopeless mismanagement and a criminal neglect of their trust by the trustees.
('66', 54, 1, 8, 100788) Harijan Boards have to escape both misfortunes, if they are to render a good account of themselves to the Harijans, whom it is their sole aim to serve.

('66', 55, 3, 5, 101681) 72. ITS MEANING
('66', 55, 4, 6, 101697) To my unaided mind you appear to be opening the first campaign of an endless and quixotic war against modern civilization.
('66', 55, 4, 7, 101820) Long ago you proclaimed yourself its sleepless enemy, and now you would, if you could, turn it back on the course it has pursued for some millennia.
('66', 55, 4, 8, 101969) I reel at the mere thought.
('66', 55, 5, 9, 101997) This is from an intimate letter from a dear friend who wrote in reply to my letter, inquiring if he could extend his co operation in the effort.
('66', 55, 5, 10, 102142) As the view expressed so frankly by the friend is, I know, shared by quite a number of friends, it is well for me to explain my position.
('66', 55, 5, 11, 102280) It would be impertinent for me to do so if my position was not also that of the A.I.V.I.A. In seeking to revive such village industries as are capable of being revived, I am making no such attempt as the friend ascribes to me.
('66', 55, 5, 12, 102507) I am trying to do what every lover of village life, everyone who realizes the tragic meaning of the disintegration of villages, is doing or trying to do.
('66', 55, 5, 13, 102661) Why am I turning back the course of modern civilization when I ask the villager to grind his own meal, eat it whole, including the nourishing bran, or when I ask him to turn his sugar cane into gur for his own requirements, if not for sale?
('66', 55, 5, 14, 102902) Am I turning back the course of modern civilization when I ask the villagers not merely to grow raw produce, but to turn it into marketable products and thereby add a few more pies to their daily income?
('66', 55, 5, 15, 103106) And surely modern civilization is not millennia old.
('66', 55, 5, 16, 103159) We can almost give its birth an exact date.
('66', 55, 5, 17, 103203) If I could do it, I would most assuredly destroy or radically change much that goes under the name of modern civilization.
('66', 55, 5, 18, 103326) But that is an old story of life.
('66', 55, 5, 19, 103360) The attempt is undoubtedly there.
('66', 55, 5, 20, 103394) Its success depends upon God.
('66', 55, 5, 21, 103424) But the attempt to revive and encourage the remunerative village industries is not part ofsuch an attempt, except in so far as every one of my activities, including the propagation of non violence, can be described as such
('66', 55, 6, 22, 103647) 1 Vide , footnote 1”Letter to V. S. Srinivasa Sastri”,17 11 1934
('66', 56, 0, 1, 103712) VOL. 66 : 16 DECEMBER, 1934 24 APRIL, 1935 57
('66', 56, 1, 2, 103758) an attempt.
('66', 56, 1, 3, 103770) The revival of village industries is but an extension of the khadi effort.
('66', 56, 1, 4, 103845) Hand spun cloth, hand made paper, hand pounded rice, home made bread and jam, are not uncommon in the West.
('66', 56, 1, 5, 103953) Only, there they do not have one hundredth of the importance they have in India.
('66', 56, 1, 6, 104034) For, with us, their revival means life, their destruction means death, to the villagers, as he who runs may see.
('66', 56, 1, 7, 104147) Whatever the machine age may do, it will never give employment to the millions whom the wholesale introduction of power machinery must displace.
('66', 56, 2, 8, 104292) Harijan, 4 1 1935

('66', 57, 1, 2, 105514) 74. LETTER TO VASUMATI PANDIT
('66', 57, 2, 3, 105544) January 4, 1935
('66', 57, 3, 4, 105560) VASUMATI,
('66', 57, 4, 5, 105570) I have your letter.
('66', 57, 4, 6, 105590) It is all right if you take boiled milk when fresh milk is not available.
('66', 57, 4, 7, 105664) You must not discontinue uncooked vegetables or fruit.
('66', 57, 4, 8, 105719) The menu should also include bhakhris 1 of whole wheat flour and roasted wheat.

('66', 59, 0, 1, 108786) 60 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('66', 59, 1, 2, 108827) 78. SPEECH AT MEETING OF CENTRAL BOARD, HARIJAN SEVAK SANGH 1
('66', 59, 2, 3, 108889) [January 5, 1935] 2
('66', 59, 3, 4, 108909) It is impossible to over estimate the value of meticulous detail in your estimates.
('66', 59, 3, 5, 108993) The path of service to the Harijans is strait and sharp as the razor’s edge, simply because the goal is that of complete self purification.
('66', 59, 3, 6, 109133) We can never be too critical of ourselves and every pie we get must be received as a dedication to God and used as a sacred trust.
('66', 59, 3, 7, 109264) Broad heads, therefore, will never do, there is no room in your estimates for ‘etceteras’ and ‘sundries’.
('66', 59, 3, 8, 109370) For instance, I could not tolerate the item ‘books, slates, etc., given free’.
('66', 59, 3, 9, 109449) Supposing someone gave us a free gift of intoxicating drugs?
('66', 59, 3, 10, 109510) Would they come under the item?
('66', 59, 3, 11, 109542) No ‘post, telegrams, etc.’, either, nor newspapers, nor expenditure on rent.
('66', 59, 3, 12, 109619) For you should be in a position to say: ‘We do not need to spend money on telegrams, we send messages through kind messengers who will take them; we need spend nothing on rent, for we have persuaded some good friends to give us a house.’ Expenditure on administration I can tolerate only to a certain extent, and I do not see any need for separate propaganda.
('66', 59, 3, 13, 109979) Actual solid work is the most eloquent propaganda.
('66', 59, 3, 14, 110030) I confess I allowed myself to be used for the purpose in that I suffered Thakkar Bapa to carry me about in his circus for about a year; but though I went from place to place under his directions, I must say that the best and the only part I could reconcile myself to was the walking tour in Orissa.
('66', 59, 3, 15, 110329) Emulate me there if you can.
('66', 59, 3, 16, 110358) The mutest servant is the most eloquent propagandist.
('66', 59, 3, 17, 110412) Run a school yourself for Harijans, open a well or temple, help in digging a well or building a village school house for Harijans.
('66', 59, 3, 18, 110543) That will be true propaganda.
('66', 59, 3, 19, 110573) I would ask you to copy the example of Mr. Frazer Hoyland, a schoolmaster from South Wales, who has come to work with his own hands in the Bihar earthquake area under M. Pierre Ceresole.
('66', 59, 3, 20, 110760) He has worked among the unemployed people in England and Wales, and knows that writing books and pamphlets is no propaganda, but that manual work and sharing in the toil of people one would serve is true propaganda.
('66', 59, 3, 21, 110976) I should, therefore, not hesitate to drop the column for propaganda.
('66', 59, 3, 22, 111045) You have a column showing office expenses.
('66', 59, 3, 23, 111088) I can understand that in our poor country we cannot run our offices free of cost, but even there, run it through Harijans.
('66', 59, 3, 24, 111211) If we must have peons, have only Harijans for the purpose,
('66', 59, 4, 25, 111270) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “The Self introspection Week” 2 From Gandhijini Dinwari
('66', 60, 0, 1, 111359) VOL. 66 : 16 DECEMBER, 1934 24 APRIL, 1935 61
('66', 60, 1, 2, 111405) not treating them as peons but as your sons or members of your family.
('66', 60, 1, 3, 111476) Expenditure on ashrams is a thing I must strongly warn you against.
('66', 60, 1, 4, 111544) Let us drop the name of ‘ashram’ for it cannot be run without a solid fund of moral and spiritual capital.
('66', 60, 1, 5, 111651) One of the branch Sanghs has budgeted Rs. 8,000 for an ashram.
('66', 60, 1, 6, 111714) Well, I should rule it out, unless they can show that they are doing work worth 8 lacs.
('66', 60, 1, 7, 111802) Broadly I might say that you should not spend a rupee until you are sure that you are getting ten rupees’ worth of work out of it.
('66', 60, 2, 8, 111933) Harijan, 11 1 1935

As a teacher who has moved rather intimately with her students I have had occasion to come across some who, through ignorance and through information gathered from unhealthy sources during the period of adolescence, resorted to practices that were not conducive either to their physical or moral well being.

('66', 76, 3, 4, 141721) I hope you will gladly welcome the compromise arrived at in the dispute that was going on regarding your wages.
('66', 76, 3, 5, 141833) 1 It will be in your interest to accept willingly the cut in your wages —that will enhance your credit too, I have no doubt about it.
('66', 76, 3, 6, 141967) I do not consider it a small matter that the main principle of the policy which we wanted to adopt years ago has been accepted in this compromise.
('66', 76, 3, 7, 142114) Now we have to make a scheme at our earliest convenience to implement it.
('66', 76, 3, 8, 142188) I need not tell you that its success mostly depends on your pure intentions and conduct.
('66', 76, 3, 9, 142277) The welfare of both the employees and the employers lies in the mill continuing to function.
('66', 76, 3, 10, 142370) He who understands this will never find it difficult to understand this compromise.
('66', 76, 3, 11, 142454) I have been telling you from the very beginning of our acquaintance that the industry exclusively belongs neither to the mill owners nor to the labourers.
('66', 76, 3, 12, 142609) The capital of the owners is money while yours is labour.
('66', 76, 3, 13, 142667) Both of these are useless unless there is unity between the two.
('66', 76, 3, 14, 142732) If you have grasped what I am saying you will realize that the good of both lies in this compromise.
('66', 76, 3, 15, 142833) You will also know how much progress we have made and how near we are towards the realization of the dream that we had been cherishing all along.
('66', 76, 3, 16, 142979) I therefore hope that all the sisters and brothers will unanimously accept the compromise.
('66', 76, 4, 17, 143070) From a copy of the Gujarati: Pyarelal Papers.
('66', 76, 4, 18, 143116) Courtesy: Pyarelal
('66', 76, 5, 19, 143135) 100. A DISCUSSION
('66', 76, 6, 20, 143153) [Before January 14, 1935] 2
('66', 76, 7, 21, 143181) Your campaign 3 is taking away from the Missionary’s popularity.
('66', 76, 7, 22, 143246) [GANDHIJI:] I see what you mean but I do not know why it should disturb them.
('66', 76, 7, 23, 143324) We are not traders trenching on one another’s province.
('66', 76, 7, 24, 143380) If it is a matter of serving oneself, I should understand their attitude, but when it is entirely a matter of serving others, it should not worry them or me as to who serves them.
('66', 76, 8, 25, 143560) 1 Omission as in the source 2 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Notes”, dated January 14, 1935 3 Against untouchability
('66', 77, 0, 1, 143685) 78 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('66', 77, 1, 2, 143726) But, perhaps, the authorities in charge of a Mission hospital would rightly feel worried if you sent your people to go and open a hospital in the same place.
('66', 77, 1, 3, 143884) But they should understand that ours is a different mission.
('66', 77, 1, 4, 143945) We do not go there to afford them simple medical relief or a knowledge of the three R’s; our going to them is a small proof of our repentance and our assurance to them that we will not exploit them any more.
('66', 77, 1, 5, 144153) I should never think of opening a hospital where there is already one; but if there is a Mission school, I should not mind opening another for Harijan children, and I would even encourage them to prefer our school to the other.
('66', 77, 1, 6, 144381) Let us frankly understand the position.
('66', 77, 1, 7, 144421) If the object is purely humanitarian, purely that of carrying education where there is none, they should be thankful that someone whose obvious duty it is to put his own house in order wakes up to a sense of his duty.
('66', 77, 1, 8, 144639) But my trouble is that the Missionary friends do not bring to bear on their work a purely humanitarian spirit.
('66', 77, 1, 9, 144750) Their object is to add more members to their fold, and that is why they are disturbed.
('66', 77, 1, 10, 144837) The complaint which I have been making all these years is more than justified by what you say.
('66', 77, 1, 11, 144932) Some of the friends of a Mission were the other day in high glee over the conversion to Christianity of a learned pandit.
('66', 77, 1, 12, 145054) They have been dear friends, and so I told them that it was hardly proper to go into ecstasies over a man forsaking his religion.
('66', 77, 1, 13, 145184) Today it is the case of a learned Hindu, tomorrow it may be that of an ignorant villager not knowing the principles of his religion.
('66', 77, 1, 14, 145317) Why should Missionaries complain if I open a school which is more liked by Harijans than theirs?
('66', 77, 1, 15, 145414) Is it not natural?
('66', 77, 2, 16, 145433) But does it mean that you would say the same thing about a Christian who embraces Hinduism?
('66', 77, 2, 17, 145525) I would.
('66', 77, 2, 18, 145534) Here is Mirabehn.
('66', 77, 2, 19, 145552) I would have her find all the spiritual comfort she needs from Christianity, and I should not dream of converting her to Hinduism, even if she wanted to do so.
('66', 77, 2, 20, 145712) Today it is the case of a grown up woman like her, tomorrow it may be that of a European child trusted to my care by a friend.
('66', 77, 2, 21, 145839) Take the case of Khan Saheb’s daughter entrusted to my care by her father.
('66', 77, 2, 22, 145914) I should jealously educate her in her own faith and should strive my utmost against her being lured away from it if ever she was so inclined.
('66', 77, 2, 23, 146056) I have had the privilege of having children and grown up persons of other faiths with me.
('66', 77, 2, 24, 146146) I was thankful to find them better Christians, Mussalmans, Parsis or Jews by their contact with me.
('66', 77, 3, 25, 146246) But if it was a pure case of conscience?
('66', 78, 0, 1, 146287) VOL. 66 : 16 DECEMBER, 1934 24 APRIL, 1935 79
('66', 78, 1, 2, 146333) I am no keeper of anybody’s conscience, but I do feel that it argues some sort of weakness on the part of a person who easily declares his or her failure to derive comfort from the faith in which he or she is born.
('66', 78, 1, 3, 146548) Harijan, 25 1 1935
('66', 78, 2, 4, 146567) 101. FOREWORD TO “TWO SERVANTS OF GOD”
('66', 78, 3, 5, 146606) DELHI, January 14, 1935 Though I had always longed for it, I was never able to be with Khan Saheb Abdul Ghaffar Khan for any length of time before the closing months of last year.
('66', 78, 3, 6, 146786) Good fortune, however, brought me not only the younger brother but also the elder, Dr. Khan Saheb, very soon after their discharge from Hazaribagh prison.
('66', 78, 3, 7, 146941) As luck would have it, they were under orders not to enter the Frontier Province till 28th December last.
('66', 78, 3, 8, 147047) They were under discipline not to offer Civil Disobedience.
('66', 78, 3, 9, 147107) And so they accepted the hospitality of Seth Jamnalal Bajaj in Wardha.
('66', 78, 3, 10, 147178) I was thus privileged to come in intimate touch with the brothers.
('66', 78, 3, 11, 147245) The more I knew them the more attracted I felt towards them.
('66', 78, 3, 12, 147306) I was struck by their transparent sincerity, frankness and utmostsimplicity.
('66', 78, 3, 13, 147383) I observed, too, that they had come to believe in truth and non violence, not as a policy but as a creed.
('66', 78, 3, 14, 147489) The younger brother, I found, was consumed with deep religious fervour.
('66', 78, 3, 15, 147561) His was not a narrow creed.
('66', 78, 3, 16, 147589) I found him to be a universalist.
('66', 78, 3, 17, 147623) His politics, if he had any, were derived from his religion.
('66', 78, 3, 18, 147684) The Doctor had no politics.
('66', 78, 3, 19, 147712) This privileged contact led me to the conclusion that the brothers were much misunderstood.
('66', 78, 3, 20, 147804) I, therefore, asked Mahadev Desai to note all he could from them of their lives and prepare for the public a sketch introducing them as men.
('66', 78, 3, 21, 147945) He was to leave politics alone and avoid criticism of the Government.
('66', 78, 3, 22, 148015) The result is this character sketch.
('66', 78, 3, 23, 148052) Let the reader judge whether the brothers’ claim to be known as simple Khudai Khidmatgars (i.e., Servants of God) is vindicated by the following pages, assuming that they give an accurate and truthful recital of the events of their lives as the brothers gave them to Mahadev Desai.
('66', 78, 3, 24, 148334) M. K. GANDHI Two Servants of God

('66', 85, 1, 2, 157778) 111. LETTER TO GANGABEHN VAIDYA
('66', 85, 2, 3, 157810) January, 15, 1935
('66', 85, 3, 4, 157828) GANGABEHN,
('66', 85, 4, 5, 157839) This, being hand made paper, is more expensive than ordinary paper and I, therefore, use it economically.
('66', 85, 4, 6, 157945) Since I started using it, consumption of paper has gone down to one half, just as consumption of khadi cloth has gone down to one tenth or even lower than that.
('66', 85, 4, 7, 158106) Everything indigenous is always cheaper in the end.
('66', 85, 4, 8, 158158) I am writing with a reed pen.
('66', 85, 4, 9, 158188) You are a keen observer.
('66', 85, 4, 10, 158213) Examine everything in your surroundings carefully.
('66', 85, 4, 11, 158264) Every article of food and clothing must, as far as possible, be indigenous.
('66', 85, 4, 12, 158340) Learn to eat fresh leaves uncooked, to drink milk without boiling it, to use wheat flour without sifting it and rice without polishing it.
('66', 85, 4, 13, 158479) If you learn only this and no more and teach the villagers to do likewise, crores of rupees will be saved.
('66', 85, 5, 14, 158586) Blessings from BAPU [From Gujarati]

('66', 88, 1, 2, 162521) 116. LETTER TO HARIBHAU PHATAK
('66', 88, 2, 3, 162552) DELHI, [January 17, 1935] 1
('66', 88, 3, 4, 162580) MY DEAR HARIBHAU,
('66', 88, 4, 5, 162598) I have your letter.
('66', 88, 4, 6, 162618) I can’t remember the letter you are referring to.
('66', 88, 4, 7, 162668) It is just likely that the tremendous pressure at which I am dealing with my correspondence has put your letter out of my mind and it is lying buried in the heap before me.
('66', 88, 4, 8, 162841) I have not said that there should be no propaganda.
('66', 88, 4, 9, 162893) Propaganda there must be.
('66', 88, 4, 10, 162919) I have said, and I still maintain, that there should be no paid propaganda or if there is, there ought to be a separate collection about it.
('66', 88, 4, 11, 163060) It is the business of savarna Hindus to organize such propaganda.
('66', 88, 4, 12, 163126) Therefore funds should be raised, if funds are necessary, earmarked for that purpose.
('66', 88, 4, 13, 163212) My own impression is that paid propaganda creates no effect whatsoever.
('66', 88, 4, 14, 163284) We conduct schools and hostels with a definite object, which is to discharge the obligation we owe to the Harijans.
('66', 88, 4, 15, 163400) It is wholly different in scope, therefore, from the establishment of schools, etc., under the old regime.
('66', 88, 4, 16, 163507) Every school we open is a fresh nail in the coffin of untouchability, and having travelled all over India in that cause you will let me judge the result.
('66', 88, 4, 17, 163661) It is therefore that I have said that the opening of schools and hostels [is] 2 the best propaganda for conducting the campaign against untouchability.
('66', 88, 4, 18, 163813) We have plenty of money; but where are the schoolmasters to be had?
('66', 88, 4, 19, 163881) Savarna schoolmasters are not to be picked up in the streets.
('66', 88, 4, 20, 163943) Now, reverse the process.
('66', 88, 4, 21, 163969) If you utilize 90 per cent of the funds for propaganda and reserve 10 per cent for schools, how will you measure the success you would have attained in the conversion of savarna Hindus as we are able to measure the result by the number of schools and hostels that we succeed in opening and conducting?
('66', 88, 4, 22, 164271) Daily I have letters from Harijans complaining of our spending money for purposes other than opening schools, hostels and the like.
('66', 88, 4, 23, 164403) I have no letter from anywhere complaining that we do not carry on enough propaganda.
('66', 88, 4, 24, 164489) Yours is the first letter received by me.
('66', 88, 5, 25, 164531) 1 The source has ‘17 1 1934’ which is evidently a slip.
('66', 88, 5, 26, 164587) In January, 1934 Gandhiji was on tour in the South.
('66', 88, 5, 27, 164639) 2 The source has ‘are’.
('66', 89, 0, 1, 164663) 90 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('66', 89, 1, 2, 164704) In Maharashtra I do not know what you will do in the matter of propaganda even if the whole of the collections were to be used by you for propaganda work.
('66', 89, 1, 3, 164859) Show me a programme and I am prepared to examine it on its own merits.
('66', 89, 1, 4, 164930) I have no bias.
('66', 89, 1, 5, 164946) One way or the other, my sole concern is to see that untouchability is removed.
('66', 89, 1, 6, 165026) I wonder if I have made my point perfectly clear.
('66', 89, 1, 7, 165076) If not, you must write again developing your views.
('66', 89, 1, 8, 165128) The complaint you make about the composition of the Maharashtra Provincial Board is, of course, your own speciality.
('66', 89, 1, 9, 165245) It has nothing to do with propaganda.
('66', 89, 1, 10, 165283) You have simply to get Deodhar to give you a minimum of time or ask him to retire in favour of one who can give the time, or have him as the ornamental head but have a Vice Chairman who would conduct the proceedings and actually organize the work from month to month, and even from day to day.
('66', 89, 1, 11, 165577) If you suggest any such Vice President, I will discuss the thing with Thakkar Bapa in the first instance.
('66', 89, 1, 12, 165683) Now about mill rice and hand pounded rice.
('66', 89, 1, 13, 165726) When you say that mill pounded polished rice is [not] dearer than hand pounded, I know that there is a flaw in your statement.
('66', 89, 1, 14, 165853) Hand pounded rice is as much polished as mill pounded polished rice.
('66', 89, 1, 15, 165922) You have to test the thing for yourself.
('66', 89, 1, 16, 165963) If you will take hand pounded unpolished rice, it would be any day and everywhere cheaper than mill polished rice when we compare the prices of unpolished mill pounded rice and unpolished hand pounded.
('66', 89, 1, 17, 166165) But you will never have the mills to produce unpolished rice in large quantities.
('66', 89, 1, 18, 166247) From the health standpoint, I have universal medical testimony that mill pounded unpolished rice suffers in vitamin when compared with hand pounded unpolished rice.
('66', 89, 1, 19, 166412) To remove the outermost husk is a very simple and expeditious process.
('66', 89, 1, 20, 166483) It is the polishing process by the hand which sends up the price of labour which I obliterate in my calculation because I do not want to go beyond the process of removing the outermost husk.
('66', 89, 1, 21, 166674) Make the investigation for yourself and then give me the prices.
('66', 89, 1, 22, 166739) You are not the only person who have committed the error if you have committed it.
('66', 89, 1, 23, 166822) It is most natural because we have never investigated these processes nor have we ever troubled to know the distinction between polished and unpolished rice.
('66', 89, 1, 24, 166980) Unpolished rice is a most beautiful grain.
('66', 89, 1, 25, 167023) It is either yellow, red or dark white, never white like the polished rice.
('66', 89, 1, 26, 167099) The red variety is the best, and sweet to taste, and cheaper withal.
('66', 89, 1, 27, 167168) I opened out one grain from the paddy and showed to those around me the full
('66', 90, 0, 1, 167245) VOL. 66 : 16 DECEMBER, 1934 24 APRIL, 1935 91
('66', 90, 1, 2, 167291) unpolished grain.
('66', 90, 1, 3, 167309) I had not seen it before.
('66', 90, 1, 4, 167335) But in a heap of half polished rice I saw a whole paddy grain.
('66', 90, 1, 5, 167398) I immediately removed the husk with my finger nails.
('66', 90, 1, 6, 167451) Out came the beautiful red grain from its husk.
('66', 90, 1, 7, 167499) I would defy anyone to show that such unpolished rice is dearer than mill polished rice.
('66', 90, 1, 8, 167588) Test again for your satisfaction and then tell me if you still claim to be right in your supposition that polished rice is cheaper than hand pounded unpolished rice.
('66', 90, 2, 9, 167754) Yours, BAPU SHRI HARIBHAU PHATAK 62 SADASHIV PETH POONA CITY
('66', 90, 3, 10, 167815) From a photostat: G.N. 1374

('66', 92, 12, 19, 170917) 121. WORKING COMMITTEE RESOLUTION
('66', 92, 13, 20, 170951) [On or before January 18, 1935] 1
('66', 92, 14, 21, 170985) Official announcement has been made that the Silver Jubilee of His Britannic Majesty’s reign is to be celebrated in India.
('66', 92, 14, 22, 171108) It is necessary for the Working Committee to guide the public as to the attitude to be adopted on the occasion.
('66', 92, 15, 23, 171220) 1 The Working Committee of the Congress met on January 16 and 18, 1935, during which time Gandhiji had discussions with the Committee and also drafted this resolution in connection with the Silver Jubilee celebrations of the Coronation of King George V
('66', 93, 0, 1, 171473) 94 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('66', 93, 1, 2, 171514) The Congress has and can have nothing but good wishes for the personal well being of His Majesty, but the Congress cannot ignore the fact that the rule in India with which His Majesty is naturally identified has been a positive hindrance to the political, moral and material growth of the nation.
('66', 93, 1, 3, 171811) It now threatens to culminate in a Constitution which, if enforced, promises to exploit the Nation, to drain her of what she still possesses of wealth and to harden her political subjection as has perhaps never been attempted before.
('66', 93, 1, 4, 172045) It is, therefore, impossible for the Working Committee to advise any participation in the forthcoming celebrations.
('66', 93, 1, 5, 172161) At the same time, the Working Committee has no desire by hostile demonstrations to wound the susceptibilities of Englishmen and others who will want to take part in the celebrations.
('66', 93, 1, 6, 172344) The Working Committee therefore, advises the general public, including Congressmen who may be members of elected bodies, to be satisfied with mere abstention from the events that may be arranged for celebration.
('66', 93, 1, 7, 172556) The Working Committee trusts that the authorities and responsible Englishmen will recognize and appreciate the honest and inevitable attitude of the Working Committee and refrain from unnecessarily wounding national self respect by compelling, directly or indirectly, participation in the forthcoming celebrations.
('66', 93, 2, 8, 172871) History of the Indian National Congress, Vol. I, p.

('66', 95, 1, 2, 175102) 124. LETTER TO JAGDISH SHASTRI January 19, 1935 BHAI JAGDISH SHASTRI,
('66', 95, 2, 3, 175172) A list of the chapters of the essay on cow protection is enclosed herewith.
('66', 95, 2, 4, 175248) You can add to it, you may even change the order.
('66', 95, 2, 5, 175298) 1. Origin of cow protection.
('66', 95, 2, 6, 175327) 2. The position in the Vedic Age.
('66', 95, 2, 7, 175361) 3. The position in the Age of the Smritis.
('66', 95, 2, 8, 175404) 4. The position in the Age of the Epics.
('66', 95, 2, 9, 175445) 5. The attitude of other religions.
('66', 95, 2, 10, 175481) 6. Origin of dispute with the Muslims.
('66', 95, 2, 11, 175520) 7. Is cow protection an essential feature of Hinduism?
('66', 95, 2, 12, 175575) If it is, then what does it signify?
('66', 95, 2, 13, 175612) Does the tradition date back to the ancient times?
('66', 95, 2, 14, 175663) Difference between the attitudes of the Arya Samajists and sanatanists and its critical appreciation.

('66', 95, 4, 19, 175977) 125. SPEECH AT SANSI BASTI, DELHI January 19, 1935 I had promised to Thakkar Bapa that I would visit this Harijan Colony some time for half an hour.
('66', 95, 4, 20, 176126) Today I have the opportunity to come here.
('66', 95, 4, 21, 176169) It is deplorable that first Hindu society has sinned against these Sansi brethren, regarding them as untouchables and then the Government on its part has declared them a criminal tribe.
('66', 95, 4, 22, 176355) It is a matter of shame for us Hindus that because of negligence on our part these people were left without work, and since they must make a living some of them adopted crime as a profession.
('66', 95, 4, 23, 176547) But not every one of them is a criminal, nor can it be so.
('66', 95, 4, 24, 176606) Nevertheless the whole community came to be called a criminal tribe.
('66', 95, 4, 25, 176675) I would ask the Sansi brethren to eschew the evil that has crept into their midst due to our indifference.
('66', 95, 4, 26, 176782) You should give up drink and gambling, and carrion too, if anyone takes it.
('66', 95, 4, 27, 176858) You should also give up stealing, etc., so that you can be recommended for exemption from reporting at police stations.
('66', 95, 4, 28, 176978) May God grant you the good sense to follow my advice.

('66', 96, 3, 4, 177184) He was taken upstairs as soon as Gandhiji was free to see him.

('66', 97, 5, 10, 179368) I do not know whether, while you listened to the story unfolded by the Begum Saheba, you were, like me, drawing a comparison between the history of Turkey and India.
('66', 97, 5, 11, 179534) I could not fail to draw many a parallel between the two stories.
('66', 97, 5, 12, 179600) No birth comes without agony, and as I listened to the story, not yet finished by the speaker, and not yet finished in action, I found that all is in the melting pot, all is transitory in this transitory world.
('66', 97, 5, 13, 179811) One could not say what would be the end of the world in which Turkey and India were but insignificant spots.
('66', 97, 5, 14, 179920) But it is best to know that what matters to India and to everybody is his or her own individual action.
('66', 97, 5, 15, 180024) For we must know that true history is not the history of kings and dynasties, but of individual men and women in general.
('66', 97, 5, 16, 180146) Some who died in utter neglect and misery were great heroes and heroines, not great kings, however big the empires they had founded and whatever the destruction they wrought on the face of the earth.
('66', 97, 5, 17, 180346) 3 The history of man and woman is still in the making.
('66', 97, 5, 18, 180401) What are a thousand or even a million years in the limitless cycle of time?
('66', 97, 5, 19, 180477) They are but a speck, and as I listened to the story of Turkey, I derived hope that, if we modelled our action according to the Right and nothing but the Right, there would be nothing but a bright future for us all.
('66', 97, 5, 20, 180693) There is an indissoluble tie that binds India to Turkey, not because we have suffered alike, but because Turkey has a Muslim population which has so much in common with India because of her millions of Muslims, who are flesh of our flesh and blood of our blood and bone of our bone.
