('66', 98, 9, 15, 182018) 129. DISCUSSION WITH EDITH HOWE MARTYN
('66', 98, 10, 16, 182057) [Before January 21, 1935] 2
('66', 98, 11, 17, 182085) She talked of her experience of the British slums and put in a strong plea for the “poor woman” who had to submit to the strong man.
('66', 98, 11, 18, 182218) [GANDHIJI:] There is no poor woman.
('66', 98, 11, 19, 182254) Poor woman is mightier than man, and I am quite prepared to demonstrate it to you if you come to the villages of India.
('66', 98, 11, 20, 182374) Any woman there would tell you that, if she did not want it, there was no man born of woman who could compel her.
('66', 98, 11, 21, 182488) I can say this from my own experience in relation to my wife, and mine is no solitary instance.
('66', 98, 11, 22, 182584) If the will to die rather than to yield is there, no monster can make the woman yield.
('66', 98, 11, 23, 182671) No, it is a mutual affair.
('66', 98, 11, 24, 182698) Men and women both are a mixture of the brute and the divine, and if we can subdue the brute, it is well and good.
('66', 98, 12, 25, 182813) But what is the woman to do, if the man for the sake of not having more children goes to another woman?
('66', 98, 12, 26, 182917) So now you are shifting your own ground.
('66', 98, 12, 27, 182958) If you misconceive

('66', 99, 1, 2, 183213) your premises, you are bound to come to wrong conclusions.
('66', 99, 1, 3, 183272) Don’t assume things and try to unman man and unwoman woman.
('66', 99, 1, 4, 183332) Let me understand the basis of your gospel.
('66', 99, 1, 5, 183376) When I said your birth control propaganda was sufficient introduction, there was some seriousness behind the joke, for I know that there are some men and women who think that in birth control lies our salvation.
('66', 99, 1, 6, 183588) Let me, therefore, understand the basis from you.
('66', 99, 2, 7, 183638) I do not see in it the salvation of the world, but what I say is that without some form of birth control there is no salvation.
('66', 99, 2, 8, 183766) You would do it in one way, I would do it in another.
('66', 99, 2, 9, 183820) I advocate your method as well, but not in all cases.
('66', 99, 2, 10, 183874) You seem to regard a beautiful function as something objectionable.
('66', 99, 2, 11, 183942) Two animals are nearest to the divine when they are going to create new life.
('66', 99, 2, 12, 184020) There is something very beautiful in the act.
('66', 99, 2, 13, 184066) Here again you are labouring under a confusion.
('66', 99, 2, 14, 184114) The creation of a new life is nearest the divine, I agree.
('66', 99, 2, 15, 184173) All I want is that one shouldapproach that act in a divine way.
('66', 99, 2, 16, 184237) That is to say, man and woman must come together with no other desire than that of creating a new life.
('66', 99, 2, 17, 184341) But if they come together merely to have a fond embrace, they are nearest the devil.
('66', 99, 2, 18, 184426) Man unfortunately forgets that he is nearest the divine, hankers after the brute instinct in himself and becomes less than the brute.
('66', 99, 3, 19, 184560) But why must you cast aspersion on the brute?
('66', 99, 4, 20, 184606) I do not.
('66', 99, 4, 21, 184616) The brute fulfils the law of his own nature.
('66', 99, 4, 22, 184661) The lion in his majesty is a noble creature and he has a perfect right to eat me up, but I have none to develop paws and pounce upon you.
('66', 99, 4, 23, 184799) Then I lower myself and become worse than the brute.
('66', 99, 5, 24, 184852) I am sorry.
('66', 99, 5, 25, 184864) I have expressed myself very badly.
('66', 99, 5, 26, 184900) I confess that in a majority of cases it is not going to be their salvation, but a factor which will conduce to higher life.
('66', 99, 5, 27, 185025) You understand what I mean, though I am afraid I have not been able to make myself quite clear.
('66', 99, 5, 28, 185121) Oh, no.
('66', 99, 5, 29, 185129) I do not want to take any undue advantage of you.
('66', 99, 5, 30, 185179) But I want you to understand my view point.
('66', 99, 5, 31, 185223) Do not run away with misconceptions.
('66', 99, 5, 32, 185260) Man must choose either of the two courses, the upward or the downward, but as he has the brute in him, he will more easily choose the downward course than the upward, especially when the downward course is presented to him in a beautiful garb.
('66', 99, 5, 33, 185504) Man easily capitulates when sin is presented in the garb of virtue, and that is what Marie Stopes 1 and others are doing.
('66', 99, 5, 34, 185626) If I were to popularize the

('66', 100, 1, 2, 185841) religion of indulgence, I know that men would simply clutch at it.
('66', 100, 1, 3, 185908) I know that, if people like you in selfless zeal cried themselves hoarse upholding your doctrine, you might even ride to apparent victory, but I also know that you will ride to certain death, of course totally unconscious of the mischief you are doing.
('66', 100, 1, 4, 186161) The downward instinct requires no advocacy, no argument.

('66', 107, 4, 13, 197803) 141. INTERVIEW TO UNITED PRESS 1
('66', 107, 5, 14, 197836) January 21, 1935
('66', 107, 6, 15, 197853) QUESTION: When do you think you will be able to give an actual start to the work of the Village Industries Association?
('66', 107, 7, 16, 197973) GANDHIJI: It is difficult to say what is meant by start.
('66', 107, 7, 17, 198030) But if by it is meant actual work through different agencies in villages, I am unable to fix the exact date, because we are moving very cautiously— cautiously in the sense that we do not want to make any mistakes so long as it is possible to avoid them—because of the varied nature of the work to be done.
('66', 107, 7, 18, 198336) This work is like sailing on an uncharted sea.
('66', 107, 7, 19, 198383) The Central Board is meeting in Wardha on the 1st of the next month, when perhaps a definite step will be taken.
('66', 107, 7, 20, 198496) Meanwhile, not a moment has been lost.
('66', 107, 7, 21, 198535) We have been collecting valuable information, and we are having promises of support from many quarters.
('66', 107, 8, 22, 198639) Q. Do you intend to start branches of the Association in all the provinces simultaneously, or do you intend to make a beginning in a few selected places?
('66', 107, 8, 23, 198793) Which will be the headquarters of the Association?
('66', 107, 8, 24, 198844) Will a branch be established here before you leave?
('66', 107, 9, 25, 198896) G. We aim at having no branches, but agencies all over India, the ideal being to have as many agents as there are villages, so as to ensure
('66', 107, 10, 26, 199036) 1 The report of the interview was revised by Gandhiji.
('66', 108, 0, 1, 199091) VOL.66:16 DECEMBER, 1934 24 APRIL, 1935 109
('66', 108, 1, 2, 199135) perfect distribution of work.
('66', 108, 1, 3, 199165) The secret of success of this effort lies in decentralization.
('66', 108, 1, 4, 199228) I do not know if an agency will be formally established in Delhi before I leave.
('66', 108, 1, 5, 199309) But I am collecting all the information that is available.
('66', 108, 1, 6, 199368) The final appointment will be made by the Central Board.
('66', 108, 1, 7, 199425) The headquarters are in Wardha, where Seth Jamnalalji has given a valuable garden with a large bungalow in it, and he has promised more land, if it is required for subsequent arrange ments.
('66', 108, 2, 8, 199615) Q. Is the Association likely to depend on its unaided strength for all information, statistical or otherwise, in respect of the dead or dying industries you seek to revive, or will it invite the co operation of all official and non official agencies operating in India at Present?
('66', 108, 3, 9, 199896) G. The Association will do nothing unaided, so vast is the work to be done.
('66', 108, 3, 10, 199972) Therefore it will invite and receive co operation of all agencies, not excluding the official agencies.
('66', 108, 4, 11, 200076) Q. Will the Association seek to revive only those industries whose revival is not reasonably calculated to come in conflict with the various world economic and commercial forces now acting and reacting on India; or will the Association try to revive the dead industries irrespective of such considerations and merely because in their ancient flourishing condition they used to give food to millions of villages?
('66', 108, 5, 12, 200488) G. The Association will certainly seek to revive and encourage as many industries as are necessary for the moral and material growth of village life.
('66', 108, 5, 13, 200638) It will not be deterred by the so called conflicting world forces.
('66', 108, 6, 14, 200705) Q. It is generally agreed that the cotton mills of India have not taken very kindly to the khadi industry.
('66', 108, 6, 15, 200812) If the Association attempts to resuscitate those dead, dying or unorganized industries which are likely to clash with the interests of more organized, indigenous industries, is it not your apprehension that the Association will meet with opposition?
('66', 108, 7, 16, 201062) G. It is likely that the Association will meet with opposition from mechanized industries, such as sugar mills, rice mills and flour mills.
('66', 108, 7, 17, 201202) It is for us to find a way out of the difficulty.
('66', 108, 7, 18, 201252) I have every hope that we shall be able to overcome these difficulties.
('66', 108, 8, 19, 201324) Q. Take, for instance, the question of sugar versus gur.
('66', 108, 8, 20, 201381) Sugar is a protected industry and is now fairly well organized.
('66', 108, 8, 21, 201445) It was stated in the Press some time ago that the Association will try to increase the consumption of gur.
('66', 108, 8, 22, 201552) If it is true, do you not think that by doing so it will evoke the opposition of the sugar industry?
('66', 108, 9, 23, 201653) G. That may be so.
('66', 108, 9, 24, 201672) If the consumption of gur increases and the consumption of sugar decreases, it would be a blessing for India, because medical testimony goes to show that gur is superior to sugar
('66', 109, 0, 1, 201851) 110 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('66', 109, 1, 2, 201893) in nutritive value; and it is the business of the Association, as also of the public, to see to it that no mechanized industry is allowed to interfere with the health of the people.
('66', 109, 2, 3, 202075) Q. May I have your views on whether or not the Association should supplement the existing large scale industries, without antagonizing them?
('66', 109, 3, 4, 202216) G. The answer to it has already been given.
('66', 109, 4, 5, 202260) Q. Am I wrong in suggesting that, from the resuscitation of dead village industries, such as you contemplate, to the industrialization of India on human, rational and intelligent lines (as opposed to greedy capitalism), it is but a step?
('66', 109, 5, 6, 202498) G. I do not know if a vast country like India, with her millions of people having four months of enforced idleness on their hand, can afford to have large scale industries and yet live a life of tolerable comfort.
('66', 109, 5, 7, 202712) Large scale, centralized industries in India, except such industries as cannot be possibly carried on in villages, must mean starvation of millions, unless honourable employment is found for the displaced millions.
('66', 109, 6, 8, 202927) Q. If what the Press says about the Government circulars 1 forestalling the activities of the Village Industries Association is true, do you think there is any chance of the Association coming in conflict with the Government?
('66', 109, 7, 9, 203153) G. There is no possibility of the Association coming in conflict with Government, because the ideal that the Association has set before it appears to me to be different from that of the Government effort if I have understood it rightly, except, perhaps, in the matter of sanitation.
('66', 109, 7, 10, 203436) We should certainly not take up the work of sanitation in villages where the Government agencies might be doing it.
('66', 109, 7, 11, 203552) There is no idea whatsoever to supplant the Government agency.
('66', 109, 7, 12, 203615) It may be to supplement the work.
('66', 109, 8, 13, 203649) Q. I suppose you have read the Government circular.
('66', 109, 9, 14, 203701) G. Yes.
('66', 109, 10, 15, 203709) Q. You must have noticed that the Government suspect that through this Association you will have greater opportunities of coming in closer contact with the villages, which you will utilize to prepare for organizing civil disobedience on a far more gigantic scale.
('66', 109, 11, 16, 203973) G. It never crossed my mind; I have never worked it in that indirect fashion.
('66', 109, 11, 17, 204051) It would defeat the very end that I have in view.
('66', 109, 11, 18, 204101) I want the material and moral growth of the villages for itself, and if it is achieved, it would be a full satisfaction of my ambition.
('66', 109, 12, 19, 204237) 1 Vide “Interview to the Press”, 10 1 1935
('66', 110, 0, 1, 204280) VOL.66:16 DECEMBER, 1934 24 APRIL, 1935 111
('66', 110, 1, 2, 204324) Similarly, if ever I should have to organize civil disobedience, it would be organized independently of any other activity.
('66', 110, 1, 3, 204448) If full effect is given to the word “civil”, all this suspicion should be dispelled.
('66', 110, 1, 4, 204533) But I have patience enough, and I am convinced that, if what I have said is true, all the suspicion will be dispelled without any further effort on my part.
('66', 110, 2, 5, 204690) Q. I. would ask another question.
('66', 110, 2, 6, 204724) You said that you could show a miracle if Government understood the spirit of your village industries scheme and lent its help to you.
('66', 110, 2, 7, 204859) What do you mean by help?
('66', 110, 2, 8, 204885) Is it financial assistance?
('66', 110, 3, 9, 204913) G. I simply say that, if Government understand the secret of my methods and give me complete co operation in the work I am doing, I undertake to show miracles.
('66', 110, 3, 10, 205073) I do not want financial co operation.
('66', 110, 3, 11, 205111) I want moral, enthusiastic endorsement from Government.
('66', 110, 4, 12, 205167) The Hindustan Time s, 22 1 1935, and Harijan, 8 2 1935

('66', 111, 1, 2, 206199) 143. QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS 1
('66', 111, 2, 3, 206228) [About January 23, 1935] 2
('66', 111, 3, 4, 206255) I have been asked by Sir S. Radhakrishnan to answer the following three questions: (1) What is your religion?
('66', 111, 3, 5, 206365) (2) How are you led to it?
('66', 111, 3, 6, 206392) (3) What is its bearing on social life?
('66', 111, 3, 7, 206432) My religion is Hinduism which, for me, is religion of humanity and includes the best of all the religions known to me.
('66', 111, 3, 8, 206551) I take it that the present tense in the second question has been purposely used instead of the past.
('66', 111, 3, 9, 206652) I am being led to my religion through Truth and Non violence, i.e., love in the broadest sense.
('66', 111, 3, 10, 206748) I often describe my religion as religion of Truth.
('66', 111, 3, 11, 206799) Of late, instead of saying God is Truth I have been saying Truth is God, in order more fully to define my religion.
('66', 111, 3, 12, 206915) I used at one time to know by heart the thousand names of God which a booklet in Hinduism gives in verse form and which perhaps tens of thousands recite every morning.
('66', 111, 3, 13, 207083) But nowadays nothing so completely describes my God as Truth.
('66', 111, 3, 14, 207145) Denial of God we have known.
('66', 111, 3, 15, 207174) Denial of Truth we have not known 3. The most ignorant among mankind have some truth in them.
('66', 111, 3, 16, 207268) We are all sparks of Truth.
('66', 111, 3, 17, 207296) The sum total of these sparks is indescribable, as yet Unknown Truth, which is God.
('66', 111, 3, 18, 207380) I am being daily led nearer to it by constant prayer.
('66', 111, 3, 19, 207434) The bearing of this religion on social life is, or has to be, seen in one’s daily social contact.
('66', 111, 3, 20, 207532) To be true to such religion one has to lose oneself in continuous and continuing service of all life.
('66', 111, 3, 21, 207634) Realization of Truth is impossible without a complete merging of oneself in and identification with this limitless ocean of life.
('66', 111, 3, 22, 207764) Hence, for me, there is no escape from social service; there is no happiness on earth beyond or apart from it.
('66', 111, 3, 23, 207875) Social service here must be taken to include every department of life.
('66', 111, 3, 24, 207946) In this scheme there is nothing low, nothing high.
('66', 111, 3, 25, 207997) For all is 4 one, though we seem 5 to be many.
('66', 111, 4, 26, 208044) Contemporary Indian Philosophy, p.
('66', 111, 5, 27, 208079) 1 The questions and answers have also been reproduced in F. Mary Barr’s Bapu, International Book House, Bombay, 1949, with slight variations.
('66', 111, 5, 28, 208221) 2 According to Mary Barr Radhakrishnan’s questions came at the time when Gandhiji was about to set out on a village tour from Delhi where he was camping.
('66', 111, 5, 29, 208375) This Gandhiji did on January 23, 1935. 3 Mary Barr’s version does not include this sentence and the one preceding.
('66', 111, 5, 30, 208490) 4 “Are” in Mary Barr’s version 5 Mary Barr has “may seem”.

('66', 113, 3, 4, 210555) BHAI MAMA,
('66', 113, 4, 5, 210566) Shouldn’t we say that you are but a luckless fellow?
('66', 113, 4, 6, 210619) I had your letters all right and I had also replied to them.
('66', 113, 4, 7, 210680) The answer to your first is Congress; the second I had asked Mahadev to answer.
('66', 113, 4, 8, 210760) As I am short of time and so that you may have it promptly here is my answer to your third.
('66', 113, 4, 9, 210852) Your treatment should consist of water cure, hip bath, sitz bath; but in your diet you should have milk, uncooked vegetables and wheat.

('66', 113, 5, 19, 211382) DESHPANDESAHEB AT THE BARRISTER’S, SHANKAR TEKDI, BARODA
('66', 113, 6, 20, 211439) From a photostat of the Gujarati: G.N. 3828
('66', 113, 7, 21, 211483) 146. HOW TO BEGIN?
('66', 113, 8, 22, 211502) Correspondents have been writing, and friends have been seeing me, to ask me how to begin the village industries work and what to do first.
('66', 113, 8, 23, 211642) The obvious answer is, “Begin with yourself and do first that which is easiest for you to do.” This answer, however, does not satisfy the enquirers.
('66', 113, 8, 24, 211791) Let me, therefore, be more explicit.
('66', 113, 8, 25, 211828) Each person can examine all the articles of food, clothing and other things that he uses from day to day and replace foreign makes or city makes by those produced by the villagers in their homes or
('66', 113, 9, 26, 212026) 1 The source is illegible here, but presumably it was “Kaka.”; vide “Letter to Narahari D. Parikh”,26 1 1935
('66', 114, 0, 1, 212135) VOL.66:16 DECEMBER, 1934 24 APRIL, 1935 115
('66', 114, 1, 2, 212179) fields with the simple inexpensive tools they can easily handle and mend.
('66', 114, 1, 3, 212253) This replacement will be itself an education of great value and a solid beginning.
('66', 114, 1, 4, 212336) The next step will be opened out to him of itself.
('66', 114, 1, 5, 212387) For instance, say, the beginner has been hitherto using a tooth brush made in a Bombay factory.
('66', 114, 1, 6, 212483) He wants to replace it with a village brush.
('66', 114, 1, 7, 212528) He is advised to use a babul twig.
('66', 114, 1, 8, 212563) If he has weak teeth or is toothless, he has to crush one end of it, with a rounded stone or a hammer, on a hard surface.
('66', 114, 1, 9, 212685) The other end he slits with a knife and uses the halves as tongue scrapers.
('66', 114, 1, 10, 212761) He will find these brushes to be cheaper and much cleaner than the very unhygienic factory made tooth brush.
('66', 114, 1, 11, 212870) The city made tooth powder he naturally replaces with equal parts of clean, finely ground wood charcoal and clean salt.
('66', 114, 1, 12, 212990) He will replace mill cloth with village spun khadi, and mill husked rice with hand husked, unpolished rice, and white sugar with village made gur.
('66', 114, 1, 13, 213137) These I have taken merely as samples already mentioned in these columns.
('66', 114, 1, 14, 213210) I have mentioned them again to deal with the difficulties that have been mentioned by those who have been discussing the question with me.
('66', 114, 1, 15, 213349) Some say, with reference to rice for instance, ‘Hand husked rice is much dearer than mill husked rice.’ Others say, ‘The art of hand husking is forgotten, and there are no huskers to be found.’ Yet others say, ‘We never get mill husked rice in our parts.
('66', 114, 1, 16, 213604) We can supply hand husked rice at 19 seers to the rupee.’ All these are right and all are wrong.
('66', 114, 1, 17, 213701) They are right so far as their own experience in their own district is concerned.
('66', 114, 1, 18, 213783) All are wrong because the real truth is unknown to them.
('66', 114, 1, 19, 213840) I am daily gathering startling experiences.
('66', 114, 1, 20, 213884) All this comes from beginning with oneself.
('66', 114, 1, 21, 213928) The following is the result of my observations to date.
('66', 114, 1, 22, 213984) Whole unpolished rice is unprocurable in the bazaars.
('66', 114, 1, 23, 214038) It is beautiful to look at and rich and sweet to the taste.
('66', 114, 1, 24, 214098) Mills can never compete with this unpolished rice.
('66', 114, 1, 25, 214149) It is husked in a simple manner.
('66', 114, 1, 26, 214182) Most of the paddy can be husked in a light chakki without difficulty.
('66', 114, 1, 27, 214252) There are some varieties the husk of which is not separated by grinding.
('66', 114, 1, 28, 214325) The best way of treating such paddy is to boil it first and then separate the chaff from the grain.
('66', 114, 1, 29, 214425) This rice, it is said, is most nutritious and, naturally, the cheapest.
('66', 114, 1, 30, 214497) In the villages, if they husk their own paddy, it must always be cheaper for the peasants than the corresponding mill husked rice, whether polished or unpolished.
('66', 114, 1, 31, 214660) The majority of rice found ordinarily in the bazaars is always more or lesspolished, whether hand husked or mill husked.
('66', 114, 1, 32, 214781) Wholly unpolished rice is always hand husked and is every time cheaper than the
('66', 115, 0, 1, 214861) 116 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('66', 115, 1, 2, 214903) mill husked rice, the variety being the same.
('66', 115, 1, 3, 214949) Subject to further research, the observations so far show that it is because of our criminal negligence that rice eating millions eat deteriorated rice and pay a heavy price into the bargain.
('66', 115, 1, 4, 215141) Let the village worker test the truth of these observations for himself.
('66', 115, 1, 5, 215214) It won’t be a bad beginning.
('66', 115, 1, 6, 215243) Next week I must take up gur and other articles of diet and another part of village work.
('66', 115, 2, 7, 215333) Harijan, 25 1 1935
('66', 115, 3, 8, 215352) 147. HIS ECONOMIC FAITH
('66', 115, 4, 9, 215376) Professor Sam Higginbottom, Director of the Agricultural Institute, Allahabad, and a member of the Board of Advisers of the All India Village Industries Association, writes in the course of a letter: 1
('66', 115, 5, 10, 215578) I enunciate my economic faith which is at the base of all my economic and spiritual efforts for India.
('66', 115, 6, 11, 215681) The two primary factors of production are land and labour.
('66', 115, 6, 12, 215740) These are united or married, and the offspring is all material things needful and desirable for man’s physical well being.
('66', 115, 6, 13, 215863) We call it ‘capital’.
('66', 115, 7, 14, 215885) Capital is the offspring of the union of land and labour.
('66', 115, 7, 15, 215943) India has land and labour in great abundance.
('66', 115, 7, 16, 215989) Both need wise use and guidance to be most beneficial to India.
('66', 115, 7, 17, 216053) This they have lacked very largely up to the present.
('66', 115, 7, 18, 216107) Hence I stress the training of village workers who will not waste all their time complaining of what they do not have, and, therefore, get discouraged and beaten at the start; but workers who will take the village as it is, with all its resources or lack of them, and, by making better use of the existing resources and the potential resources that are within the present financial grasp of the villager, create, with the land and their labour, the capital within the village suited to the village needs.
('66', 115, 7, 19, 216612) This is a long, slow, educative process that means hard work, but certain success.
('66', 115, 8, 20, 216695) The details of the programme will include proper use of all village wastes for soil enrichment; the prevention of erosion; the right system of rotation of crops; the selection of better seed, methods and implements; cattle improvement through selective breeding and proper feeding; co operation for purchasing and marketing of village products, for road improvement;
('66', 115, 9, 21, 217062) 1 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('66', 116, 0, 1, 217099) VOL.66:16 DECEMBER, 1934 24 APRIL, 1935 117
('66', 116, 1, 2, 217143) development of existing village industries that process village products and, wherever necessary, the introduction of new village industries to round out the village life.
('66', 116, 1, 3, 217315) There is a great deal in this with which every lover of the movement for the restoration of village life to its proper status must heartily agree.
('66', 116, 2, 4, 217462) Harijan, 25 1 1935
('66', 116, 3, 5, 217481) 148. NOTES
('66', 116, 4, 6, 217492) ANOTHER HARIJAN SEVAK GONE
('66', 116, 5, 7, 217519) Acharya Gidwani was a staunch Harijan sevak.
('66', 116, 5, 8, 217564) He was deeply interested in Harijan work.
('66', 116, 5, 9, 217606) He was bringing up a Harijan girl as a member of his own family.
('66', 116, 5, 10, 217671) With him there was none low none high.
('66', 116, 5, 11, 217710) Love of Harijan service was an integral part of his nature.
('66', 116, 5, 12, 217770) I had known him fight for Harijans when he first came to me.
('66', 116, 5, 13, 217831) He never hesitated whenever the call to service came.
('66', 116, 5, 14, 217885) Such servants of humanity never die.
('66', 116, 5, 15, 217922) They live through their service.
('66', 116, 5, 16, 217955) The deceased leaves a brave widow and a large family.
('66', 116, 5, 17, 218009) I tender them my respectful sympathy.
('66', 116, 6, 18, 218047) CREDIT v.
('66', 116, 6, 19, 218057) CASH The question repeatedly arises in the management of the numerous khadi bhandars of the All India Spinners’ Association whether khadi should be sold on credit.
('66', 116, 6, 20, 218221) For years past I have held the opinion that it is a wrong principle to have credit sales in businesses conducted on purely philanthropic lines.
('66', 116, 6, 21, 218365) Such philanthropic manage ment should be able to teach the public that credit sales mean an advance upon the prices that would be asked for cash sales.
('66', 116, 6, 22, 218517) Only such sales can become an index of public patronage of a business run on philanthropic lines.
('66', 116, 6, 23, 218615) I have found in the end that, whilst there may be some heart burning in the beginning, there is a decided advantage.
('66', 116, 6, 24, 218732) Philanthropy has to be detached from immediate results.
('66', 116, 6, 25, 218788) It has got to work on simple, unchallengeable faith.
('66', 116, 6, 26, 218841) I would, therefore, strongly advise all managers of stalls under the All India Spinners’ Association and allied organizations, and the All India Village Industries Association, which will be presently at work, to adhere to the principle of cash sales, and elimination of credit altogether.
('66', 116, 7, 27, 219131) Harijan, 25 1 1935

('66', 121, 6, 16, 226424) 158. SPEECH AT M.L.A.S’ MEETING, DELHI 1
('66', 121, 7, 17, 226465) January 27, 1935
('66', 121, 8, 18, 226482) Facing the mild afternoon sun, Mahatma Gandhi referred to the twin legislations sought to be promoted in the last Assembly, and said: As regards the Temple entry Bill, this need not be pursued at the present moment, because obviously public opinion must be sufficiently cultivated in its favour.
('66', 121, 8, 19, 226778) The Harijan workers are doing this, the mass mind of the Hindu is passively in favour of it.
('66', 121, 8, 20, 226871) Yet the intelligentsia among sanatanists, especially the pundits are still against it.
('66', 121, 9, 21, 226958) In a matter of this kind, they could not force the pace by a majority of votes alone.
('66', 121, 9, 22, 227044) Those interested in the subject might meanwhile make a special study of the subject.
('66', 121, 9, 23, 227129) As for the Removal of Untouchability Bill, Mahatma Gandhi advised, this could be pursued to the end.
('66', 121, 9, 24, 227230) It concerned the civic rights of the Harijans and so could
('66', 121, 10, 25, 227289) 1 Held in the Harijan Colony, Kingsway Camp.
('66', 121, 10, 26, 227334) Thirty five M. L. A.s attended the meeting at the invitation of G. D. Birla.
('66', 122, 0, 1, 227411) VOL.66:16 DECEMBER, 1934 24 APRIL, 1935 123
('66', 122, 1, 2, 227455) be taken by all legislators, whether Hindus, Mussalmans or others.
('66', 122, 1, 3, 227522) Even if the whole body of Hindu opinion were to be against the removal of untouchability, still he would advise a secular legislature like the Assembly not to tolerate that attitude, for in this matter there was no interference with religious rights or religious observance, but simply the removal of untouchability from the statute law of this country.
('66', 122, 1, 4, 227876) Take for instance the use of public wells which was the sorest point with the Harijans.
('66', 122, 1, 5, 227964) Cattle could approach these wells and tanks, but not the Harijans.
('66', 122, 1, 6, 228031) It bordered on inhumanity when it was known that in Rajputana thousands of rupees had to be spent for boring wells, and yet there the Harijans were not allowed to use them.
('66', 122, 1, 7, 228204) Similarly about schools.
('66', 122, 1, 8, 228229) He could quote chapter and verse on this matter.
('66', 122, 1, 9, 228278) There was the Bill promoted by Mr. M. R Jayakar 1 and another Bill recently drafted by Mr. C. Rajagopalachari.
('66', 122, 1, 10, 228389) Such a Bill could be further elucidated and amended, if necessary, but it should be pursued as quickly as possible.
('66', 122, 1, 11, 228505) It was the bounden duty of the Hindus after the resolution passed 2 by the Conference in Bombay under the chairmanship of Malaviyaji, to support a Bill of this kind and for the Hindu members of the Assembly to actively pursue it.
('66', 122, 2, 12, 228735) The services of Harijan Sevak Sangh would be available to the members in this matter.
('66', 122, 3, 13, 228821) There were other directions in which the Assembly could help in the Harijan welfare.
('66', 122, 3, 14, 228906) No doubt provincial Governments were wide awake and trying to do several things for the Harijans.
('66', 122, 3, 15, 229004) The activities of the Harijan Sabha perhaps stimulated their efforts.
('66', 122, 3, 16, 229074) All that was for the good of the Harijans.
('66', 122, 3, 17, 229117) The Harijans should take aid from whatever quarter it came, provided it in no way compromised their essential interests.
('66', 122, 3, 18, 229238) But the Government could give only according to regulations and no more.
('66', 122, 3, 19, 229311) The Harijan Sevak Sangh however was not bound by such restrictions.
('66', 122, 3, 20, 229379) The Assembly was a fit enough body for exercising legitimate pressure upon the Government to see that funds were allotted for the purpose of the Harijan uplift.
('66', 122, 3, 21, 229540) This could be done perhaps by moving a resolution.
('66', 122, 3, 22, 229591) They could also consult Mr. M. C. Rajah and give him any help he might require.
('66', 122, 3, 23, 229671) Lastly, Mahatma Gandhi referred to the cruel treatment of the Harijans in certain parts of India recently.
('66', 122, 3, 24, 229778) He instanced a case of recent assault by zamindars in Meerut on the Harijans over the begar (forced labour) question in which one Harijan was reported to have died.
('66', 122, 3, 25, 229943) There was yet another report of tragedy from Cawnpore the full facts of which are not known yet.
('66', 122, 3, 26, 230040) Then there was the ancient quarrel in Chettinad between the Nattars and the Harijans, the latter of whom were not allowed to wear the cloth they liked.
('66', 122, 3, 27, 230192) Some of the Nattars were very unreasonable and tried to defend their attitude on the ground of custom.
('66', 122, 3, 28, 230295) On these and other instances of cruel treatment, the Assembly members might put questions and try to do something.
('66', 122, 4, 29, 230410) The Hindustan Times, 28 1 1935
('66', 122, 5, 30, 230441) 1 Published in Harijan, 18 2 1933; vide also “Sjt.
('66', 122, 5, 31, 230492) Jayakar on Untouchability” 2 On September 25, 1932, vide “Resolution at the Hindu Leaders’ Conference, Bombay”, 25 9 1932 3 A brief discussion followed in which Asaf Ali, C. Rajagopalachari, S. Satyamurti, K. Nageswara Rao and others took part.

('66', 123, 1, 2, 230779) 159. ADVICE TO STUDENTS 1
('66', 123, 2, 3, 230805) DELHI, [Before January 28, 1935]
('66', 123, 3, 4, 230838) We propose doing medical work there.
('66', 123, 3, 5, 230875) How shall we go about our business, Mahatmaji?
('66', 123, 3, 6, 230922) Could you give us some hints?
('66', 123, 4, 7, 230952) GANDHIJI: I have experience of this work since my early days in South Africa.
('66', 123, 4, 8, 231030) Let me then begin with a warning.
('66', 123, 4, 9, 231064) By taking a littlemedical aid to them, you do not really help them.
('66', 123, 4, 10, 231132) You must teach them sanitation and hygiene, which alone can prevent malaria.
('66', 123, 4, 11, 231209) Quinine does seem to subdue malaria, but will not root it out.
('66', 123, 4, 12, 231272) What is essential is the preventive treatment and the after care of patients.
('66', 123, 4, 13, 231350) They do not know that careless diet often prepares the breeding ground for malaria germs.
('66', 123, 4, 14, 231440) They eat anything and everything.
('66', 123, 4, 15, 231474) But a malaria patient must eschew starch, too much protein, and live mainly on milk during convalescence.
('66', 123, 4, 16, 231580) That is what you have to tell them.
('66', 123, 4, 17, 231616) Teach them how to prevent disease.
('66', 123, 4, 18, 231651) I will not congratulate you if you tell me that you have distributed a thousand quinine pills.
('66', 123, 4, 19, 231746) Give them practical lessons in sanitation if you can.
('66', 123, 4, 20, 231800) Go there with spades and shovels, fill up stagnant pools, see to the drainage, see that their wells are properly dredged and that their tank is not contaminated.
('66', 123, 4, 21, 231962) The late Principal Rudra, under whose hospitable roof I have had the privilege of living, used to tell me how Delhi had fought a successful battle against the swamps and mosquito breeding pools around Delhi.
('66', 123, 4, 22, 232170) We have now to teach the people to do what the municipality or the local boards may not do, for want of funds or any other reason.
('66', 123, 4, 23, 232301) Above all, teach them to rid their village of filth and dirt.
('66', 123, 4, 24, 232363) It is the most difficult part of your work, unless you would be willing scavengers.
('66', 123, 4, 25, 232447) For days you must sweep the streets and teach them to preserve health and conserve their golden manure at one and the same time.
('66', 123, 4, 26, 232576) Poore’s Rural Hygiene used to be a precious little book on this subject.
('66', 123, 4, 27, 232649) You have to teach them to bury their night soil in nine inch deep pits and cover it up with earth, the principle being that such earth is full of life and that the sun’s rays penetrate that depth.
('66', 123, 4, 28, 232846) In a little

('66', 130, 1, 2, 244388) 168. LETTER TO HARIBHAU PHATAK
('66', 130, 2, 3, 244419) WARDHA, January 29, 1935
('66', 130, 3, 4, 244444) MY DEAR HARIBHAU,
('66', 130, 4, 5, 244462) I have your postcard.
('66', 130, 4, 6, 244484) Evidently you have not been reading Harijan.
('66', 130, 4, 7, 244529) I have reproduced the testimony of Dr. Ansari and other doctors in its pages.
('66', 130, 4, 8, 244607) 1 Medical testimony in favour of unpolished rice is universal.
('66', 130, 4, 9, 244670) It is being eaten even now in Sambalpur and many parts of Bengal.
('66', 130, 4, 10, 244736) Proof of the pudding is in the eating.
('66', 130, 4, 11, 244775) You should try the thing yourself.
('66', 130, 4, 12, 244810) You are quite right in saying that unpolished rice is harder to cook.
('66', 130, 4, 13, 244880) But it is not harder to digest if it is well cooked.
('66', 130, 4, 14, 244933) It must take longer to cook for the simple reason that unpolished rice contains organic salts and protein.
('66', 130, 4, 15, 245040) Polished rice is practically starch.
('66', 130, 4, 16, 245077) Starch always takes less time to cook.
('66', 130, 4, 17, 245116) Unpolished rice is like unskinned pulses or vegetables.
('66', 130, 4, 18, 245172) If you skin your dal and your vegetables they are easily cooked, but they are also less nutritious.
('66', 130, 4, 19, 245272) A nutritious article takes a longer time to digest, as it must, but it is not on that account considered to be indigestible.
('66', 130, 4, 20, 245397) If you say that you cannot eat the same quantity of unpolished rice as that of polished, you will be quite right.
('66', 130, 4, 21, 245511) Our object, however, is not to fill the belly with as much as can be put into it, but to take a proper proportion of balanced foods.
('66', 130, 4, 22, 245644) The habit of eating polished rice is waste of national health and wealth.
('66', 130, 4, 23, 245718) You will remember you sent me medical opinion which you thought was in favour of cow’s milk in preference to buffalo’s milk.
('66', 130, 4, 24, 245843) I think I showed to you that the authority you sent was not conclusive.
('66', 130, 4, 25, 245915) The authority in question merely showed that cow’s milk was better for infants than buffalo’s milk.
('66', 130, 4, 26, 246015) I want decisive opinion in favour of cow’s milk to buffalo’s milk even for adults if that opinion can be honestly sustained.
('66', 130, 5, 27, 246140) Yours, BAPU
('66', 130, 6, 28, 246152) From a photostat: G.N. 1373
('66', 130, 7, 29, 246180) 1 Vide “Villagers’ Hands”

('66', 131, 2, 3, 246278) January 29, 1935
('66', 131, 3, 4, 246295) TO MY AMERICAN FRIENDS:
('66', 131, 4, 5, 246319) Kodanda Rao has been in America for some time.
('66', 131, 4, 6, 246366) He is a member of the Servants of India Society founded by the late G. K. Gokhale whom I have regarded and often described as my political guru.
('66', 131, 4, 7, 246511) Kodanda Rao was private secretary to the Right Hon.
('66', 131, 4, 8, 246563) Srinivasa Sastri when he was appointed the Agent General of Govern ment of India in South Africa.
('66', 131, 4, 9, 246661) He was editor of the Servant of India when he left for America.
('66', 131, 4, 10, 246725) He is a moderate in politics and an ardent social reformer holding advanced views on many social problems.
('66', 131, 4, 11, 246832) He rendered me great assistance whilst I was permitted to carry on the anti untouchability movement from the Yeravda Prison.
('66', 131, 4, 12, 246957) I have no doubt that he will receive a patient and courteous hearing wherever he goes.
('66', 131, 4, 13, 247044) Any assistance rendered to him will be deeply appreciated by me.
('66', 131, 5, 14, 247109) M. K. GANDHI

('66', 131, 8, 17, 247184) January 29, 1935
('66', 131, 9, 18, 247201) MY DEAR SITARAMA SASTRY,
('66', 131, 10, 19, 247226) I had your three letters, two of which do not call for any answer.
('66', 131, 10, 20, 247293) Have you sent Kumarappa your form duly filled in?
('66', 131, 10, 21, 247343) If the experiment that is being made in the use of groundnut oil for lighting purposes is successful, it will have far reaching consequences.

('66', 140, 8, 18, 261370) 187. LETTER TO ACHYUT PATWARDHAN
('66', 140, 9, 19, 261403) January 30, 1935
('66', 140, 10, 20, 261420) MY DEAR PATWARDHAN, You have done well in bringing the weavers’ case to my notice.
('66', 140, 10, 21, 261503) I had a similar case in Orissa during the walking tour.
('66', 140, 10, 22, 261559) It was a question affecting 10,000 weavers.
('66', 140, 10, 23, 261603) I have resolutely set my face against doing anything for weavers who weave mills spun yarn, for they cut their own throat by weaving mill spun yarn, and they know it.
('66', 140, 10, 24, 261770) But they wrongly plead helplessness.
('66', 140, 10, 25, 261807) As I told the weavers of Orissa, in a weaving family where there is one weaver, the rest of the members help in attending to the different processes through which yarn has to pass before it comes to the loom.
('66', 140, 10, 26, 262016) My suggestion then is that every weaver family should spin its own yarn, that is to say, it should do the ginning, carding and spinning.
('66', 140, 10, 27, 262153) Such a family should use for itself the khadi woven by it and put the surplus on the market.
('66', 140, 10, 28, 262246) This will ensure spinning of a high order, because all the members of the family would be interested in spinning as strong and even yarn as is possible.
('66', 141, 0, 1, 262399) 142 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('66', 141, 1, 2, 262441) course, the income of the weaver would increase in exact proportion to the skill employed in producing good yarn.
('66', 141, 1, 3, 262555) Withefficient management, I can show that such a family stands to gain by taking up spinning.
('66', 141, 1, 4, 262649) The gain will be threefold.
('66', 141, 1, 5, 262677) It will be independent of the middleman who sells yarn and the fluctuations of the yarn market, and save a portion of the money spent in buying cloth required for the family, for, except when the price of cotton goes down very low, the value of cotton required for domestic use will always be less than the price of cloth purchased in the market.
('66', 141, 1, 6, 263024) Moreover, it has been found by experience that a man and woman use less yards of khadi than of mill cloth, and less still where khadi and yarn are respectively hand woven and hand spun.
('66', 141, 1, 7, 263210) And it is the universal testimony of practised spinners that when they have khadi woven out of their own yarn it lasts three times as long as manufactured cloth.
('66', 141, 1, 8, 263372) If this thing appeals to you, you can organize [the work].
('66', 141, 1, 9, 263431) A. I. S. A. can come to the assistance by purchasing the surplus khadi that these families will weave.
('66', 141, 1, 10, 263534) I am telling the weaver friend whose letter you have enclosed that you would explain my scheme to him.
('66', 141, 1, 11, 263637) If you like the scheme and any of the weavers will take it up under the conditions mentioned by me, you should, in order to save time, place yourself in touch with Gangadharrao, who, officially or unofficially, I do not remember which, represents the Karnatak branch of the A. ('66', 148, 4, 9, 274013) 203. ESCAPING THE OBVIOUS
('66', 148, 5, 10, 274039) When I was addressing a mixed conference of Harijans and non Harijans the other day, I happened to deplore the fact that at railway stations one heard the cry ‘Mussalman milk, Mussalman water’; ‘Hindu milk, Hindu water’.
('66', 148, 5, 11, 274260) ‘Hindu chapati’ and ‘Mussalman chapati’ I could bear, though I did not believe in anything like it; but Mussalman and Hindu milk, with the making of which man had nothing to do, I could neither understand nor tolerate.
('66', 148, 5, 12, 274479) I added that those who believed in the total removal of untouchability had to be free from superstitions like ‘Mussalman and Hindu milk and water’.
('66', 148, 5, 13, 274627) I have already remarked in these columns that those who refuse to take water and the like touched by Harijans may not claim that they are free from the taint of untouchability.
('66', 148, 5, 14, 274804) It would be preposterous to justify the practice of differentiating between Mussalman and Hindu water and milk, when we do away with the difference between Harijan water and milk and non Harijan water and milk.
('66', 148, 5, 15, 275015) The great movement for the removal of untouchability would lose all its charm if it became a mere salve for conscience without truth behind it.
('66', 148, 5, 16, 275159) The virus of untouchability is all pervasive, and those who believe in it cannot be said to be free till they have ceased to regard any single individual as untouchable or in any way inferior in status by reason of his birth, community or faith.
('66', 148, 5, 17, 275405) A letter has just come to emphasize the necessity of a proper understanding of the implications of the movement.
('66', 148, 5, 18, 275518) It describes how there was a public dinner arranged over the celebration of the silver jubilee of a high school in Berar.
('66', 148, 5, 19, 275640) Harijan students were invited to it.
('66', 148, 5, 20, 275677) The letter informs me that the Harijan students were provided with separate seats, the guests drawn from all the other castes and communities sitting in one row.
('66', 148, 5, 21, 275839) Here was a wanton insult needlessly offered to the cultured Harijan students, who could not be recognized
('66', 149, 0, 1, 275945) 150 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('66', 149, 1, 2, 275987) as such from their appearance.
('66', 149, 1, 3, 276018) Such insults at this time of the day at a high school function show that, though much headway has been made in the campaign against untouchability, the superstition persists even in the least expected quarters and in the least expected manner.
('66', 149, 1, 4, 276262) It should be borne in mind that here there was no question of inter dining, there was noquestion of mixed cooking, it was a question merely of sitting in the same row.
('66', 149, 1, 5, 276430) If sitting on the same bench in the same compartment in a railway train and eating one’s food in that condition is not inter dining, surely this was not.
('66', 149, 1, 6, 276584) But in the dictionary of untouchability, inter dining has a specific meaning which excludes sitting at meal time in the same row with people.
('66', 149, 2, 7, 276726) Harijan, 1 2 1935
('66', 149, 3, 8, 276744) 204. BEE KEEPING 1
('66', 149, 4, 9, 276763) In answer to an inquiry, Shri J. N. Jayakaran of Y. M. C. A. Rural Reconstruction Centre, Ramnathpuram, Coimbatore, gives the following interesting information:
('66', 149, 5, 10, 276924) Krishnaswami Naidu, a small holder, knows, and demonstrates to his neighbours, that the total outturn from a coriander crop is represented not merely by the usual quantity of coriander which it can produce without the help of bees, but also by the increase in the quantity of production caused by better pollination by these busy insects plus 42 pounds of A 1 golden honey, this latter alone bringing to his pocket a decent sum of Rs. 63. He has but 10 hives of bees, which he has caught from nature and hived in cheap dealwood boxes.
('66', 149, 5, 11, 277459) Bee keeping seems to me to possess immense possibilities.
('66', 149, 5, 12, 277517) Apart from its village value, it may be cultivated as a hobby by moneyed young men and women.
('66', 149, 5, 13, 277611) They will add to the wealth of the country and produce the finest health giving sugar for themselves.
('66', 149, 5, 14, 277713) If they are philanthropically inclined, they can distribute it as health giving food among sickly Harijan children.
('66', 149, 5, 15, 277829) There is no reason why it should be a luxury of the rich or an expensive medicinal vehicle in the hands of the hakims and vaidyas.
('66', 149, 5, 16, 277960) No doubt, my hope is based on inferences drawn from meagre data.
('66', 149, 5, 17, 278025) Experiments that may be made in villages and in cities by young men and women should show whether honey can become a common article of food or has to remain an uncommon article, which it is today
('66', 149, 6, 18, 278221) Harijan, 1 2 1935
('66', 149, 7, 19, 278239) 1 This appeared under “Notes”.
('66', 150, 0, 1, 278270) VOL.66:16 DECEMBER, 1934 24 APRIL, 1935 151
('66', 150, 1, 2, 278314) 205. HOW TO BEGIN? II 1
('66', 150, 2, 3, 278338) Last week I dealt with rice.
('66', 150, 2, 4, 278367) Let us now take up wheat.
('66', 150, 2, 5, 278393) It is the second most important article of diet, if not the first.
('66', 150, 2, 6, 278460) From the nutritive stand point, it is the king of cereals.
('66', 150, 2, 7, 278519) By itself it is more perfect than rice.
('66', 150, 2, 8, 278559) Flour bereft of the valuable bran is like polished rice.
('66', 150, 2, 9, 278616) That branless flour is as bad as polished rice is the universal testimony of medical men.
('66', 150, 2, 10, 278706) Whole wheat flour ground in one’s own chakki 2 is any day superior to, and cheaper than, the fine flour to be had in the bazaars.
('66', 150, 2, 11, 278836) It is cheaper because the cost of grinding is saved.
('66', 150, 2, 12, 278889) Again, in whole wheat flour there is no loss of weight.
('66', 150, 2, 13, 278945) In fine flour there is loss of weight.
('66', 150, 2, 14, 278984) The richest part of wheat is contained in its bran.
('66', 150, 2, 15, 279036) There is a terrible loss of nutrition when the bran of wheat is removed.
('66', 150, 2, 16, 279109) The villagers and others who eat whole wheat flour ground in their own chakkis save their money and, what is more important, their health.
('66', 150, 2, 17, 279248) A large part of the millions that flour mills make will remain in and circulate among the deserving poor when village grinding is revived.
('66', 150, 2, 18, 279387) But the objection is taken that chakki grinding is a tedious process, that often wheat is indifferently ground and that it does not pay the villagers to grind wheat themselves.
('66', 150, 2, 19, 279564) If it paid the villagers formerly to grind their own corn, surely the advent of flour mills should make no difference.
('66', 150, 2, 20, 279683) They may not plead want of time, and when intelligence is allied to labour, there is every hope of improvement in the chakki.
('66', 150, 2, 21, 279809) The argument of indifferent grinding can have no practical value.
('66', 150, 2, 22, 279875) If the chakki was such an indifferent grinder, it could not have stood the test of time immemorial.
('66', 150, 2, 23, 279975) But to obviate the risk of using indifferently ground whole wheat flour, I suggest that, wherever there is suspicion, the flour of uneven grinding may be passed through a sieve and the contents may be turned into thick porridge and eaten with or after chapati.
('66', 150, 2, 24, 280236) If this plan is followed, grinding becomes incredibly simple, and much time and labour can be saved.
('66', 150, 3, 25, 280337) All this change can only be brought about by some previous
('66', 150, 4, 26, 280396) 1 For the first instalment, vide “How to Begin” 2 Quern
('66', 151, 0, 1, 280452) 152 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('66', 151, 1, 2, 280494) preparation on the part of workers and instruction of villagers.
('66', 151, 1, 3, 280559) This isa thankless task.
('66', 151, 1, 4, 280584) But it is worth doing, if the villagers are to live in health and elementary comfort.
('66', 151, 1, 5, 280670) Gur 1 is the next article that demands attention.
('66', 151, 1, 6, 280720) According to the medical testimony I have reproduced in these columns 2, gur is any day superior to refined sugar in food value, and if the villagers cease to make gur as they are already beginning to do, they will be deprived of an important food adjunct for their children.
('66', 151, 1, 7, 280996) They may do without gur themselves, but their children cannot without undermining their stamina.
('66', 151, 1, 8, 281093) Gur is superior to bazaar sweets and to refined sugar.
('66', 151, 1, 9, 281148) Retention of gur and its use by the people in general means several crores of rupees retained by the villagers.
('66', 151, 1, 10, 281260) But some workers maintain that gur does not pay the cost of production.
('66', 151, 1, 11, 281332) The growers who need money against their crops cannot afford to wait till they have turned cane juice into gur and disposed of it.
('66', 151, 1, 12, 281463) Though I have testimony to the contrary, too, this argument is not without force.
('66', 151, 1, 13, 281545) I have no ready made answer for it.
('66', 151, 1, 14, 281581) There must be something radically wrong when an article of use, made in the place where also its raw material is grown, does not pay the cost of labour.
('66', 151, 1, 15, 281734) This is a subject that demands local investigation in each case.
('66', 151, 1, 16, 281799) Workers must not take the answer of villagers and despair of a remedy.
('66', 151, 1, 17, 281870) National growth, identification of cities with villages, depend upon the solution of such knotty problems as are presented by gur.
('66', 151, 1, 18, 282001) We must make up our mind that gur must not disappear from the villages, even if it means an additional price to be paid for it by city people.
('66', 151, 1, 19, 282144) Harijan, 1 2 1935

('66', 152, 6, 17, 283491) February 1, 1935
('66', 152, 7, 18, 283508) DEAR FRIEND,
('66', 152, 8, 19, 283521) I have your letter.
('66', 152, 8, 20, 283541) I do not know what I have done with the verse sent by Sastri.
('66', 152, 8, 21, 283603) Most probably they are still lying in the Harijan file.
('66', 152, 8, 22, 283659) There is a great deal of matter still lying awaiting attention.
('66', 152, 8, 23, 283723) If you have a copy, you may send it to me.
('66', 152, 8, 24, 283766) It may be that I might have examined the verse, and not finding it suitable for the columns of Harijan, might have destroyed it.
('66', 152, 8, 25, 283895) For the answer to your question I would refer you to my Introduction to Anasaktiyoga 3 published in Gujarati.
('66', 152, 8, 26, 284005) I translated the Preface into English for the benefit of the readers of Young India.
('66', 152, 8, 27, 284090) If you get hold of the old file of Young India, you will find the translation in it.
('66', 152, 8, 28, 284175) The answer briefly is this:
('66', 152, 9, 29, 284203) 1 The addressee had stayed with Gandhiji during his visit to Delhi in January.
('66', 152, 9, 30, 284282) 2 The subscription is in Hindi.
('66', 152, 9, 31, 284314) 3 Vide “Anasaktiyoga” sub title “The Message of the “Gita”
('66', 153, 0, 1, 284373) 154 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('66', 153, 1, 2, 284415) The Gita was written not to establish ahimsa, but to show a groping world a way of acting truly in every conceivable circumstance.
('66', 153, 1, 3, 284546) But nevertheless you can gather that the Gita leads you infallibly to ahimsa.
('66', 153, 1, 4, 284624) Remember that Arjuna was not striving to follow ahimsa, but he was struggling to get out of the duty in front of him because of his partiality which he had suddenly developed for his kinsmen.
('66', 153, 1, 5, 284816) The question before him was not whether to kill or not to kill, but whether to kill one’s kinsmen or not to kill them.
('66', 153, 1, 6, 284935) Then, again, nigraha 1 in the verse quoted by you means a fruitless fight against one’s fundamental nature.
('66', 153, 1, 7, 285043) Fight against one’s weakness is repeatedly enjoined in the Gita, but where a weakness becomes settled nature with a person all fighting becomes vain.
('66', 153, 1, 8, 285193) Arjuna’s nature was that of a fighter, not because he was born to fight but because his own individual nature loved fighting.
('66', 153, 1, 9, 285319) When, what may appear to us, weakness in a man becomes part of his being, it ceases to have the quality of weakness with him; and if at the behest of someone such a person begins to fight against his nature, he is bound to fail or else he would become a hypocrite.
('66', 153, 1, 10, 285584) To ask such a person to go against his nature would be to expect a leopard to change his spots.
('66', 153, 2, 11, 285680) Yours sincerely, SHRI B. MADHAVA BALIGA VANI VILAS MOHALLA VONTIKOPPAL P. O., MYSORE
('66', 153, 3, 12, 285765) From a copy: Pyarelal Papers.

('66', 159, 9, 20, 293501) BHAI JAINENDRA,
('66', 159, 10, 21, 293517) This may be the brief answer to your letter.
('66', 159, 10, 22, 293562) You yourself have given it.
('66', 159, 10, 23, 293590) For a belief in rebirth, it is necessary to believe in the existence of ‘I’.
('66', 159, 10, 24, 293667) If I do not exist and God alone exists, then who is to be reborn and how?
('66', 159, 10, 25, 293741) This realization itself is rebirth, isn’t it?
('66', 159, 10, 26, 293787) The possibility of rebirth is there only as long as the ‘I’ exists.
('66', 159, 10, 27, 293855) When you truly believe—merely saying it is not enough—that ‘God alone exists’, then there is no rebirth for you.
('66', 159, 10, 28, 293968) The man who becomes one with God is liberated.
('66', 159, 10, 29, 294015) This much your reason will certainly accept.
('66', 159, 10, 30, 294060) But it will not be realized in experience.
('66', 159, 10, 31, 294103) Realization may take even thousands of years.
('66', 159, 10, 32, 294149) Realization comes through the heart.
('66', 159, 10, 33, 294186) The head can provide only logic.
('66', 159, 10, 34, 294219) But what is the worth of logic?
('66', 159, 10, 35, 294251) Service alone can bring about realization.

('66', 160, 1, 2, 294400) 222. LETTER TO AMRIT KAUR
('66', 160, 2, 3, 294426) WARDHA, Not revised February 2, 1935
('66', 160, 3, 4, 294463) DEAR AMRIT,
('66', 160, 4, 5, 294475) Here is my message for the Harijans who are troubled about child marriages.
('66', 160, 4, 6, 294551) “In these days of self purification, Harijans ought to know that they are to avoid all the bad customs of caste Hindus.
('66', 160, 4, 7, 294671) They should therefore avoid child marriages.
('66', 160, 4, 8, 294716) But reformers may not be impatient.
('66', 160, 4, 9, 294752) Sarda Act is, in my opinion, a wise step.
('66', 160, 4, 10, 294794) But it may not be strictly enforced against Harijans when it is very laxly enforced against caste Hindus.
('66', 160, 4, 11, 294900) There should be effective enlightened propaganda by Harijans among fellow Harijans on the evil of child marriages and the bearing of the Sarda Act on them.
('66', 160, 4, 12, 295056) And then when it is made certain that people wilfully ignore that Act, a few prosecutions may be undertaken.
('66', 160, 4, 13, 295165) But even then they must be the sole concern of Harijans.
('66', 160, 4, 14, 295222) They may not ask for or receive even financial assistance in this matter from caste Hindus.
('66', 160, 4, 15, 295314) In any case at least one year should be given to concentrated propaganda.” If this is not the message you want you may withhold publication and let me know what you want.
('66', 160, 5, 16, 295485) There is no cold here.
('66', 160, 5, 17, 295508) We have been having rains instead.
('66', 160, 5, 18, 295543) I hope you are better.

('66', 161, 1, 2, 295792) 223. LETTER TO DR.
('66', 161, 1, 3, 295811) B. C. ROY
('66', 161, 2, 4, 295821) February 2, 1935
('66', 161, 3, 5, 295838) DEAR DR.
('66', 161, 3, 6, 295847) BIDHAN,
('66', 161, 4, 7, 295855) Rani Vidyavati is the wife of a poor broken down zamindar in Hardoi district.
('66', 161, 4, 8, 295933) I have known her for years as a staunch Congress worker.
('66', 161, 4, 9, 295990) She has been to jail.
('66', 161, 4, 10, 296012) She is now ailing from some disease which the local doctors opine requires special treatment, probably even an operation.
('66', 161, 4, 11, 296134) They have advised her to seek the shelter of Chittaranjan Seva Sadan.
('66', 161, 4, 12, 296204) Naturally the request came to me some months ago that I should write to you and inquire whether you could accommodate her at the Seva Sadan as a poor patient.
('66', 161, 4, 13, 296363) But later, there seemed to be an improvement in her health, and therefore she postponed her going to Calcutta.
('66', 161, 4, 14, 296474) Now, evidently, she has to undergo special treatment.

('66', 169, 7, 11, 309055) I send you herewith a questionnaire 1 on milk which you will please answer at your early convenience.
('66', 169, 7, 12, 309157) I am now in a position to seek your concrete assistance for the A.I.V.I.A. The Board has been sitting for the last four days continuously and has given instructions to its members to prosecute the programme of inducing the villagers to take to hand husking of unpolished rice and pressing their own oil and cane, and grinding their own corn wherever these four primary employments have been given up, and to attend to village sanitation and hygiene.
('66', 169, 7, 13, 309607) Now, in all this work you can give the greatest assistance by securing the co operation of medical men, medical students and other students.
('66', 169, 7, 14, 309748) You can cover the whole of Bengal with an army of workers, paid or honorary; and if the workers are good, they will repay tenfold whatever they might get, in a visible and immediate improvement in the economic condition and health of the villagers.
('66', 169, 7, 15, 309997) You can even produce a village literature that may become the model for the whole of India.
('66', 169, 7, 16, 310089) I say this deliberately, because no province has so much chemical skill as Bengal; and is it not that which is principally required in the prosecution of this programme?

('66', 170, 1, 2, 310475) 236. A QUESTIONNAIRE
('66', 170, 2, 3, 310496) February 5, 1935
('66', 170, 3, 4, 310513) Ayurvedic physicians say that cow’s milk is the prince among milks from the health point of view.
('66', 170, 3, 5, 310611) They give buffalo’s milk an inferior place.
('66', 170, 3, 6, 310655) Does modern medical science sustain that view?
('66', 170, 3, 7, 310702) If so, in what way?
('66', 170, 3, 8, 310722) One hears it stated often that all fats do not act alike on the system.
('66', 170, 3, 9, 310794) Is there any distinction between butter extracted from cow’s milk and that from buffalo’s milk?
('66', 170, 3, 10, 310890) If so, what is it?
('66', 170, 3, 11, 310909) That pound per pound buffalo’s milk yields a larger quantity of fat or butter than cow’s milk is irrelevant to the inquiry.
('66', 170, 4, 12, 311033) From a copy: Pyarelal Papers.
('66', 170, 4, 13, 311063) Courtesy: Pyarelal

('66', 171, 8, 16, 312767) February 5, 1935
('66', 171, 9, 17, 312784) DEAR JADHAV,
('66', 171, 10, 18, 312797) I should never have thought that over there people are killing goats in the name of religion.
('66', 171, 10, 19, 312891) Surely it is bad to have to kill them for food; but I hold it to be a blasphemy to kill any animal in the name of religion.
('66', 171, 10, 20, 313015) It is bringing down God to our level when we think that He can possibly be pleased by our sacrificing dumb animals for our sins.
('66', 171, 10, 21, 313144) The only way of pleasing God is, in my opinion, to sacrifice ourselves.
('66', 171, 11, 22, 313216) Yours sincerely,

('66', 175, 1, 2, 316915) 248. LETTER TO M. J. KANETKAR
('66', 175, 2, 3, 316945) [After February 5, 1935] 1
('66', 175, 3, 4, 316972) MY DEAR KANETKAR,
('66', 175, 4, 5, 316990) I have just finished reading the chapter on population bogey.
('66', 175, 4, 6, 317052) I must confess that it is not at all convincing.
('66', 175, 4, 7, 317101) You have given away the whole of your case by saying that pestilence and other visitations will keep the growth under check.
('66', 175, 4, 8, 317226) Their case is that modern science reduces the death rate.
('66', 175, 4, 9, 317284) Every day produces new discoveries for conservation of life.
('66', 175, 4, 10, 317345) Therefore the increase will be unbearable.
('66', 175, 4, 11, 317388) This argument seriously brought has to be seriously answered.
('66', 175, 4, 12, 317450) You have not even studied your subject.
('66', 175, 4, 13, 317490) Able writers have combated the theory of Malthus and its later developments.
('66', 175, 4, 14, 317567) If the other chapters are as bad, I can only ask you to study your subject and rewrite the book.
('66', 175, 4, 15, 317664) I have now passed the book on to Prof.
('66', 175, 4, 16, 317703) Malkani to read and give me his opinion, He knows nothing of this.
('66', 175, 5, 17, 317770) a copy: Pyarelal Papers.

('66', 177, 7, 15, 321044) We make rice poorer in food value by getting it pounded and spending money on it.
('66', 177, 7, 16, 321126) Unpolished rice should become one mass after being cooked.

('66', 177, 7, 18, 321261) Do try snuff.

('66', 186, 1, 2, 333340) 269. LETTER TO C. VIJAYARAGHAVACHARIAR
('66', 186, 2, 3, 333379) WARDHA, February 7, 1935
('66', 186, 3, 4, 333404) DEAR FRIEND, I have your two letters.
('66', 186, 3, 5, 333442) I hope you will excuse the delay.
('66', 186, 3, 6, 333476) My time is not my own, and I never knew that there was any hurry.
('66', 186, 3, 7, 333542) I hold totally different views from yours.
('66', 186, 3, 8, 333585) We have not to deal with the family of the great Queen as individuals, but we have to deal with them as representatives of a mighty government.
('66', 186, 3, 9, 333729) We have to celebrate an event in connection not with the private vitrues of an autocrat, but we have to deal with the events of an empire for a period of twenty five years during which King George has been the nominal head but which as an individual he has perhaps no more power to influence than you or I, and infinitely less than the Collector of your district in his own district.
('66', 186, 3, 10, 334113) I, therefore, feel that the resolution of the Working Committee 1 was the only correct thing to do.
('66', 186, 3, 11, 334213) It preserves the self respect of the nation without hurting the susceptibilities of anybody.
('66', 186, 3, 12, 334306) Lastly I have to own to you that the resolution was drafted by me as I happened to be in Delhi at the time, not by design but by accident.
('66', 186, 3, 13, 334445) They would not deal with such a delicate matter without conferring with me.
('66', 186, 3, 14, 334521) Possibly, had I not been there the resolution would have been bitter and perhaps offensive.
('66', 186, 3, 15, 334613) Everybody has owned that the present resolution is purged of any offence.
('66', 186, 3, 16, 334687) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI SHRI G. VIJAYARAGHAVACHARIAR ARAMA, SALEM (S. INDIA)
('66', 186, 4, 17, 334770) From a copy: G. Vijayaraghavachariar Papers.

('66', 187, 15, 26, 336119) 273. ABYSMAL IGNORANCE
('66', 187, 16, 27, 336142) A Harijan sevak writes:
('66', 187, 17, 28, 336166) On the occasion of the Jaipur Rajya Sammelan, which was held on 25 12 34, a khadi exhibition stall was set up on the first floor of a building
('66', 187, 18, 29, 336309) 1 The note, addressed to the brother of Rajkishori, the widowed daughter in law of Chand Tyagi, was written on a letter Rajkishori wrote to her brother on February 7, 1935.
('66', 188, 0, 1, 336482) VOL.66:16 DECEMBER, 1934 24 APRIL, 1935 189
('66', 188, 1, 2, 336526) overlooking the chowk, where the Sammelan was held.
('66', 188, 1, 3, 336578) A Harijan boy was first in charge of the sales, and could be seen sitting in the gallery above by the savarna Hindus who were assembled in the chowk.
('66', 188, 1, 4, 336728) The fact that a Harijan boy was allowed to sit at a higher level than themselves was very much resented by the savarna Hindus, who resolved at a Panchayat meeting that:
('66', 188, 2, 5, 336897) (1) No one from the village should attend the khadi exhibition on pain of excommunication.
('66', 188, 3, 6, 336988) (2) No one should send his girls to the local Kanya Pathshala, as it was connected with the Rajya Sammelan people.
('66', 188, 4, 7, 337103) (3) No one should permit teachers of the Harijan Pathshala to enter his home.
('66', 188, 5, 8, 337181) In spite of this ukase of the Panchayat, as many as 28 young men took part in the Sammelan.
('66', 188, 5, 9, 337273) They were fined Re.
('66', 188, 5, 10, 337293) 1 each, which they refused to pay.
('66', 188, 5, 11, 337328) From three to four hundred persons used to dine together in the Sammelan kitchen without any distinction of caste.
('66', 188, 5, 12, 337443) This fact has been seized upon by the reactionaries, who have raised the usual cry of ‘Religion in danger’.
('66', 188, 5, 13, 337551) The conduct of the orthodox section in this instance is only a proof of our abysmal ignorance.
('66', 188, 5, 14, 337646) A religion that cannot get rid of such invidious and inequitous distinctions between man and man is doomed to perish.
('66', 188, 5, 15, 337764) The fact that the savarna reformers have remained undaunted by the threat of the boycott must be regarded as a happy augury.
('66', 188, 5, 16, 337889) Let not those who may be affected by the boycott harbour any ill feeling towards the orthodox party.
('66', 188, 5, 17, 337990) At the same time, let no one be turned away from his duty by the threat of coercion.
('66', 188, 5, 18, 338075) The reformers must proceed with their work with patient, silent determination, unaffected by anger or fear.
('66', 188, 6, 19, 338183) Harijan, 8 2 1935
('66', 188, 7, 20, 338201) 274. HOW TO BEGIN?
('66', 188, 8, 21, 338220) I have dealt with some chief articles of food and shown what they mean to the villagers in health and wealth.
('66', 188, 8, 22, 338330) There is, however, the equally important subject of sanitation and hygiene.
('66', 188, 8, 23, 338406) Proper attention to these means increase in health, energy and wealth, directly and indirectly.
('66', 188, 8, 24, 338502) Some foreign observers have testified that, of all the nations of the earth, India comes, perhaps, to the top in the observance of personal cleanliness.
('66', 188, 8, 25, 338655) But I fear that it is not possible to say the same of corporate, in other words, village cleanliness.
('66', 188, 8, 26, 338757) In yet other words, we have not made much advance beyond the family interest.
('66', 188, 8, 27, 338835) We would
('66', 189, 0, 1, 338844) 190 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('66', 189, 1, 2, 338886) sacrifice everything for the family as distinguished from the village, i e., in a sense, the nation.
('66', 189, 1, 3, 338987) Members of a family will keep their own home clean, but they will not be interested in the neighbour’s.
('66', 189, 1, 4, 339091) They will keep their courtyard clean of dirt, insects and reptiles, but will not hesitate to shove all into the neighbour’s yard.
('66', 189, 1, 5, 339221) As a result of this want of corporate responsibility, our villages are dung heaps.
('66', 189, 1, 6, 339304) Though we are an unshod nation, we so dirty our streets and roads that for a sensitive person it is painful to walk along them barefoot.
('66', 189, 1, 7, 339441) It is difficult to get clean, drinkable water in village wells, tanks and streams.
('66', 189, 1, 8, 339524) The approaches to an ordinary village are heaped with muck and rubbish.
('66', 189, 1, 9, 339596) Village sanitation is, perhaps, the most difficult task before the All India Village Industries Association.
('66', 189, 1, 10, 339705) No Government can change the habits of a people without their hearty co operation.
('66', 189, 1, 11, 339788) And if the latter is forthcoming, a Government will have little to do in the matter.
('66', 189, 1, 12, 339873) The intelligentsia—medical men and students—can deal with the problem successfully if they would conscientiously, intelligently, jealously and regularly do the work in the villages.
('66', 189, 1, 13, 340055) Attention to personal and corporate hygiene is the beginning of all education.
('66', 189, 1, 14, 340134) The things to attend to in the villages are cleaning tanks and wells and keeping them clean, getting rid of dung heaps.
('66', 189, 1, 15, 340254) If the workers will begin the work themselves, working like paid Bhangis from day to day and always letting the villagers know that they are expected to join them so as ultimately to do the whole work themselves, they may be sure that they will find that the villagers will sooner or later co operate.
('66', 189, 1, 16, 340556) At least such is my experience of South Africa and Champaran, and even during the quick walking tour in Orissa last year.
('66', 189, 1, 17, 340678) Lanes and streets have to be cleansed of all the rubbish which sould be classified.
('66', 189, 1, 18, 340762) There are portions which can be turned into manure, portions which have simply to be buried and portions which can be directly turned into wealth.
('66', 189, 1, 19, 340909) Every bone picked up is valuable raw material from which useful articles can be made or which can be crushed into rich manure.
('66', 189, 1, 20, 341036) Rags and waste paper can be turned into paper, and excreta picked up are golden manure for the village fields.
('66', 189, 1, 21, 341147) The way to treat the excreta is to mix them, liquid as well as solid, with superficial earth in soil dug no deeper than one foot at the most.
('66', 189, 1, 22, 341289) In his book on rural hygiene, Dr. Poore says that excreta should be buried in earth no deeper than nine to twelve inches (I am quoting from memory).
('66', 189, 1, 23, 341438) The author contends that the superficial earth is charged with minute life, which, together with light and air which
('66', 190, 0, 1, 341555) VOL.66:16 DECEMBER, 1934 24 APRIL, 1935 191
('66', 190, 1, 2, 341599) easily penetrate it, turn the excreta into good, soft, sweet smelling soil within a week.
('66', 190, 1, 3, 341689) Any villager can test this for himself.
('66', 190, 1, 4, 341729) The way to do it is either to have fixed latrines, with earthen or iron buckets, and empty the contents in properly prepared places from day to day, or to perform the functions directly on to the ground dug up in squares.
('66', 190, 1, 5, 341951) The excreta can either be buried in a village common or in individual fields.
('66', 190, 1, 6, 342029) This can only be done by the co operation of the villagers.
('66', 190, 1, 7, 342089) At the worst, an enterprising villager can collect the excreta and turn them into wealth for himself.
('66', 190, 1, 8, 342191) At present, this rich manure, valued at lakhs of rupees, runs to waste every day, fouls the air and brings disease into the bargain.
('66', 190, 1, 9, 342324) Village tanks are promiscuously used for bathing, washing clothes and drinking and cooking purposes.
('66', 190, 1, 10, 342425) Many village tanks are also used by cattle.
('66', 190, 1, 11, 342469) Buffaloes are often to be seen wallowing in them.
('66', 190, 1, 12, 342519) The wonder is that, in spite of this sinful misuse of village tanks, villages have not been destroyed by epidemics.
('66', 190, 1, 13, 342635) It is the universal medical evidence that this neglect to ensure purity of the water supply of villages is responsible for many of the diseases suffered by the villagers.
('66', 190, 1, 14, 342806) This, it will be admitted, is a gloriously interesting and instructive service, fraught with incalculable benefit to the suffering humanity of India.
('66', 190, 1, 15, 342956) I hope it is clear from my description of the way in which the problem should be tackled, that, given willing workers who will wield the broom and the shovel with the same ease and pride as the pen and the pencil, the question of expense is almost whollyeliminated.
('66', 190, 1, 16, 343222) All the outlay that will be required is confined to a broom, a basket, a shovel and a pickaxe, and possibly some disinfectant.
('66', 190, 1, 17, 343349) Dry ashes are, perhaps, as effective a disinfectant as any that a chemist can supply.
('66', 190, 1, 18, 343435) But here let philanthropic chemists tell us what is the most effective and cheap village disinfectant that villagers can improvise in their villages.
('66', 190, 2, 19, 343585) Harijan, 8 2 1935
('66', 190, 3, 20, 343603) 275. LETTER TO THE SECRETARY, NEW INDUSTRIAL & COMMERCIAL EDUCATION SOCIETY
('66', 190, 4, 21, 343679) WARDHA, February 8, 1935 DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter for which I thank you.
('66', 190, 4, 22, 343759) I should like you to discuss with Shri Haribhau G. Phatak of Poona who knows all about the activities regarding Harijans and village industries in general.

('66', 196, 10, 28, 352636) This is how it is usually done.
('66', 196, 10, 29, 352668) For this purpose the
