('66', 197, 11, 19, 353902) By Air Mail February 10, 1935
('66', 197, 12, 20, 353932) MY DEAR AGATHA,
('66', 197, 13, 21, 353948) I have just received and read your letter of 29th ultimo.
('66', 197, 13, 22, 354006) Please send the enclosed 1 to Mr. Heath.
('66', 197, 13, 23, 354047) I am sending it under the same cover to save a few good annas.
('66', 197, 13, 24, 354110) This letter will be airmailed to you.
('66', 197, 14, 25, 354148) 1 Vide the preceding item.
('66', 198, 0, 1, 354175) VOL.66:16 DECEMBER, 1934 24 APRIL, 1935 199
('66', 198, 1, 2, 354219) One part of your letter, therefore, is answered in my letter to Mr. Heath.
('66', 198, 2, 3, 354294) Now for the non attendance at Mr. Raza Ali’s tea party.
('66', 198, 2, 4, 354350) Whenever such invitations have come to me by design, there has been intimation given to me of it.
('66', 198, 2, 5, 354448) Here it was a most casual invitation.
('66', 198, 2, 6, 354486) Two days before the receipt of it, Raza Ali himself had seen me and engaged me in a heart to heart conversation about his mission in South Africa.
('66', 198, 2, 7, 354633) He had arranged for the party already before he came to me.
('66', 198, 2, 8, 354693) But he did not even inquire whether I would attend it.
('66', 198, 2, 9, 354748) If I had received the invitation when he came, I would have opened the conversation myself.
('66', 198, 2, 10, 354840) But I knew nothing of the party then, naturally nothing therefore of the invitation.
('66', 198, 2, 11, 354925) The invitation card was buried in a heap of papers unacknowledged.
('66', 198, 2, 12, 354992) Suddenly, the evening previous to the function, I thought that I must at least acknowledge it.
('66', 198, 2, 13, 355087) And so, early in the morning (it was bitterly cold) I sent the note of which you have a copy.
('66', 198, 2, 14, 355181) It was delivered by Pyarelal personally to Raza Ali.
('66', 198, 2, 15, 355234) It was so delivered and sent so early in order that if there was any meaning behind the invitation I should know.
('66', 198, 2, 16, 355348) Pyarelal saw Raza Ali.
('66', 198, 2, 17, 355371) The latter beyond expressing his regret that I was not going said nothing.
('66', 198, 2, 18, 355446) I concluded that there was no meaning behind it, and I had no time to waste in going to a function in which I could have no interest, and the like of which I never attend except [those] with some honourable purpose behind them.
('66', 198, 2, 19, 355674) Here there was none.
('66', 198, 2, 20, 355695) Indeed I felt that the Viceroy and everybody might even be embarrassed if I responded to a courteous invitation which the sender felt bound to send but would be glad if it was not accepted.
('66', 198, 2, 21, 355885) This is the whole of the reason behind my non acceptance.
('66', 198, 3, 22, 355943) At the time I wrote the letter, so far as I can now recall, I knew nothing of the invitations to Congress M. L. A. s.
('66', 198, 3, 23, 356061) In any case, my non acceptance had no connection with their non acceptance.
('66', 198, 3, 24, 356137) For them there was no other way.
('66', 198, 3, 25, 356170) I was consulted about their attitude and I had given the opinion that they could not accept the invitation.
('66', 198, 3, 26, 356278) But had I known that I was wanted at the meeting for the purpose of breaking the ice, I would unhesitatingly have gone.
('66', 198, 3, 27, 356398) I am no longer a Congress member; and whilst I do nothing that would compromise the Congress because of my past connection with it, I would not hesitate to take action that Congressmen could not possibly take without diminishing the prestige of the Congress.
('66', 198, 3, 28, 356657) I hope this explains to you the whole of my position.
('66', 198, 3, 29, 356711) I have since learnt that the Viceroy would
('66', 199, 0, 1, 356754) 200 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('66', 199, 1, 2, 356796) have been glad if I had gone.
('66', 199, 1, 3, 356826) But I do not know whether that was a thought after the event or before.
('66', 199, 1, 4, 356898) If it was before, a mere hint would have sufficed to send me to the tea party.
('66', 199, 1, 5, 356977) And previous hints have invariably been given to me on such occasions I have C. F. Andrew’s letter.

('66', 200, 3, 14, 359329) 291. LETTER TO P. NARAYANA REDDY
('66', 200, 4, 15, 359362) February 10, 1935 DEAR NARAYANA REDDY,
('66', 200, 5, 16, 359401) I have your letter.
('66', 200, 5, 17, 359421) I am sorry I can’t send your suggestion for publication in Harijan.
('66', 200, 5, 18, 359489) You are altogether wrong in thinking that I have started the village industries work because I believe that Harijan work is finished or because I have now transferred my love to something else.
('66', 200, 5, 19, 359683) Village industry is a natural consequence of intense Harijan propaganda and complementary of it.
('66', 200, 5, 20, 359780) You will see from the items that I have taken up that they affect Harijans first and foremost.
('66', 200, 5, 21, 359875) It is they who live only on rice or atta and salt.
('66', 200, 5, 22, 359926) If they get wholesome atta and rice, surely it is good, and if I agitated that they alone should eat unpolished rice and whole ground wheats they won’t understand it and the proposition can never be carried.
('66', 200, 5, 23, 360134) Then again, the majority of those who were engaged in the husking of paddy were Harijans.
('66', 200, 5, 24, 360224) It is they who have been displaced by the monstrous mills.
('66', 200, 5, 25, 360283) You ought to under stand that if the movement for better sanitation succeeds, so far as the Harijan scavengers are concerned the problem is solved, as it can be solved in no other fashion.

('66', 205, 0, 1, 366372) 206 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('66', 205, 1, 2, 366414) I am glad you are arranging to have the device put up at the Ashram for the hand pounding of rice.
('66', 205, 1, 3, 366513) But evidently you are all still labouring under a mistake.
('66', 205, 1, 4, 366572) You do not want the pestle and mortar that is required for polishing.
('66', 205, 1, 5, 366642) The removing of husk is done by grinding on a very light chakki.
('66', 205, 1, 6, 366707) I have now discovered that chakkis for grinding are made of wood or pure mud for the simple reason that it is only the outer husk we want to remove without damaging the inner grain which can’t bear much weight.
('66', 205, 1, 7, 366918) It is, therefore, a performance which even a child can undertake without any strain.
('66', 205, 1, 8, 367003) No further process is required for preparing the rice for cooking.
('66', 205, 1, 9, 367070) My food is tomatoes, milk, almond paste and some bhaji, ordinarily palak, methi or luni.

('66', 210, 6, 21, 374650) February 11, 1935
('66', 210, 7, 22, 374668) Even though the temple dates back to 1907 the real pranpratistha 2 of Shri Laxminarayan, according to Gandhiji took place on the day when the trustees of the temple opened it to Harijans.
('66', 210, 7, 23, 374856) Since that day, Shri Laxminarayan could as well be called Daridranarayana, meaning God of the most helpless, as untouchables are today.
('66', 210, 8, 24, 374992) With the word Daridranarayana, villagers who are at present most discarded and heavily oppressed, came before his vision.

('66', 225, 6, 14, 399175) 330. GREEN LEAVES
('66', 225, 7, 15, 399193) Take up any modern text book on food or vitamins, and you will find in it a strong recommendation to take a few edible green leaves uncooked at every meal.
('66', 225, 7, 16, 399349) Of course, these should always be well washed half a dozen times to remove all dirt.
('66', 225, 7, 17, 399434) These leaves are to be had in every village for the trouble of picking.
('66', 225, 7, 18, 399506) And yet greens are supposed to be only a delicacy of cities.
('66', 225, 7, 19, 399567) Villagers in many parts of India live on dal and rice or roti, and plenty of chillies, which harm the system.
('66', 225, 7, 20, 399677) Since the economic reorganization of villages has been commenced with food reform it is necessary to find out the simplest and cheapest foods that would enable villagers to regain lost health.
('66', 225, 7, 21, 399870) The addition of green leaves to their meals will enable villagers to avoid many disease from which they are now suffering.
('66', 225, 7, 22, 399993) The villagers’ food is deficient in vitamins; many of them can be supplied by fresh green leaves.
('66', 225, 7, 23, 400091) An eminent English doctor told me in Delhi that a proper use of green leaves was calculated to revolutionize the customary notions of food and that much of what was today being supplied by milk might be supplied by green leaves.
('66', 225, 7, 24, 400320) That, of course, means elaborate research and examination in detail of the nourishing properties of the innumerable leaves that are to be found hidden among the grasses that grow wild in India.
('66', 225, 8, 25, 400514) 1 The names have been omitted.
('66', 226, 0, 1, 400545) VOL.66: 16 DECEMBER, 1934 24 APRIL, 1935 227
('66', 226, 1, 2, 400590) For nearly five months I have been living entirely on uncooked foods.
('66', 226, 1, 3, 400660) I used to take what appeared to me an enormous quantity of a vegetable every day.
('66', 226, 1, 4, 400742) For the past five months I have been taking green leaves in the place of cooked leaves or other vegetable.
('66', 226, 1, 5, 400849) It then seemed to me monstrous that I should have to depend upon the Wardha bazaar for the few ounces of leaves I needed.
('66', 226, 1, 6, 400971) One fine morning Sjt.
('66', 226, 1, 7, 400993) Chhotelalji of the Wardha Ashram brought to me a leaf that was growing wild among the Ashram grasses.
('66', 226, 1, 8, 401095) It was luni.
('66', 226, 1, 9, 401108) I tried it, and it agreed with me.
('66', 226, 1, 10, 401143) Another day he brought chakwat.
('66', 226, 1, 11, 401175) That also agreed.
('66', 226, 1, 12, 401193) But before recommending these jungle leaves to the public, I thought I would have them botanically identified.
('66', 226, 1, 13, 401304) Here is the result, through the kind courtesy of Prof.
('66', 226, 1, 14, 401359) J. P. Trivedi.
('66', 226, 1, 15, 401374) The quotations are from Watt’s monumental volumes on The Economic Products of India.
('66', 226, 2, 16, 401459) Since these were received, I had introduced to me the leaves of sarsav, suva, turnip tops, carrot tops, radish tops and pea plant leaves.
('66', 226, 2, 17, 401597) Besides these, it is hardly necessary to state that the radish, turnip and carrot tubers are also known to be edible in their raw state.
('66', 226, 2, 18, 401734) It is waste of money and ‘good’ taste to cook these leaves or tubers.
('66', 226, 2, 19, 401804) The vitamins contained in these vegetables are wholly or partially lost in cooking.
('66', 226, 2, 20, 401888) I have called cooking these waste of ‘good’ taste, because the uncooked vegetables have a natural good taste of their own which is destroyed by cooking.
('66', 226, 3, 21, 402041) Harijan, 15 2 1935

('66', 227, 3, 7, 403547) 332. ALL ABOUT RICE
('66', 227, 4, 8, 403567) The problem of rice is daily presenting interesting features.
('66', 227, 4, 9, 403629) Shri Shankerlal Banker has already commenced experiments unpolished rice.
('66', 227, 4, 10, 403703) He writes: 1
('66', 227, 5, 11, 403716) The only comment I would like to offer on this letter is that I do not think that any further medical opinion will help.
('66', 227, 5, 12, 403837) The opinion I have gathered and reproduced in these columns is emphatic in favour of unpolished rice.
('66', 227, 5, 13, 403939) But so far as I am aware we have nothing in medical literature describing experiments on which Shri Banker has, like many of us, made the commencement.
('66', 227, 5, 14, 404091) Proof of the pudding is in the eating; let everyone make the experiment for himself.
('66', 227, 5, 15, 404176) One caution, however, as a practised cook, I would like to utter.
('66', 227, 5, 16, 404242) Among the many domestic quarrels I used to have with my wife was one over rice cooking.
('66', 227, 5, 17, 404330) She would have every grain separated.
('66', 227, 5, 18, 404368) I had developed into a dietetic reformer and I knew that that rice was not half as good as that which was well and properly cooked.
('66', 227, 5, 19, 404500) Not an ounce of water in which I cooked rice was thrown away.
('66', 227, 5, 20, 404562) But at that time I knew no distinction between polished and unpolished rice.
('66', 227, 5, 21, 404639) I simply took the ordinary bazaar rice and cooked it through till it became one mass.
('66', 227, 5, 22, 404725) The reader will be glad to know that the quarrel ended in a victory for the reform, and the wife became a convert to properly cooked rice.
('66', 227, 5, 23, 404864) The precaution about unpolished rice is all the
('66', 227, 6, 24, 404912) 1 The quotation is not reproduced here.
('66', 227, 6, 25, 404952) Banker had asserted that contrary to the opinion of some, unpolished.
('66', 227, 6, 26, 405022) rice was not difficult to digest and suggested that Gandhiji might elicit authentic information on the point.
('66', 228, 0, 1, 405132) VOL.66: 16 DECEMBER, 1934 24 APRIL, 1935 229
('66', 228, 1, 2, 405177) more necessary, because the pericarp of rice, which contains all its richer constituents, requires to be cooked thoroughly.
('66', 228, 1, 3, 405301) Therefore, if un polished rice is soaked in cold water for at least three hours before cooking, and then well boiled, there is not only no danger of its proving indigestible, but it will be decidedly more palatable, as has already been found at Maganwadi, the abode of the Association in Wardha.
('66', 228, 1, 4, 405597) We have been having here what may be called half polished rice, not the perfect variety that is described in the foregoing letter.
('66', 228, 1, 5, 405728) Ne vertheless, the rice is well cooked.
('66', 228, 1, 6, 405768) Nobody has complained about its indigestibility.
('66', 228, 1, 7, 405817) But, being far more nutritious than polished rice, which is about pure starch, naturally unpolished rice cannot be, and must not be, eaten in the same quantity as polished rice.
('66', 228, 1, 8, 405995) This is true of all conservative cookery.
('66', 228, 2, 9, 406037) Harijan, 15 2 1935
('66', 228, 3, 10, 406056) 333. MEANING OF ‘STATUS’
('66', 228, 4, 11, 406081) A very valued Harijan sevak puts the following question arising out of the working of the recently passed 1 new constitution.
('66', 228, 5, 12, 406207) The term ‘status’ in the pledges A and B. If by this term is meant that in the eye of God there is no superior or inferior human being, as in the eye of law there is none, our members are prepared to subscribe to it.
('66', 228, 5, 13, 406424) That is to say, they accept it as a religious or philosophical doctrine, the status referred to being spiritual.
('66', 228, 5, 14, 406537) But if by it is meant that no difference in worldly status should be recognized as between master and servant, teacher and pupil, husband and wife, judge and prisoner and so on, it is difficult for us to sign the pledge.
('66', 228, 5, 15, 406758) Kindly let me know if it is spiritual and not wordly status that is meant here.
('66', 228, 5, 16, 406838) Here is the portion of the pledge referred to.
('66', 228, 6, 17, 406885) I do not consider any human being as inferior to me in status and I should strive my utmost to live up to that belief.
('66', 228, 6, 18, 407004) I should think that the answer is given in the pledge itself.
('66', 228, 6, 19, 407066) Evidently, however, equality has been confused by the writer with obliteration of differences.
('66', 228, 6, 20, 407161) If there were no differences or no varieties, there would be no phenomenal world, and the question of equality, i.e., inferiority and superiority, would not arise at all.
('66', 228, 6, 21, 407332) But when God became many, differentiation became a necessity of the case, it would be surely rebellion against the Maker for any of the component parts
('66', 228, 7, 22, 407484) 1 The constitution of the Harijan Sevak Sangh was adopted on January 2, 1935.
('66', 229, 0, 1, 407562) 230 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('66', 229, 1, 2, 407604) to claim superiority over others.
('66', 229, 1, 3, 407638) They must be all equal in status, though different in stature, colour, form, qualities, etc.
('66', 229, 1, 4, 407731) Husband and wife, pupil and teacher, master and servant, judge and criminal, jailor and prisoner are undoubtedly different, but woe betide the husband who considers himself as superior to his wife, or the master as superior to his servant, of the judge as superior to the condemned criminal.
('66', 229, 1, 5, 408023) All the misery in the world is born of the belief in inequality.
('66', 229, 1, 6, 408088) Untouchability as Hindus practise it is its extreme form.
('66', 229, 1, 7, 408146) And what can be more appropriate than that a Harijan sevak should, whilst purging himself of the ancestral taint, think inwardly and get rid altogether of the poison of inequality?
('66', 229, 1, 8, 408327) But what is to be the mark of a master who considers his servant to be his inferior and of the one who considers him to be his equal?
('66', 229, 1, 9, 408461) Well, the one has no consideration for his servant, for he has no interest in him save that he wants service from him against the pay he receives.
('66', 229, 1, 10, 408608) The other treats him as a member of his family.
('66', 229, 1, 11, 408656) Old servants in godfearing families take the place of parents to their masters’ children.
('66', 229, 1, 12, 408746) The masters are sharers in their servants’ misfortunes and trials.
('66', 229, 1, 13, 408813) The servants do not feel that they are any different from their masters, whom they will even upbraid if they go wrong.
('66', 229, 1, 14, 408932) The difference between the superior master and the humble master is the difference between chalk and cheese.
('66', 229, 1, 15, 409041) It is a difference in kind, not merely in degree.
('66', 229, 1, 16, 409091) We are all far from the attainment of this equality, though it is natural and becoming to us as human beings endowed with reason and heart.
('66', 229, 1, 17, 409231) But it is our duty, as also privilege, to strive to enforce that belief in daily life and not merely hope to live it in the world hereafter.
('66', 229, 1, 18, 409372) If we do not make an honest effort, what can be the meaning of equality in the eye of the law?
('66', 229, 1, 19, 409467) This friend, who is a conscientious honorary and honoured worker in the cause, has also difficulty in understanding the implications of the expression ‘whole time workers’ occurring in Rule 10 of the constitution, which provides for one third of Provincial Boards being whole time workers.
('66', 229, 1, 20, 409757) His difficulty is real, because there is nothing to suggest in the rule that they should or may be paid workers.
('66', 229, 1, 21, 409870) As I was present when the constitution was being patiently hammered into shape, I can easily fill in the gap which was purposely left there.
('66', 229, 1, 22, 410011) A permanent paid service by whole time workers is in contemplation.
('66', 229, 1, 23, 410079) It is already in the process of formation.
('66', 229, 1, 24, 410122) It will not exclude honorary whole time workers who have means enough to enable them to give their whole time to the work.
('66', 229, 1, 25, 410245) The word ‘paid’ seemed also to be offensive in this connection.
('66', 229, 1, 26, 410309) Hence it was dropped.
('66', 230, 0, 1, 410331) VOL.66: 16 DECEMBER, 1934 24 APRIL, 1935 231
('66', 230, 1, 2, 410376) But it is clearly contemplated that one third of the workers should be drawn from paid whole time workers wherever they might be available, always assuming that they possess other qualifications for the responsible office.
('66', 230, 1, 3, 410599) The friend has a third difficulty which he states as follows:
('66', 230, 2, 4, 410661) The members of our Board, and especially the Harijan members, desire that Rule 24 should be modified by inserting a minimum proportion of one third in the place of “as many Harijan members as it is possible to secure”.
('66', 230, 2, 5, 410880) In a place like Madras, it is e asily possible to secure 15 Harijanmembers, and as the rule now stands, it would not be permissible to put any others on the Board.
('66', 230, 2, 6, 411044) That would defeat the very object of the Sangh, which is the service of Harijans by non Harijan Hindus.
('66', 230, 2, 7, 411148) The difficulty arises, perhaps, from his overlooking the clause consistently with its maximum”.
('66', 230, 2, 8, 411244) Let me give the whole sentence in the rule.
('66', 230, 2, 9, 411288) “Every Board or Committee shall have as many Harijan members as it is possible to secure consistently with its maximum.” The qualifying clause was intentionally put to avoid the interpretation sought to be placed upon the rule.
('66', 230, 2, 10, 411516) The suggested alteration was con sidered by the Board at Delhi.
('66', 230, 2, 11, 411580) But many members had ex perienced difficulties in securing suitable Harijans to make one third of the membership of their Boards.
('66', 230, 2, 12, 411710) The existing rule meets both the diffi culties.
('66', 230, 2, 13, 411758) I must, however, reiterate my own faith here.
('66', 230, 2, 14, 411804) I was opposed, as I am even now, to the inclusion of Harijans in Harijan Sevak Boards.
('66', 230, 2, 15, 411891) If the Harijan Sevak Sangh is a society of penitent debtors, as it has been conceived to be, it can contain no creditors.
('66', 230, 2, 16, 412013) Creditors are there.
('66', 230, 2, 17, 412034) They will some day or other dictate their terms.
('66', 230, 2, 18, 412083) Today the vast majority are helpless.
('66', 230, 2, 19, 412121) Some even believe that they would commit a heinous sin if they regarded themselves as anything but the meanest and tabooed creation of God.
('66', 230, 2, 20, 412261) The penitent caste Hindu has to render service in all humility.
('66', 230, 2, 21, 412325) It may or may not be accepted.
('66', 230, 2, 22, 412356) His repentance may be too late.
('66', 230, 2, 23, 412388) But whether late or in time, he must perform it.
('66', 230, 2, 24, 412437) He can’t have Harijans to do for him.
('66', 230, 2, 25, 412475) No wonder, with the possible interpretation put upon the rule, the Harijan friends were frightened to shoulder the burden.
('66', 230, 2, 26, 412598) Were they to do penance themselves or to impose it on caste Hindus, who would not be on the Board at all?
('66', 230, 2, 27, 412704) But the tangible difficulty of members from the different provinces who wanted some Harijans on their Boards overbore my opposition.
('66', 230, 2, 28, 412837) My ideal had to recede before their hard experience.
('66', 231, 0, 1, 412890) 232 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('66', 231, 1, 2, 412932) proper, unstrained interpretation of the rule, therefore, is that the Harijan Sevak Boards are to contain as many Harijans as possible, but always containing a preponderating majority of caste Hindus who shall not be less than two thirds of the whole Board.
('66', 231, 1, 3, 413190) But they are not bound to have even one third Harijans if duly qualified persons cannot be secured.
('66', 231, 1, 4, 413290) The pledge to be signed by them has been purposely made extremely light and simple.
('66', 231, 1, 5, 413374) There should, therefore, be no difficulty in securing one third Harijan members.
('66', 231, 1, 6, 413455) The rule being there, it must be honestly worked.
('66', 231, 2, 7, 413505) Harijan, 15 2 1935

('66', 245, 4, 16, 434124) A large quantity can thus be husked with little labour.
('66', 245, 4, 17, 434180) This may be said to be my discovery.
('66', 245, 4, 18, 434217) The quern can be made as light as desired by fixing a washer to the axle.
('66', 245, 4, 19, 434291) This saves a lot of time.
('66', 245, 4, 20, 434317) The work has been rendered very easy.
('66', 245, 4, 21, 434355) The rice obtained thus is always cheaper than mill rice.
('66', 245, 4, 22, 434412) It tastes verysweet and one gets more satisfaction from a smaller quantity.

('66', 246, 1, 2, 435250) 359. MEMBERSHIP OF ALL INDIA VILLAGE INDUSTRIES ASSOCIATION
('66', 246, 2, 3, 435310) From the abstract of the proceedings, to be found elsewhere 1, of the last meeting of the All India Village Industries Association (Headquarters: Wardha, C. P.), readers will find out how one can become a Member or Associate of the Sangh.
('66', 246, 2, 4, 435549) It is to be hoped that those who can fulfil the conditions of Membership or Associateship, will send in the forms duly filled in to the Secretary, Wardha.
('66', 246, 2, 5, 435704) It will be wrong to wait for invitations.
('66', 246, 2, 6, 435746) People await invitations when it is a matter of getting power or prestige.
('66', 246, 2, 7, 435821) They do not, when it is a matter of seeking the privilege of service.
('66', 246, 2, 8, 435891) Let the intending members realize that, unless they are registered as such before 31st March next, they lose in certain eventualities the opportunity of appointment as trustees.
('66', 246, 2, 9, 436069) In the event of a trusteeship becoming vacant before the expiry of five years of the existence of the Association, the remaining trustees should have as long a range of choice as possible.
('66', 246, 2, 10, 436258) This is not possible if many members are not registered before 31st March.
('66', 246, 2, 11, 436333) Without a wide range of choice, the progress of the movement towards its ideal would suffer a check.
('66', 246, 2, 12, 436434) For, the trustees are not merely custodians of the funds, but they are also custodians of the ideal for which the Association stands.
('66', 246, 2, 13, 436568) But even they, however capable they may be of representing the ideal, will be a shaky foundation unless they have the knowledge that they have the support of a large number of men and women from whom they can draw inspiration and strength and on whom they can rely when they have to choose a successor or successors.
('66', 246, 2, 14, 436885) Trusteeship of the Association has been made a position of heavy responsibility by the trustees being made finally responsible for the protection of the ideal, in the remote but not altogether impossible event of its being lowered in the process of democratization of the Association.
('66', 246, 2, 15, 437170) And yet democratization is as necessary for the growth of the movement as the permanence of the ideal, which must not be put in the melting pot.
('66', 246, 2, 16, 437315) But the working out of the ideal is so put.
('66', 246, 2, 17, 437359) For, it is made to rest solely in the hands of a Board which seven years hence becomes subject to election by voters whose sole qualification is
('66', 246, 3, 18, 437504) 1 Vide Appendix “Abstract of the Proceedings of the Board of Management of All India Village Industries Association”, 22 2 1935.
('66', 247, 0, 1, 437633) 248 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('66', 247, 1, 2, 437675) subscribing to the creed of the Association.
('66', 247, 1, 3, 437720) It is true that the application for membership is subject to rejection by the Board.
('66', 247, 1, 4, 437805) That is a precaution merely to prevent an unbeliever becoming a member only to shatter the ideal to pieces.
('66', 247, 1, 5, 437913) The franchise is more extensive than even adult franchise.
('66', 247, 1, 6, 437972) Every villager who is conscious of the dignity of village life and its infinite capacity for promoting the happiness of mankind can belong to the Association.
('66', 247, 1, 7, 438131) Let those, therefore, who believe in the policy and the ideal of the Association become members and work for the economic, moral and physical welfare of the villagers of India, irrespective of differences in political faith, religion, caste or race.
('66', 247, 1, 8, 438381) The Association recognizes no caste, religious, political or racial differences.
('66', 247, 2, 9, 438462) Harijan, 22 2 1935
('66', 247, 3, 10, 438481) 360. COW’S MILK v.
('66', 247, 3, 11, 438500) BUFFALO’S
('66', 247, 4, 12, 438510) The question whether cow’s milk is superior to buffalo’s has come up for inquiry in considering that of village reconstruction.
('66', 247, 4, 13, 438638) I have addressed friends on the subject.
('66', 247, 4, 14, 438679) Shri Haribhau Phatak has forwarded to me a letter received by him from Prof.
('66', 247, 4, 15, 438756) Rao Bahadur Sahasrabuddhe, which reads as follows: 1
('66', 247, 5, 16, 438809) With regard to your enquiry about the differences between cow milk and buffalo milk, I have to say that the fat and casein of cow milk are more easily digestible than those of buffalo millk.
('66', 247, 6, 17, 439000) The cow milk has also greater amount of vitamins than buffalo milk.
('66', 247, 6, 18, 439068) These qualities affect children and adults equally, but an adult can digest buffalo milk while a child cannot.
('66', 247, 6, 19, 439179) I think this is all that you want.
('66', 247, 6, 20, 439214) He has also received an opinion from Dr. S. K. Apte of Sholapur, Vice President, Gopalak Sangh, which is reproducedbelow, 2
('66', 247, 7, 21, 439338) the names of those who sent replies to his questionnaire and some of the replies themselves being omitted.
('66', 247, 8, 22, 439445) The question whether cow milk is superior to buffalo milk is being discussed during the last three years, and this has had a good effect in attracting the public attention to the utility of cow milk.
('66', 247, 8, 23, 439645) The burden of proving that it is superior lies on those who assert so.
('66', 247, 8, 24, 439716) There are several ways of proving this scientifically.
('66', 247, 8, 25, 439771) They can be enumerated as follows:
('66', 247, 9, 26, 439806) 1 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('66', 247, 9, 27, 439843) 2 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('66', 248, 0, 1, 439880) VOL.66: 16 DECEMBER, 1934 24 APRIL, 1935 249
('66', 248, 1, 2, 439925) 1. To compare the merits and demerits of both milks by analysis of their components.
('66', 248, 1, 3, 440010) It is possible chemically to ascertain the nutritive value of their components.
('66', 248, 1, 4, 440090) Such an experiment has been made by Prof.
('66', 248, 1, 5, 440132) Rao Bahadur D. L. Sahasrabuddhe of the Agricultural College, Poona, the details of which he has published in the Dhyanprakash dated 11 9 1934. He has made it clear therein not only that cow milk is very useful for the nutrition of young children but that buffalo milk is actually harmful to them.
('66', 248, 2, 6, 440429) 2. To make two equal groups of boys or men live under the same conditions and to provide one batch with about a seer of cow milk and the other with an equal amount of buffalo milk for a certain period and to watch and record the physical, mental and intellectual development of each member of both the groups.
('66', 248, 2, 7, 440739) The Gopalak Sangh of Sholapur had written to the Hoard s Dairy man for information as to which countries except India use buffaloes as dairy animals.
('66', 248, 2, 8, 440889) The reply to this query shows that buffalo milk is used outside India only in the Philippine Islands and the southern part of China.
('66', 248, 2, 9, 441022) An experiment of the above nature is, therefore, not likely to be made anywhere outside India.
('66', 248, 2, 10, 441117) This experiment will have to be made on some students residing in a boarding house.
('66', 248, 3, 11, 441201) 3. This comparative experiment on human beings is a matter of great expense.
('66', 248, 3, 12, 441278) It is possible to try this experiment on animals, especially rats and guinea pigs kept in experimental laboratories.
('66', 248, 3, 13, 441395) As the Gopolak Sangh has no material available for this sort of experiment, it has written to the Government Pasteur Institute at Coonoor to try such an experiment; but no reply has yet been received from the authorities there.
('66', 248, 4, 14, 441623) 4. The Gopalak Sangh, Sholapur, took recourse to a fourth, and the easiest, way towards this end.
('66', 248, 4, 15, 441721) A questionnaire regarding cow and buffalo milks was prepared and sent some six months back to various doctors, physicians, research experts, newspapers and periodicals, and Government officers in Medical and Health Departments in and outside India.
('66', 248, 4, 16, 441970) About seven hundred copies in Marathi and English of this questionnaire were then sent out.
('66', 248, 4, 17, 442062) About fifty replies have been received so far.
('66', 248, 5, 18, 442109) The following are the conclusions deducible from the replies:
('66', 248, 6, 19, 442171) 1. Buffalo milk is injurious to the development of children, and only cow milk is, in the absence of mother’s milk, useful to them.
('66', 248, 7, 20, 442303) 2. Cow milk, being easily digestible, is more beneficial to patients than buffalo milk.
('66', 248, 8, 21, 442391) 3. There is no definite evidence to show that the use of buffalo milk by adults is in any way injurious.
('66', 248, 8, 22, 442496) Mr. Bruen, the livestock expert to the Government of Bombay, says that buffalo milk is hard to digest for a person of any age, because the excess fat in buffalo milk when it forms soap in the intestine, is hard to digest with the usual amount of salts, and it takes the
('66', 249, 0, 1, 442766) 250 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('66', 249, 1, 2, 442808) deficient quantity of the mineral salts from bones, which are consequently weakened.
('66', 249, 1, 3, 442893) This does not occur in the digestion of cow milk.
('66', 249, 2, 4, 442943) 4. Cow milk is useful for intellectual growth, mainly of children.
('66', 249, 2, 5, 443010) No definite conclusion can be drawn regarding better effect of cow milk on the intellectual growth of adults.
('66', 249, 2, 6, 443120) 5. If, instead of rearing up buffaloes, cows are kept in the city, it will produce a beneficial effect on the general hygiene of that city, with less expense.
('66', 249, 2, 7, 443279) The experiment that Dr. Apte has suggested is worth making.
('66', 249, 2, 8, 443339) The question of the comparative merits of the cow and the buffalo is of national importance from many points of view.
('66', 249, 2, 9, 443457) In no other country in the world do these animals play the part that they do in the life of the nation in India.
('66', 249, 2, 10, 443570) Even without further experiment, the opinions collected by Dr. Apte of eminent medical men and dairy experts sufficiently prove the superiority of cow’s milk over buffalo’s.

('66', 255, 3, 14, 457306) 368. UNPOLISHED RICE V. POLISHED RICE
('66', 255, 4, 15, 457344) Rice from which merely its husk has been removed is known as unpolished rice, whereas, that from which a part of the grain has been rubbed off, is known as polished rice.
('66', 255, 4, 16, 457515) It seems that in Gujarat, ordinarily, the latter is consumed in greater quantities.
('66', 255, 4, 17, 457599) Medical opinion, however, states that only the former should be used, the reason being that polished rice has no nutritional value.
('66', 255, 4, 18, 457731) One doctor is of the opinion that eating polished rice is one of the causes of constipation.
('66', 255, 4, 19, 457824) In all cases of constipation he has cured his patients by prescribing unpolished rice to them.
('66', 255, 4, 20, 457919) However, rice eaters will not give up their deplorable habit of eating polished rice on account of medical opinion alone.
('66', 255, 4, 21, 458041) What they need is their own experience as well as that of others.
('66', 255, 4, 22, 458107) And this is as it should be.
('66', 255, 4, 23, 458136) A statement is meaningless to anyone whose experience contradicts it.
('66', 255, 4, 24, 458206) Hence, I am collecting the experiences of those who are making experiments.
('66', 255, 4, 25, 458282) Shri Shankerlal Banker’s experiment is the best amongst these.
('66', 255, 4, 26, 458345) I have described it in the last issue.
('66', 255, 5, 27, 458384) Shri Banker has suggested that if necessary medical opinion should be sought to prove that unpolished rice is not harmful to the
('66', 255, 6, 28, 458513) 1 Vide “All About Rice”, 15 2 1935
('66', 256, 0, 1, 458548) VOL. 66 : 16 DECEMBER, 1934 24 APRIL, 1935 257
('66', 256, 1, 2, 458595) digestive system.
('66', 256, 1, 3, 458613) That, however, is not necessary.
('66', 256, 1, 4, 458646) All doctors claim with one voice that only unpolished rice should be eaten.
('66', 256, 1, 5, 458722) But this cannot be regarded as a statement based on experience.
('66', 256, 1, 6, 458786) They should either give their own experience or that of their patients.
('66', 256, 1, 7, 458858) There is little of such experience from them.
('66', 256, 1, 8, 458904) Hence, we should rely on the experience only of rice eaters.
('66', 256, 1, 9, 458965) Anyone undertaking the experiment should bear in mind that as unpolished rice contains all the nutritional elements, it should be properly cooked.
('66', 256, 1, 10, 459112) We should give up the habit of keeping the grains separate.
('66', 256, 1, 11, 459172) These may appear pleasing to the eye but there is no sweetness in them.
('66', 256, 1, 12, 459244) Unpolished rice is cooked in the offices of the Village Industries Association in Wardha.
('66', 256, 1, 13, 459334) Everyone eats it with relish.
('66', 256, 1, 14, 459364) But this rice cannot be eaten in the same quantity as white, shiny, polished rice.
('66', 256, 1, 15, 459447) A small quantity is enough to satisfy both the palate and the appetite.
('66', 256, 1, 16, 459519) The monetary gain is obviously twofold.
('66', 256, 1, 17, 459559) As husking is a simple operation, the cost of labour is much less.
('66', 256, 1, 18, 459626) The pounding requires more effort and skill; hence the labour charges are higher.
('66', 256, 1, 19, 459708) However, the greatest benefit lies in the maximum strength and satisfaction derived from eating unpolished rice in small quantities.
('66', 256, 1, 20, 459841) Mill rice can never equal these benefits.
('66', 256, 1, 21, 459883) No one could have a mill merely for the sake of husking rice.
('66', 256, 1, 22, 459945) One cannot afford it.
('66', 256, 1, 23, 459967) The experiments will be pure and productive of results if those making them observe the following rules: 1. Only the husk should be removed from the paddy.
('66', 256, 1, 24, 460123) It should not be pounded at all.
('66', 256, 1, 25, 460156) 2. Unpolished rice should be cleaned, little stones and other impurities should be removed from it and it should then be washed a couple of times in clean cold water.
('66', 256, 1, 26, 460323) It should not be rubbed while washing.
('66', 256, 1, 27, 460362) Rubbing is bound to remove some of the nutritious upper coating.
('66', 256, 1, 28, 460427) 3. The washed rice should be soaked in cold water for three hours.
('66', 256, 1, 29, 460494) Only a little water should be used.
('66', 256, 1, 30, 460530) 4. This soaked rice, along with the water used for soaking, should be added to boiling water and allowed to cook on a slow fire and removed only after it acquires a homogeneous consistency.
('66', 256, 1, 31, 460720) If too much water has been added, it should not be drained but allowed to be soaked up by the rice.
('66', 256, 1, 32, 460820) The next time a more proportionate quantity of water should be used.

('66', 259, 8, 12, 464233) 373. NOTE FOR RAMESHWARDAS PODDAR
('66', 259, 9, 13, 464267) February 24, 1935
('66', 259, 10, 14, 464285) We have no right to judge anyone a sinner as we are all full of imperfections.
('66', 259, 10, 15, 464364) We have no reason or means to judge whether those we regard as greater sinners than ourselves are truly so.
('66', 259, 10, 16, 464472) A person stealing a mere pice can be a greater sinner than a person indulging in sexual immorality.
('66', 259, 10, 17, 464572) Possibly the thief committed a deliberate theft while the licentious person put up great but unsuccessful resistance against the temptation.
('66', 259, 10, 18, 464713) Who can know of his good efforts?
('66', 259, 10, 19, 464747) God alone knows the secrets of the human heart.
('66', 259, 10, 20, 464795) Thus we must not make comparative reckoning of others’ sins but only increase the spirit of forgiveness.
('66', 259, 10, 21, 464900) This is one of the aims of the doctrine of ahimsa.
('66', 259, 10, 22, 464951) M. K. GANDHI [PS.]
('66', 259, 11, 23, 464970) All this I have written applies to everyone.

('66', 267, 4, 7, 475399) 385. QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS 2
('66', 267, 5, 8, 475428) [Before March 1, 1935] 3
('66', 267, 6, 9, 475453) Q. You do not seem to have regard to the question of leisure.
('66', 267, 6, 10, 475515) Too much work Ieaves little leisure to the poorer classes for any intellectual thinking and recreation, and you are now seeking to make them work more.
('66', 267, 7, 11, 475667) A. Is that really so?
('66', 267, 7, 12, 475689) I am trying to deal with people who do not know what to do with their enforced leisure.
('66', 267, 7, 13, 475777) It is their enforced idleness that has made them like so many lifeless stones.
('66', 267, 7, 14, 475856) There is such inertia that some of them do not want to be disturbed.
('66', 267, 8, 15, 475925) Q. You will certainly give employment where it is needed.
('66', 267, 8, 16, 475983) But are you not putting an excessive emphasis on dull monotonous work when you ask them to grind their own corn and husk their own rice?
('66', 267, 9, 17, 476120) A. It is no more monotonous than the idle hours hanging heavy on their hands, and it will cease to be monotonous when they realize that they not only earn a few coppers but preserve their own health and that of their countrymen.
('66', 267, 9, 18, 476349) It is certainly not more monotonous than working away in modern factories.
('66', 267, 9, 19, 476424) Any work, however humdrum, which does not take away the joy of creating something, is not monotonous.

('66', 267, 9, 22, 476664) This is monotonous, for they work without intelligence, but there is no monotony about the work of the shoe maker who makes the whole shoe himself.

('66', 268, 7, 17, 478467) 386. NOTE
('66', 268, 8, 18, 478477) ECONOMICS, FALSE AND TRUE
('66', 268, 9, 19, 478503) A friend has sent me the following extract from Dr. F. D. Farrell, President of the Kansas State College:
('66', 268, 10, 20, 478609) Social values must not be sacrificed for economic values.
('66', 268, 10, 21, 478667) One of the greatest futilities is to progress economically and retrogress socially.
('66', 268, 10, 22, 478751) We all need to recognize that we work and strive so that we may live better, rather than that we live solely that we may work and strive.
('66', 268, 10, 23, 478889) If we live badly, we are poor, no matter how much money we have.
('66', 268, 11, 24, 478954) Adversity is impressing large numbers of farm people with this fact.
('66', 268, 11, 25, 479023) Thus, it is laying the foundation for the acceptance of a rural philosophy that seems likely in the end to prevail.
('66', 268, 11, 26, 479139) This philosophy holds that the chief objective of farming is not to accumulate monetary wealth, but to promote human happiness in the countryside that the farm should be regarded primarily as a home and only incidentally as a business enterprise.
('66', 268, 12, 27, 479386) Adversity is teaching many of us to enjoy the non monetary wealth with which we are surrounded.
('66', 268, 12, 28, 479482) This wealth includes an endless variety of things
('66', 269, 0, 1, 479532) 270 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('66', 269, 1, 2, 479574) from which happiness and satisfaction may be extracted: things ranging all the way from gorgeous sunsets to the companionship of children.
('66', 269, 1, 3, 479713) By living simply and depending largely on our non monetary wealth, we may find not only health and l happiness, but also a large measure of economic security.
('66', 269, 1, 4, 479872) Indeed, economics that ruins one’s health is false, because money without health has no value.
('66', 269, 1, 5, 479967) Only that economy is true which enables one to conserve one’s health.
('66', 269, 1, 6, 480037) The whole of the initial programme of village re construction is, therefore, aimed at true economy, because it is aimed at promoting the health and vigour of the villagers.
('66', 269, 2, 7, 480210) A SHAME
('66', 269, 3, 8, 480218) A strongly built young man of about 25 years presented himself to me only yesterday and asked me whether he could stay with me for two or three days.
('66', 269, 3, 9, 480368) He hails from Bahraich.
('66', 269, 3, 10, 480392) His people have a few acres of land.
('66', 269, 3, 11, 480429) He attended the Bombay Congress.
('66', 269, 3, 12, 480462) Ever since he has been travelling and living on the hospitality of strangers.
('66', 269, 3, 13, 480540) He mixes with Ramanujis.
('66', 269, 3, 14, 480565) They, he tells me, give him food andsomething towards his railway fare.
('66', 269, 3, 15, 480637) On my telling him that living as he was doing on charity was not right, his retort was: “I see nothing wrong in my begging for my food and expenses, as I expect to serve the people.” He could see no incongruity in demanding his maintenance first and then expecting, at some distant date, to render service against maintenance plus, of course wages.
('66', 269, 3, 16, 480986) As he had come at the dinner hour, I invited him to share the meal with us.
('66', 269, 3, 17, 481062) I told him after the meal that he could not stay with us any longer, unless he was prepared to labour with us the whole day long and do the work allotted to him.
('66', 269, 3, 18, 481224) Up to the time of writing he has not been seen by any of us.
('66', 269, 4, 19, 481285) I wish it was possible to say that this was the first case of its kind that came under my observation.
('66', 269, 4, 20, 481388) Young men and women should be ashamed of begging for the supply of their wants.
('66', 269, 4, 21, 481468) If the sense of shame that wrongly attaches to physical labour could be got rid of, there is work enough and to spare for young men and women of average intelligence.
('66', 269, 5, 22, 481635) Harijan, 1 3 1935
('66', 269, 6, 23, 481653) 1 For further light on the case of the young man, whose name was Avadhesh, vide “Notes”, 13 4 1935, sub title, “Full Repentance”.
('66', 270, 0, 1, 481783) VOL. 66 : 16 DECEMBER, 1934 24 APRIL, 1935 271
('66', 270, 1, 2, 481830) 387. MANURE PITS
('66', 270, 2, 3, 481847) Mr. Brayne, Commissioner, Rural Reconstruction, Punjab has sent me, at my request, a parcel of literature published by him.
('66', 270, 2, 4, 481971) This contains useful leaflets of general information to the villagers.
('66', 270, 2, 5, 482042) From these, I propose to publish a selection from time to time.
('66', 270, 2, 6, 482106) I take first the bulletin 1 on Manure Pits: One can subscribe to all that is said here.
('66', 270, 2, 7, 482194) I know that the pits such as Mr. Brayne suggests are generally recommended.
('66', 270, 2, 8, 482270) In my opinion, however, superficial burial recommended by Poore is more scientific and more remunerative.
('66', 270, 2, 9, 482376) The cost of digging is lessened and that of removal avoided altogether or certainly lessened.
('66', 270, 2, 10, 482470) Add to this the fact that the excreta are turned into manure in almost a week’s time, for the reason that the bacteria, which live within six or nine inches of the surface of the earth, and the air and the rays of the sun act upon the excreta and turn them into sweet manure much more quickly than when the refuse is buried deep.
('66', 270, 2, 11, 482800) But the chief thing to remember is not the various methods of disposing of refuse so much as the necessity of burying all the refuse for the double purpose of promoting the villagers’ health and their material condition through the better yield of their crops which the manure must produce.
('66', 270, 2, 12, 483091) It should be remembered that organic rubbish other than excreta must be separately buried.
('66', 270, 2, 13, 483182) Attention to hygiene is undoubtedly the first step to village reconstruction.
('66', 270, 3, 14, 483260) Harijan, 1 3 1935

('66', 276, 1, 2, 492146) 397. LETTER TO JETHALAL G. SAMPAT
('66', 276, 2, 3, 492180) March 6, 1935 It has been resolved 1. to have a congregational prayer in the evening; 2. to create among the wives of the workers interest in publicity work; 3. to promote among the wives of the workers feeling of mutual love and affection; 4. to take minimum help from servants for domestic chores; 5. to give up tea and sugar in our homes; 6. to help the workers make progress in spinning, etc.; 7. to provide hygienic lavatories, etc.; 8. to give systematic education to co workers on free days; 9. to reduce the area of publicity; 10. to begin work with the processing of cotton; 11. to acquire an average of fifteen counts in spinning; 12. to propagate takli among the proper people; 13. to think also about the other industries.

('66', 277, 10, 18, 494049) Sometimes l may appear to others to do so, but it is contrary to my nature to act hastily; and at the present moment I am doubly circumspect, for the simple reason that my own ahimsa is on trial.
('66', 277, 10, 19, 494245) It is not enough for me to protest my innocence.
('66', 277, 10, 20, 494294) If I have it in me, it must be self luminous even as the sun.
('66', 277, 10, 21, 494356) I suppose even the blind, though they do not see the sun, feel the dawn when it is coming.
('66', 277, 10, 22, 494447) The noon day heat, of course, they cannot help feeling.
('66', 277, 10, 23, 494503) And when a man is filled with love, it must be like the noon day sun.
('66', 277, 10, 24, 494573) I may fail to express such ahimsa during this lifetime.
('66', 277, 10, 25, 494629) I shall proclaim that failure from the housetops rather than alter by a hair’s breadth the standard I have set before me.
('66', 277, 10, 26, 494751) Just at the present moment, therefore, I can say that any action hastening Civil Resistance is highly improbable.
('66', 277, 10, 27, 494865) But if it does come, I have no doubt that you will say that

('66', 282, 1, 2, 500673) 409. WELL BEGUN
('66', 282, 2, 3, 500689) A sister 1 who in conjunction with another 2 has just begun work in a little village in C. P. writes a deeply interesting and earnest letter from which I take the following extract: 3
('66', 282, 3, 4, 500873) There is much more that is valuable in the letter before me.
('66', 282, 3, 5, 500934) But I resist the temptation to quote more.
('66', 282, 3, 6, 500977) I must not divide with other items 4 the emphasis which I wish to lay on the necessity for village workers of labouring like the villagers, which the quotation so clearly recognizes.
('66', 282, 3, 7, 501160) If these two sisters are blessed by God with health and can stick to their work for long, if not for life, they will certainly make of their village a model—not merely because they have begun with physical labour, but also because of the propriety of their whole scheme of work and the selfless love of the villagers which fires them.
('66', 282, 3, 8, 501495) Harijan, 8 3 1935
('66', 282, 4, 9, 501513) 410. A BAFFLING PROBLEM
('66', 282, 5, 10, 501537) An honours graduate writes:
('66', 282, 6, 11, 501565) I am a native of Rayalaseema 5 now in the grip of famine.
('66', 282, 6, 12, 501623) The reasons for the deplorable distress which should move the hearts of all the people of India are:
('66', 282, 7, 13, 501724) (1) The awful neglect of the minor irrigation works essential for water supply for daily and irrigation purposes in this rainless uplands region.
('66', 282, 8, 14, 501870) (2) Awful neglect of the domestic industries including hand spinning and weaving, which were brought to life by your work in the other parts of the country but not in this region.
('66', 282, 9, 15, 502050) (3) Awful ignorance and want of education, ancient or modern, among the people and their everlasting engagement in factious fights and criminal litigation.
('66', 282, 9, 16, 502206) Hence, more than famine relief work, famine protection work is absolutely necessary to making the life of the people of this region worth living at all.
('66', 282, 9, 17, 502359) The third is, perhaps, not a cause but a result of the first two causes.
('66', 282, 9, 18, 502432) And if the first is substantial and cannot be or is not remedied,
('66', 282, 10, 19, 502498) 1 Mary Chesley; vide “Letter to Mary Chesley”, 1 3 1935 2 Mary Barr 3 Not reproduced here.
('66', 282, 10, 20, 502589) The correspondent had written about the manual labour she had been doing constructing a verandah in her house.
('66', 282, 10, 21, 502700) She had further added that after completing the verandah she intended to take up gardening.
('66', 282, 10, 22, 502792) 4 The source has “with her items”.
('66', 282, 10, 23, 502827) 5 In Andhra Pradesh
('66', 283, 0, 1, 502847) 284 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('66', 283, 1, 2, 502889) the alternatives before the unhappy inhabitants of these regions are death from starvation or migration from that waterless land.
('66', 283, 1, 3, 503019) It is, however, likely that the situation is not so hopeless as my correspondent describes.
('66', 283, 1, 4, 503111) In any case, I expect that the improvement in the matter of water supply is beyond the ability of private workers.
('66', 283, 1, 5, 503226) But if the conditions of life are at all tolerable, much can undoubtedly be done by right and honest effort in the direction of finding employment for the people.
('66', 283, 1, 6, 503389) There is so much waste material and waste labour in the country that if the two can be utilized, no one need starve.
('66', 283, 1, 7, 503506) There is no doubt that relief measures without simultaneous preventive measures are worse than useless.
('66', 283, 1, 8, 503610) They pauperise the people and turn them away from honest labour.
('66', 283, 1, 9, 503675) Relief measures can themselves be preventive.
('66', 283, 1, 10, 503721) Thus, instead of giving doles, organizers can organize local industries and invite the sufferers to engage in them.
('66', 283, 1, 11, 503837) No one who is not disabled should be fed unless he performs his allotted task.
('66', 283, 1, 12, 503916) In my opinion, intelligent labour is for the time being the only primary and adult education in this land of starving millions.
('66', 283, 1, 13, 504044) Literary education should follow the education of the hand—the one gift that visibly distinguishes man from beast.
('66', 283, 1, 14, 504159) It is a superstition to think that the fullest development of man is impossible without a knowledge of the art of reading and writing.
('66', 283, 1, 15, 504294) That knowledge undoubtedly adds grace to life, but is in no way indispensable for man’s moral, physical or material growth.
('66', 283, 1, 16, 504418) It is, therefore, to be wished that the graduate correspondent and all the workers whom we can muster together would live in the midst of the sufferers and apply themselves to the constructive task of finding work on the spot for them, so as to enable them to feel the dignity that belongs to the man who earns his bread honestly.
('66', 283, 2, 17, 504749) Harijan, 8 3 1935

('66', 289, 6, 12, 512147) I think the letter from the secretary of the A. I. V. I. A. is quite proper.
('66', 289, 6, 13, 512224) What we want to do is not to carry on a campaign of prohibition, which can only come through the State and which is the proper subject to be taken up by somebody.
('66', 289, 6, 14, 512387) But what the A. I. V. I. A. seeks to do is to convert the drunkard to abstemiousness.

('66', 289, 6, 16, 512563) Picketing is a valuable thing up to a point and for a time.
('66', 289, 6, 17, 512623) It cannot become a permanent institution and then according to the principle of the division of labour it cannot be done by one and the same organization.
('66', 289, 6, 18, 512778) A. I. V. I. A. is purely constructive and therefore it must confine itself to teaching people abstemiousness.
('66', 289, 6, 19, 512888) It cannot take up also the work of picketing and move the State to declare prohi bition.
('66', 289, 6, 20, 512977) For that another body has to be created.
('66', 289, 6, 21, 513018) You have therefore to make your choice.
('66', 289, 6, 22, 513058) Either work from without or work from within.
('66', 289, 6, 23, 513104) Both are necessary and no rule can be laid down as to what a person should do.
('66', 289, 6, 24, 513183) That choice has to be made by each one for himself.

('66', 291, 3, 8, 515021) I would strictly abide by that promise, so long as you wish me to do so, but if Sheth Ambalal represents the opinion of the other judges, there is just a danger of their either declining to give their decision, or give it against you on the grounds of insufficiency of evidence.
('66', 291, 3, 9, 515300) I felt therefore that I should let you know what was happening.
('66', 291, 3, 10, 515364) You will please let me know what you would like me to do.
('66', 291, 3, 11, 515422) I cannot guide you, one way or the other, for the simple reason that I do not know what is best in your interest.
('66', 291, 3, 12, 515536) You alone can judge for yourselves what is good for you.

('66', 298, 1, 2, 525864) 440. ADVICE TO VILLAGERS 1
('66', 298, 2, 3, 525891) [Before March 14, 1935] 2
('66', 298, 3, 4, 525917) Just a number of six inches wide and a foot deep trenches would do with open space in between, on which the earth dug out should be banked up in ridges, the people to use the two banks of the trench as seats.
('66', 298, 3, 5, 526126) This is the simplest device.
('66', 298, 3, 6, 526155) You have done the thing without any sense of shame all these years, and you may do without latrines.

('66', 301, 5, 7, 532020) 444. SCAVENGERS ALL
('66', 301, 6, 8, 532040) Untouchability is responsible for more things than we know.
('66', 301, 6, 9, 532100) Now that attention is being drawn to village sanitation, it is becoming clear that the insanitation of villages and towns is chiefly due to the belief in untouchability.
('66', 301, 6, 10, 532270) For fear of touching our own dirt and, therefore, cleaning it, we wallow in dirt and have consigned our obvious duty to a portion of our kith and kin, and because they are rendering what is the most important service of all, we have made them lepers of society, untouchable and uncared for.
('66', 301, 6, 11, 532561) The only remedy for the removal of this social evil and curse is for every one of us to be his own scavengers.
('66', 301, 6, 12, 532672) We would then soon learn the art of cleanliness.
('66', 301, 6, 13, 532721) We would miss many of the most common diseases which are due to filth.
('66', 301, 6, 14, 532792) And we should at the same time serve an economic end.
('66', 301, 6, 15, 532846) G. I. Fowler states, in his Wealth and Waste, that a proper disposal of human excreta would realize Rs. 2 per head per year.
('66', 301, 6, 16, 532971) In the vast majority of cases, all this rich manure is being wasted and disease invited.
('66', 301, 6, 17, 533060) He quotes Prof.
('66', 301, 6, 18, 533076) Brultini, from his volume The Use of Waste Materials, who says that “nitrogen derived from the 282,000 residents of Delhi is sufficient to fertilize a minimum of 10,000 and maximum of 95,000 acres.” Because we do not know how to treat our scavengers, Delhi of ancient fame has pestilential spots of which we have to feel ashamed.
('66', 301, 6, 19, 533406) If we all become scavengers, we would know how to treat ourselves and how to turn what today is poison into rich food for plant life.
('66', 301, 6, 20, 533540) Thirty crores of the population of India should mean, according to Dr. Fowler, an annual gain of 60 crores of rupees to the country if we would but make a wise use of human excreta.
('66', 301, 6, 21, 533722) Let no one be appalled by the magnitude of the problem.
('66', 301, 6, 22, 533778) Those who have the conviction have to begin with themselves in the full faith that everybody else is bound to follow their example if their faith
('66', 301, 7, 23, 533924) 1, 2 & 3 Omissions as in the source
('66', 302, 0, 1, 533960) VOL. 66 : 16 DECEMBER, 1934 24 APRIL, 1935 303
('66', 302, 1, 2, 534007) outlasts the first flush of enthusiasm.
('66', 302, 1, 3, 534047) The word “faith” is, perhaps, not the proper word.
('66', 302, 1, 4, 534098) For the proposition that human excreta are as valuable as those of cattle is not a matter of faith but of daily experience.
('66', 302, 1, 5, 534222) What is required is eradication of age long inertia.
('66', 302, 1, 6, 534275) Sustained, intelligent application of a few today will be the common property of the many tomorrow.

('66', 307, 1, 4, 543293) I admit that there is not much room for choice but such as there is in favour of the indigenous gentry, for the simple reason that they cannot drain the wealth of the country and it is easier to deal with them than with the foreign industrialists who do not hesitate to make good their position by force of arms which they are able to wield effectively.
('66', 307, 1, 5, 543647) Their Indian counterpart is unarmed, and knows that he cannot play fast and loose with his dependents.
('66', 307, 1, 6, 543750) If you saw that your neighbours were in need of assistance during the harvesting season, it would certainly be your duty to offer your help without any expectation of return in the shape of helping you to build the verandah.
('66', 307, 1, 7, 543975) I have now your letter of 9th March in front of me.
('66', 307, 1, 8, 544027) I have a vivid recollection of our discussion over Duncan’s two chapters.
('66', 307, 1, 9, 544101) They had reference to the village worker.
('66', 307, 1, 10, 544143) You told me in the course of our discussion whilst you endorsed his views generally there were portions about which you thought he was over enthusiastic and highly emotional.
('66', 307, 1, 11, 544318) It was not a perfunctory discussion either.
('66', 307, 1, 12, 544362) You laid special stress upon his suggestion of wandering teachers who would go from village to village.
('66', 307, 1, 13, 544466) I think that this was the only point which would have been overlooked 1 had I not come across your letter of the 9th.

('66', 309, 1, 2, 546704) 455. SPEECH AT THE A. I .V. I. A. BOARD MEETING 1
('66', 309, 2, 3, 546754) [On Or before March 18, 1935] 2
('66', 309, 3, 4, 546786) The pledge does bear a spiritual stamp.
('66', 309, 3, 5, 546826) The very fact that we are coming again and again to it indicates that the Board wants to discharge its duties strictly, consistently with the objects of the Association.
('66', 309, 3, 6, 546996) The Pledge was arrived at after the fullest deliberation, and the question whether it will affect the number of our members need not worry us at all.
('66', 309, 3, 7, 547146) The Board can go on with half a dozen members.
('66', 309, 3, 8, 547193) All that we have to do is to explain the implications of the pledge and then it should be left to him or her who subscribes to it to find out whether he or she can satisfy all the conditions.
('66', 309, 3, 9, 547385) The member will certainly ask himself at every step whether he is applying the best part of his energy and talent to the objects of the Association, that is to say, even whilst he is eating or travelling.
('66', 309, 3, 10, 547590) If you think it is a vague pledge, you may make it more concrete, but I do not think it is vague.
('66', 309, 3, 11, 547688) It is a gentlemen’s pledge, and each member is put upon his honour as to the interpretation of the pledge.
('66', 309, 3, 12, 547795) We may not pry into the details of a man’s life.
('66', 309, 3, 13, 547844) Let the man be his own judge.
('66', 309, 3, 14, 547874) Let me tell you that it is possible for an active solicitor to give all his talent and energy to the objects of the Association.
('66', 309, 3, 15, 548003) Thus he will give a different shape tohis office.
('66', 309, 3, 16, 548053) He will invest in reams and reams of hand made paper and village made ink and see that all the documents issuing from his office are on that paper and written in that ink.
('66', 309, 3, 17, 548225) He has a large staff in his office.
('66', 309, 3, 18, 548261) Whenever he has leisure, he will try to interest them in the Association and persuade them to confine themselves, as far as possible, to village made things.
('66', 309, 3, 19, 548419) And so on and so forth.
('66', 309, 4, 20, 548443) Harijan, 22 3 1935

('66', 310, 1, 2, 548740) 456. DISCUSSION WITH MEMBERS OF A. I. V. I. A. 1
('66', 310, 2, 3, 548789) [On or before March 18, 1935] 2
('66', 310, 3, 4, 548821) A regular battle raged between Gandhiji and the scientist members from Bengal on the meaning of unpolished rice.
('66', 310, 3, 5, 548934) Some of the members ate for the first time here the full unpolished rice of Gandhiji’s definition, and some had understood by it the hand pounded, part polished rice which is still to be found in our villages.
('66', 310, 3, 6, 549144) But Gandhiji, who had taken his stand on medical opinion refused to yield an iota of his ground and contended that the pericarp, aleurone and embryo, containing vitamins that, according to medical opinion, were destroyed in mill polished rice, were all retained only in unhusked rice and could be retained in no other.
('66', 310, 3, 7, 549463) That they were so retained or could be so retained in once pounded or twice pounded rice had to be proved by the chemists and scientists.
('66', 310, 4, 8, 549601) [A MEMBER:] But rice pounded only once by the hand in the village dhenki is almost unpolished.
('66', 310, 4, 9, 549696) [GANDHIJI:] That is not how a scientist would talk.
('66', 310, 4, 10, 549748) Do we talk of an almost complete right angle?
('66', 310, 4, 11, 549794) A right angle is a right angle of 90 degrees, not less, not more.
('66', 310, 5, 12, 549860) But the people are so accustomed to the slightly polished rice that it is difficult to persuade them to take to the use of wholly unpolished rice.
('66', 310, 5, 13, 550007) A reformer will not argue like that.
('66', 310, 6, 14, 550044) It does not cook easily, and when cooked, it all becomes a lump and scares people away.
('66', 310, 6, 15, 550132) That it takes more time to cook is true, that it is delicious, and more delicious than the polished rice, has been proved beyond doubt; and after all, what is handsome to the eye may not be handsome after all.
('66', 310, 6, 16, 550342) Handsome is that handsome tastes.
('66', 310, 7, 17, 550376) [GOSIBEHN:] Don’t you murder good age old proverbs, Bapu, in the heat of your argument.
('66', 310, 7, 18, 550464) Well, what else can I do, when I am out to murder age old prejudices and superstitions?
('66', 310, 8, 19, 550552) The scientist members were adamant too.
('66', 310, 8, 20, 550592) Pericarp, they conceded, was lost in the part polished, once pounded rice, but was it essential to health?
('66', 310, 9, 21, 550699) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Notes” 2 Vide the preceding item.
('66', 311, 0, 1, 550774) 312 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('66', 311, 1, 2, 550816) [G.] If you can prove that it is not essential to health, I shall readily capitulate.
('66', 311, 2, 3, 550902) But the problem of food does not simply consist in the calculation of vitamins and proteins.
('66', 311, 2, 4, 550995) Biological experiments must also be made, and it is those experiments that should finally determine the matter.
('66', 311, 2, 5, 551107) It is for you to make those biological experiments.
('66', 311, 2, 6, 551159) Don’t say off hand that Bengalis need half a pound of rice every day and must digest half a pound.
('66', 311, 2, 7, 551258) Devise a scientifically perfect diet for them.
('66', 311, 2, 8, 551305) Determine the quantity of starch required for an average human constitution.
('66', 311, 2, 9, 551382) I would not be satisfied until I have been able to add some milk and milk fat and greens to the diet of our common village folk, and I want chemists who would starve in order to find an ideal diet for their poor countrymen.
('66', 311, 2, 10, 551606) Unfortunately for us, our doctors have never approached the question from the humanitarian standpoint, at any rate from the poor man’s standpoint.
('66', 311, 3, 11, 551753) The upshot of the discussion was the decision to suspend the issue of certificates and cancel the ones already issued, so far as unpolished rice is concerned, and the members were urged to carry on further inquiry and research, in order to place the matter beyond a shadow of doubt.
('66', 311, 3, 12, 552036) Harijan, 22 3 1935
('66', 311, 4, 13, 552055) 457. LETTER TO MANILAL AND SUSHILA GANDHI
('66', 311, 5, 14, 552097) Unrevised March 18, 1935
('66', 311, 6, 15, 552122) MANILAL AND SUSHILA, You have given a good description of the agent.
('66', 311, 6, 16, 552191) I am able to form an idea.
('66', 311, 6, 17, 552218) You should write “Saiyed Sahib” and not just “Saiyed”.
('66', 311, 6, 18, 552273) I do not want to annoy you by persistently criticizing you.
('66', 311, 6, 19, 552333) I trust that you would do nothing with deliberate malice but I also know that you could be led astray or provoked into saying or writing thoughtless words.
('66', 311, 6, 20, 552489) Moreover you do allow your opinions to be based on unconfirmed reports.
('66', 311, 6, 21, 552561) But it is difficult to change your habit forthwith.
('66', 311, 6, 22, 552613) Yes, if you regularly pray as in the ashram and recite Chapter XII [of the Gita] which both of you were made to memorize before your marriage and if you meditate on all this, your heart will soften without any effort and your words will be full of humility, love and truth.
('66', 311, 6, 23, 552887) Then you will not sit in judgment upon what others do.
('66', 311, 6, 24, 552942) You will rather examine your own conduct.
('66', 311, 6, 25, 552984) God has not equipped us very fully with the faculty of judging others.
('66', 311, 6, 26, 553055) Who has been able to
('66', 312, 0, 1, 553076) VOL. 66 : 16 DECEMBER, 1934 24 APRIL, 1935 313
('66', 312, 1, 2, 553123) penetrate the depth of the human heart and isn’t everything imperfect unless we know what is within us?
('66', 312, 1, 3, 553227) That is why the sages have said that we should never sit in judgment over others.
('66', 312, 1, 4, 553309) We will have done our duty if we can weigh our own deeds dispassionately.
('66', 312, 1, 5, 553383) The maxim that if we are good, the whole world is good is but a corollary of this statement.
('66', 312, 1, 6, 553476) I have no time to write about other things.
('66', 312, 1, 7, 553520) I will definitely send for Aruna khadi woven from yarn spun by me.
('66', 312, 1, 8, 553587) But I am afraid you may not get it in time.

('66', 312, 6, 13, 553743) BHAI VALLABHBHAI,
('66', 312, 7, 14, 553761) It is difficult to advise.
('66', 312, 7, 15, 553788) Ballubhai seems to have committed himself to some extent.
('66', 312, 7, 16, 553846) If he has agreed to have prayers, why should he object to distribution of sweets?

('66', 312, 7, 23, 554454) Since civil disobedience has been suspended, the Government may issue any orders it likes and get them obeyed, but most people will do nothing willingly.

('66', 315, 1, 2, 557893) 461. LETTER TO SHANKERLAL BANKER
('66', 315, 2, 3, 557926) WARDHA, March 19, 1935
('66', 315, 3, 4, 557949) MY DEAR SHANKERLAL,
('66', 315, 4, 5, 557969) I have already handed to you Messrs Kirloskar Bros.
('66', 315, 4, 6, 558021) letter of 14th instant addressed to me.
('66', 315, 4, 7, 558061) I commend their letter to the earnest attention of the examiners.
('66', 315, 4, 8, 558127) As Messrs Kirloskar Bros.
('66', 315, 4, 9, 558153) have permitted me to give my own opinion, 1 do so for the guidance of the examiners.
('66', 315, 4, 10, 558238) The numbers against the following paragraphs refer to those in their letter.
('66', 315, 4, 11, 558315) (2) The trial at Wardha is not yet complete.
('66', 315, 4, 12, 558360) In so far as it has gone, I can say that a capable worker did succeed once or twice in spinning over 8,000 yards in 4 hours.
('66', 315, 4, 13, 558485) There never has yet been an output of 16,000 in eight hours at Wardha.
('66', 315, 4, 14, 558556) No woman has worked at it for eight hours at a stretch here.
('66', 315, 4, 15, 558617) My trial of it is still proceeding.
('66', 315, 4, 16, 558653) I should like to try it for six months before pronouncing an opinion onits average capacity.
('66', 315, 4, 17, 558746) But if the examiners are satisfied on this point, absence of a conclusive opinion from me need not in any way delay or otherwise affect the examiners’ award.
('66', 315, 4, 18, 558904) (5) I am unable to subscribe to the opinion that the machine “has fulfilled all the important and major conditions of the competition”.
('66', 315, 4, 19, 559040) I have up to now only applied myself to two conditions, viz., 1st and 4th.
('66', 315, 4, 20, 559115) I do not regard the 1st condition as to handiness as a minor one.
('66', 315, 4, 21, 559181) Indeed it is in my opinion the one unalterable condition.
('66', 315, 4, 22, 559239) Without that condition, there would surely be no difficulty in producing a machine that would give more than 16,000 yards in 8 hours.
('66', 315, 4, 23, 559373) Handiness has to be proved with reference to the crores of cottages scattered in 700,000 villages of India.
('66', 315, 4, 24, 559481) Accepting Webster’s definition of ‘convenient’, a mere look at the machine would convince one who has any knowledge of Indian cottages and conditions that the machine cannot be called handy in any shape or form.
('66', 315, 4, 25, 559693) For an Indian cottage it is without doubt a cumbersome piece of machinery.
('66', 315, 4, 26, 559768) As to conditions 5 and 6, I am wholly incompetent to pronounce an opinion.
('66', 315, 4, 27, 559843) As to condition 2, it is yet too early for me to pronounce an opinion.
('66', 315, 4, 28, 559914) I understand from Shri Kale as also from the machine of the
('66', 316, 0, 1, 559974) VOL. 66 : 16 DECEMBER, 1934 24 APRIL, 1935 317
('66', 316, 1, 2, 560021) firm who were good enough to visit me that the machine is not capable of being reduced in size any further than it is already.
('66', 316, 1, 3, 560148) I am quite satisfied that the machine cannot be accommodated in an Indian cottage of the average size.
('66', 316, 1, 4, 560251) The firm’s suggestion that cottages should be specially built in order to house the machine is too unpractical to need refutation.
('66', 316, 1, 5, 560382) In my opinion, therefore, the machine does not satisfy what to me is one of the vital conditions of the prize.
('66', 316, 1, 6, 560493) But it may not be considered as more than the evidence of a witness before the judges.
('66', 316, 2, 7, 560580) Yours sincerely,
('66', 316, 3, 8, 560597) SHANKERLAL BANKER AHMEDABAD
('66', 316, 4, 9, 560625) From a copy: Pyarelal Papers.
('66', 316, 4, 10, 560655) Courtesy: Pyarelal

('66', 318, 4, 6, 562809) 466. LETTER TO DR.
('66', 318, 4, 7, 562828) N. N. GODBOLE
('66', 318, 5, 8, 562842) WARDHA, March 20, 1935
('66', 318, 6, 9, 562865) DEAR DR.
('66', 318, 6, 10, 562874) GODBOLE,
('66', 318, 7, 11, 562883) I thank you for your letter enclosing your valuable note on the comparative merit of cow butter fat and buffalo butter fat.
('66', 318, 7, 12, 563007) The carefulness with which you are approaching this question tempts me to put further questions.
('66', 318, 7, 13, 563104) I am using tamarind as part of food, of course in measured quantities, for those who are suffering from constipation and who are on uncooked green leaves such as methi, chakvat and the like.
('66', 318, 7, 14, 563295) The popular belief in these parts, however, seems to be that tamarind produces boils and induces rheumatism.
('66', 318, 7, 15, 563404) Is there any warrant for these beliefs?
('66', 318, 7, 16, 563444) Can you also tell me what leaves are edible in an uncooked state?
('66', 318, 7, 17, 563510) I am using just now the bhajis one gets in the market including cabbage, cauliflower, in an uncooked state.
('66', 318, 7, 18, 563618) One thing more.
('66', 318, 7, 19, 563634) If you are following the pages of Harijan, you must have noticed the opinion I have published on unpolished rice.
('66', 318, 7, 20, 563748) 2 It seems that there is no such thing as whole unpolished rice to be had in the market.
('66', 318, 7, 21, 563837) I had difficulty in procuring whole unpolished rice.
('66', 318, 7, 22, 563890) And I am now grinding my own paddy and have now whole unpolished rice.
('66', 318, 7, 23, 563961) Chemists, however, say that there is no proof to show that whole unpolished rice is meant by those who have given their opinion in its favour.
('66', 318, 7, 24, 564104) I have, however, contended that in a matter of such importance medical men who have given me their considered opinion could not have used the expression ‘unpolished rice, in a loose unscientific manner.
('66', 318, 7, 25, 564307) There can be degrees of polished rice but surely not of unpolished.
('66', 318, 7, 26, 564375) They contend that it is highly likely that the pericarp which even a slight polishing removes, is unnecessary for the system if
('66', 318, 8, 27, 564503) 1 Vide “Letter to Secretary, Political Department, Government of Bengal”, 20 2 1935 2 Vide “How to Begin”
('66', 319, 0, 1, 564609) 320 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('66', 319, 1, 2, 564651) not also injurious.
('66', 319, 1, 3, 564671) Of course they admit that they have no authority for their statement.
('66', 319, 1, 4, 564741) They simply say that the testimony in favour of unpolished rice has reference only to the partly polished, hand pounded bazaar rice which passes as unpolished.
('66', 319, 1, 5, 564901) Can you throw any light on this controversy?
('66', 319, 1, 6, 564946) Is the pericarp of rice lndigestible?
('66', 319, 1, 7, 564984) Is it harmful to the system?
('66', 319, 1, 8, 565013) Can it be that this matter has escaped investigation up till now?
('66', 319, 2, 9, 565079) Yours sincerely, DR.
('66', 319, 2, 10, 565100) N. N. GODBOLE HINDU UNIVERSITY BENARES

('66', 320, 6, 15, 567053) BHAI HARIVADAN,

('66', 320, 7, 18, 567180) Now today the time has come for giving you some trouble.
('66', 320, 7, 19, 567237) A Harijan who is a favourite of Mama and whom Mama gives first rank in integrity and who shares half of your name—being called Haribhai—seems to have become your neighbour to satisfy your wishes.

('66', 320, 7, 21, 567480) Now all this is beyond my comprehension.
('66', 320, 7, 22, 567521) Leave aside Harijans.
('66', 320, 7, 23, 567543) How many men of such integrity have we among non Harijan workers?

('66', 320, 7, 25, 567743) Mama has asked me to help him.
('66', 320, 7, 26, 567774) Solve my problem to my satisfaction; and only after that the question of assistance can be thought of.
