('66', 323, 0, 1, 570477) 324 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('66', 323, 1, 2, 570519) 474. INTERVIEW TO A MISSIONARY 1
('66', 323, 2, 3, 570552) [Before March 22, 1935] 2
('66', 323, 3, 4, 570578) A missionary friend who was on a visit to us asked Gandhiji what was the most effective way of preaching the gospel of Christ, for that was his mission.
('66', 323, 3, 5, 570731) [GANDHIJI:] To live the gospel is the most effective way— most effective in the beginning, in the middle and in the end.
('66', 323, 3, 6, 570852) Preaching jars on me and makes no appeal to me, and I get suspicious of missionaries who preach.
('66', 323, 3, 7, 570949) But I love those who never preach but live the life according to their lights.
('66', 323, 3, 8, 571028) Their lives are silent yet most effective testimonies.
('66', 323, 3, 9, 571083) Therefore I cannot say what to preach, but I can say that a life of service and uttermost simplicity is the best preaching.
('66', 323, 3, 10, 571207) If, therefore, you go on serving people and ask them also to serve, they would understand.
('66', 323, 3, 11, 571298) But you quote instead John 3, 16 and ask them to believe it.
('66', 323, 3, 12, 571359) That has no appeal to me, and I am sure people will not understand it.
('66', 323, 3, 13, 571430) Where there has been acceptance of the gospel through preaching, my complaint is that there has been some motive.
('66', 323, 4, 14, 571544) [Q.] But we also see it and we try our best to guard against it.
('66', 323, 4, 15, 571609) [A.] But you can’t guard against it.
('66', 323, 4, 16, 571646) One sordid motive vitiates the whole preaching.
('66', 323, 4, 17, 571694) It is like a drop of poison which fouls the whole food.
('66', 323, 4, 18, 571750) Therefore I should do without any preaching at all.
('66', 323, 4, 19, 571802) A rose does not need to preach.
('66', 323, 4, 20, 571834) It simply spreads its fragrance.
('66', 323, 4, 21, 571867) The fragrance is its own sermon.
('66', 323, 4, 22, 571900) If it had human understanding and if it could engage a number of preachers’ the preachers would not be able to sell more roses than the fragrance itself could do.
('66', 323, 4, 23, 572063) The fragrance of religious and spiritual life is much finer and subtler than that of the rose.
('66', 323, 5, 24, 572158) Harijan, 29 3 1935
('66', 323, 6, 25, 572177) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s report of the interview published in, Harijan under the title “The Most Effective Way”.
('66', 323, 6, 26, 572298) 2 Gandhiji commenced his four week silence on March 22. The interview, therefore, must have taken place before that date.
('66', 323, 6, 27, 572420) 3 Mahadev Desai says: “But all this apparently failed to be of effect and the reverend gentleman retired with the imprecation, .
('66', 323, 6, 28, 572549) ‘Mr. Gandhi .
('66', 323, 6, 29, 572563) soon there will come a day when you will be judged, not in your righteousness, but in the righteousness of Jesus.’ ”
('66', 324, 0, 1, 572680) VOL. 66 : 16 DECEMBER, 1934 24 APRIL, 1935 325
('66', 324, 1, 2, 572727) 475. INTERVIEW TO MISSIONARY LADIES 1
('66', 324, 2, 3, 572765) [Before March, 22, 1935] 2
('66', 324, 3, 4, 572792) Q. When you concentrate on the health and welfare of the villages, are you going in for medical relief to any extent?
('66', 324, 4, 5, 572910) GANDHIJI: We are not going in for medical relief but for prevention.
('66', 324, 4, 6, 572979) Therefore we concentrate on sanitation and hygiene.
('66', 324, 4, 7, 573031) I am of opinion that a good deal of medical help is given ‘only in order to make people more helpless.
('66', 324, 4, 8, 573134) Medical help, in most cases, is practically thrown at them, and so it is lost on them.
('66', 324, 4, 9, 573221) Some of my co workers are going to a village close by where the streets are covered with filth.
('66', 324, 4, 10, 573317) No wonder if the eyes of the children there are bad and there are all kinds of diseases.
('66', 324, 4, 11, 573406) Just now our workers’ efforts do not seem to make any impression on the villagers; but when they find that, as a result of their village having become cleaner and free from filth, they are also comparatively free from disease, they will appreciate the difference.
('66', 324, 4, 12, 573670) Now, if you had a free dispensary there and were giving doses of medicine to all that came, you would make no headway.
('66', 324, 4, 13, 573789) Tackling the village sanitation is the only really substantial work.
('66', 324, 4, 14, 573858) There is an evil at our doors which is perfectly preventible, and yet we have suffered our villagers to tolerate it for scores of years.
('66', 324, 4, 15, 573995) It is an uphill task, whilst the distribution of free medicines is much easier.
('66', 324, 4, 16, 574075) But I am asking my co workers to avoid the easy thing and cheap applause.
('66', 324, 4, 17, 574149) We must first concentrate on the prevention of disease, we can tackle the disease itself later on.
('66', 324, 5, 18, 574248) Q. Then you won’t have doctors?
('66', 324, 6, 19, 574280) A. No, if you will not misunderstand me.
('66', 324, 6, 20, 574321) I have done medical relief work myself.
('66', 324, 6, 21, 574361) Only last month Harijans in Kathia war were given free medical relief by doctors, who performed operations for cataract and other diseases of the eyes.
('66', 324, 6, 22, 574513) But I am just now talking of measures for the preservation of general health, and even when my workers have achieved the preliminary task of cleaning the villages, I should equip them with just four things— quinine, castor oil, bicarbonate of soda and iodine.
('66', 324, 6, 23, 574773) No fifth thing is necessary.
('66', 324, 7, 24, 574802) Q. You seem to give the last place in your programme to schools?
('66', 324, 8, 25, 574867) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s report of the interview published in Harijan under the title “The Most Effective Way”.
('66', 324, 8, 26, 574987) The missionary ladies had come from Nagpur.
('66', 324, 8, 27, 575031) 2 Vide the preceding item.
('66', 325, 0, 1, 575058) 326 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('66', 325, 1, 2, 575100) We are conducting numerous schools for Harijans and giving numerous scholarships to Harijan boys.
('66', 325, 1, 3, 575198) What is the use of my adding the school programme to the work of the Industries Association?
('66', 325, 1, 4, 575291) It is intended to supplement the work of the Harijan Sangh and the Spinners’ Association.
('66', 325, 1, 5, 575381) This last has a capital of Rs. 20 lakhs to operate upon, and the Harijan Sangh has also a fair amount of funds.
('66', 325, 1, 6, 575493) I must now launch a campaign, I said to myself, which needs very little funds and which adds to the pockets of the poor.
('66', 325, 1, 7, 575614) Thus, if I could simply ask the villagers not to waste the human manure but to turn it to good account, I should, without any capital outlay, help them to save Rs. 50 crores every year.
('66', 325, 1, 8, 575800) This turning of human evacuations to rich manure by superficial burial I learnt from Dr. Poore, and it is the simplest and the most effective method, whereas the activated sludge plan and the septic tank are comparatively expensive things.
('66', 325, 2, 9, 576040) Q. Does your Harijan Sangh do anything for the spiritual welfare of the people?
('66', 325, 3, 10, 576120) A. With me, moral includes spiritual, and so my answer to your question will be ‘everything, and ‘nothing’.
('66', 325, 3, 11, 576228) Nothing, because we have no department to look after their spiritual welfare.
('66', 325, 3, 12, 576306) Everything, because we expect the personal touch of the workers to transform the men among whom they are working.
('66', 325, 3, 13, 576420) Even as it is, we are caught in the coil of hypocrisy; but when you set apart a department for the work, you make the thing doubly difficult.
('66', 325, 3, 14, 576562) In my career as a reformer I have regarded everything from the moral standpoint.
('66', 325, 3, 15, 576643) Whether I am engaged in tackling a political question or a social or economic one, the moral side of it always obtrudes itself and it pervades my whole attitude.
('66', 325, 3, 16, 576805) But I admit I have no special department to look after the Harijans’ spiritual welfare.
('66', 325, 4, 17, 576893) Q. But we, Christians, feel that we, who have something to share, must share it with others.
('66', 325, 4, 18, 576986) If we want consolation, we find it from the Bible.
('66', 325, 4, 19, 577037) Now, as for the Harijans, who have no solace to get from Hinduism, how are we to meet their spiritual needs?
('66', 325, 5, 20, 577146) A. By behaving just like the rose.
('66', 325, 5, 21, 577181) Does the rose proclaim itself, or is it self propagated?
('66', 325, 5, 22, 577238) Has it an army of missionaries proclaiming its beauties?
('66', 325, 6, 23, 577295) Q. But supposing someone asked us, ‘Where did you get the scent?’
('66', 325, 7, 24, 577361) A. The rose, if it had sense and speech, would say, ‘Fool, don’t you see that I got it from my Maker?’
('66', 325, 8, 25, 577464) Q. But if someone asks you, ‘Then, is there no book?’
('66', 326, 0, 1, 577518) VOL. 66 : 16 DECEMBER, 1934 24 APRIL, 1935 327
('66', 326, 1, 2, 577565) A. You will then say, ‘Yes, for me there is the Bible.’ If they were to ask me, I would present to some the Koran, to some the Gita, to some the Bible and to some Tulsidas’s Ramayana.
('66', 326, 1, 3, 577749) I am like a wise doctor prescribing what is necessary for each patient.
('66', 326, 2, 4, 577821) Q. But I find difficulty in getting much from the Gita.
('66', 326, 3, 5, 577877) A. You may, but I do not find any difficulty in getting much from the Bible as well as from the Koran.
('66', 326, 4, 6, 577980) Harijan, 29 3 1935
('66', 326, 5, 7, 577999) 476. LETTER TO MADELEINE ROLLAND
('66', 326, 6, 8, 578032) [Before March 22, 1935] 1
('66', 326, 7, 9, 578058) DEAR MADELEINE,
('66', 326, 8, 10, 578074) I have just read your letter to Pyarelal.
('66', 326, 8, 11, 578116) Thank God I am about to observe complete silence, thus I can reply to your letter immediately.
('66', 326, 8, 12, 578211) Yes, I ought to write a complete letter in reply to the long letter of the Sage 2. But the very adjective “complete” frightens me.
('66', 326, 8, 13, 578342) I have no time to compose a letter which will do sufficient justice to this letter from there.
('66', 326, 8, 14, 578437) I must try to do it during my days of silence.
('66', 326, 8, 15, 578484) Your question is simple.
('66', 326, 8, 16, 578509) My opposition is to socialism as it is interpreted here in its official programme.
('66', 326, 8, 17, 578592) I can have nothing to say against the theory or the philosophy of socialism.
('66', 326, 8, 18, 578669) The programme as it is put here cannot be achieved without violence.
('66', 326, 8, 19, 578738) The socialists here do not exclude violence under all circumstances whatsoever.
('66', 326, 8, 20, 578818) They would take to arms openly if they saw there was a chance to usurp power by it.
('66', 326, 8, 21, 578902) There are in the programme some details into which I need not enter.
('66', 326, 8, 22, 578971) I wonder if this reply will answer your difficulties.
('66', 326, 8, 23, 579025) However, you must write about your difficulties more concretely.
('66', 326, 8, 24, 579090) Love to you both.
('66', 326, 10, 25, 579108) From a copy: C.W. 9737. Courtesy: R. K. Prabhu
('66', 326, 11, 26, 579155) 1 The source has “March 28”.
('66', 326, 11, 27, 579184) However it is clear from the text that the letter was written before Gandhiji had started his silence, which he did on March 22. 2 Romain Rolland

('66', 327, 1, 2, 579372) 477. NOTES
('66', 327, 2, 3, 579383) DEPLORING ‘CONVERSIONS’
('66', 327, 3, 4, 579407) A Harijan sevak in Devakottah writes deploring the so called conversions to Christianity of Harijans in that locality.
('66', 327, 3, 5, 579526) The public know how they are systematically persecuted by the Nattars.
('66', 327, 3, 6, 579597) If, afflicted by the persecution and losing hope of ever receiving help from the other savarna Hindus, the poor Harijans seek shelter in Christianity, we may not be surprised.
('66', 327, 3, 7, 579773) And our grief is worse than useless if we cannot turn it into powerful energy.
('66', 327, 3, 8, 579852) Conversion under the stress of physical discomfort is no spiritual conversion.
('66', 327, 3, 9, 579931) But we may not grumble if Harijans change their faith in order to better their material condition and to secure protection from persecution.
('66', 327, 3, 10, 580072) What we need deplore is the cause of conversion.
('66', 327, 3, 11, 580121) Let us realize and own that savarna Hindus are the cause.
('66', 327, 3, 12, 580179) If the savarna Hindus of Devakottah were alive to a sense of duty by the Harijans of their locality the Nattars, who are themselves savarna Hindus, would not dare persecute Harijans as if the latter were not members of the same human family as the former.
('66', 327, 3, 13, 580435) The correspondent suggests that some persons from outside Devakottah might go and work among the Nattars and the Harijans.
('66', 327, 3, 14, 580558) It would be good if this happened.
('66', 327, 3, 15, 580593) But I doubt if ever substantial results will be obtained by stray outsiders going there temporarily.
('66', 327, 3, 16, 580694) Any such effort must be vain, as will be that of doctors going among and seeking to cure patients who would not help themselves with the medicines prescribed for them.
('66', 327, 3, 17, 580862) Both the wings of the savarna Hindus, those who stand aloof and the Nattar savarna Hindus, are suffering from illnesses, the latter from hankering after the persecution of their fellows, and the former from criminal apathy.
('66', 327, 3, 18, 581086) Outsiders can at best go among them, diagnose the disease and prescribe the remedy.
('66', 327, 3, 19, 581170) It is for the patients to adopt the remedy.
('66', 327, 3, 20, 581214) The young savarnas of Devakottah know the cause and the remedy.
('66', 327, 3, 21, 581278) Will they apply it?
('66', 327, 3, 22, 581298) Thakkar Bapa is in their midst or will be presently.
('66', 327, 3, 23, 581351) Will they listen to his advice?
('66', 327, 3, 24, 581383) Conversions are but one small result of the disease.
('66', 327, 3, 25, 581436) Remove the cause, and the conversions will cease, as also many worse results.
('66', 327, 4, 26, 581514) ‘TAKLI’ FOR VILLAGE WORKERS
('66', 327, 5, 27, 581542) I would request the several workers in various parts of India who
('66', 328, 0, 1, 581608) VOL. 66 : 16 DECEMBER, 1934 24 APRIL, 1935 329
('66', 328, 1, 2, 581655) have been seeking to deliver the message of self reliance in the matter of cloth in villages, to pay their attention to the potentialities of the takli as a means of spinning.
('66', 328, 1, 3, 581831) This subject has been referred to previously in these columns some time back, and it deserves to be studied with great attention.
('66', 328, 1, 4, 581961) It has been demonstrated by the inmates of the Satyagraha Ashram and sister institutions of Wardha that for an average spinner the productive capacity of the takli, if rightly handled, is equal to that of the charkha in every respect.
('66', 328, 1, 5, 582196) For a person who is not altogether weak and who wants to spin only during leisure hours, and not with a view to remuneration, the takli is capable of completely replacing the charkha.
('66', 328, 1, 6, 582380) The workers should, therefore, learn the new method of plying the takli, and introduce it in the villages in preference to the charkha.
('66', 328, 1, 7, 582516) For the aged and the weak the charkha would still be necessary.
('66', 328, 1, 8, 582580) For, the charkha, according to the principles of mechanics, is but a takli worked by a system of levers.
('66', 328, 1, 9, 582685) And as one whose muscles are not strong enough to lift up a weight by hand would need the help of a lever to do so, so one who cannot give the necessary momentum to the takli by the muscles of his palm, or cannot bear the strain of constantly raising and lowering the arm, would need the charkha.
('66', 328, 2, 10, 582982) A WORKER’S PILGRIMAGE
('66', 328, 3, 11, 583004) Shri Sitarama Sastry has been organizing what may be called pilgrimages of workers who convey the message of village service, among their surroundings.
('66', 328, 3, 12, 583156) He sends me a brief report of the second pilgrimage from which I take the following:
('66', 328, 4, 13, 583241) The second ‘march, commenced on the morning of the 17th February and ended in the evening of the 4th March.
('66', 328, 4, 14, 583349) The party consisted of 8 men led by Srijut N. Venkatachellapaty and Ramineni Appayya.
('66', 328, 4, 15, 583435) Two worked for 4 days, one for 11 days, and the other 5 worked continuously.
('66', 328, 5, 16, 583512) They visited 13 villages in the Bapatla 1 taluq, one village in Tenali 2
('66', 328, 6, 17, 583585) taluq, and another in Repalle taluq, in all 15 places.
('66', 328, 6, 18, 583640) They travelled by rail, motor, country carts and on foot; and the distance covered by them is 75 miles.
('66', 328, 7, 19, 583744) They delivered lectures in 4 villages with the aid of the magic lantern and gave gramophone performances in 5 villages.

('66', 329, 11, 15, 584441) This is a step in the right direction.
('66', 329, 11, 16, 584480) I would suggest that the pilgrims should avoid all travelling by rail, motor, or even village carts.
('66', 329, 11, 17, 584581) If they will adopt my advice, they will observe that their work will be more effective and that the expenses will be practically nil.
('66', 329, 11, 18, 584715) No more than two or three should form a party.
('66', 329, 11, 19, 584762) I would expect villagers to house and feed the parties.
('66', 329, 11, 20, 584818) Small parties will be no tax on the resources of villagers, as large ones are likely to be.
('66', 329, 11, 21, 584910) The work of the parties should be more in the nature of sanitary service, survey of village conditions and instruction of the villagers as to what they can do without much, if any, outlay of money to improve their health and economic conditions.
('66', 329, 11, 22, 585156) If we seek to make villages self dependent to the utmost extent possible, there is not much scope for sale, in the villages visited, of articles made in other villages, except where it is clear that villagers do not or cannot make such articles in their own villages.
('66', 329, 11, 23, 585424) Village service as conceived by the A. I. V. I. A. has a unique mission.
('66', 329, 11, 24, 585497) Town parties go out to villages to clean, instruct and purchase.
('66', 329, 11, 25, 585562) Parties of villagers can be organized to go to towns to sell articles made in their villages and demonstrate their usefulness.
('66', 329, 11, 26, 585689) This village movement is one of decentralization and restoration of health and comfort and the skill of the artisan to villagers.

('66', 331, 3, 13, 589021) 479. INSTRUCTIONS TO THE MEMBERS OF A. I. V. I. A.
('66', 331, 4, 14, 589072) The Pledge 1 was purposely drawn up as it is.
('66', 331, 4, 15, 589118) It is of a general character.
('66', 331, 4, 16, 589148) It is a gentleman’s pledge, each member being put upon his or her honour as to the interpretation of the expression ‘the best part of my energy and talents to the furtherance of its object, which is the all round welfare of villagers of India’.
('66', 331, 4, 17, 589393) Members are also pledged, not only to work for the furtherance of the object, but also ‘to strive to live up to the ideals and prefer the use of village manufactures to any other’.
('66', 331, 4, 18, 589574) The recommending Member of the Board will, therefore, see to it that the candidate for Membership has, in everything he does, welfare of villagers at heart.
('66', 331, 4, 19, 589731) It follows that such a person will give to village work at least some time every day, not necessarily in villages, but may be, for villages.
('66', 331, 4, 20, 589872) Thus, a Member living in a city on a particular day, who sells to or induces a person to buy village manufactures, has done some village work for that day.
('66', 331, 4, 21, 590028) The Member recommending will also see to it that the candidate, wherever possible, uses for himself articles of village manufacture, e.g., khadi in the place of mill cloth, village earthen pots instead of factory made china, reed pen instead of steel pen, hand made paper instead of ordinary paper, wholesome babul, neem or such other twigs
('66', 331, 5, 22, 590369) 1 Vide Appendix “Forms of Undertaking to be given by Associates, Paid Workers and Honorary Workers of A.I.V.I.A”, 22 3 1935.
('66', 332, 0, 1, 590494) VOL. 66 : 16 DECEMBER, 1934 24 APRIL, 1935 333
('66', 332, 1, 2, 590541) as tooth brushes, instead of the very insanitary and injurious modern tooth brushes, leather goods made in villages out of village tanned hide, instead of ordinary bazaar articles, village gur instead of factory sugar, hand pounded, whole rice, instead of mill polished rice.
('66', 332, 1, 3, 590817) Harijan, 22 3 1935

('66', 354, 4, 6, 623039) 523. SELF SUSTAINED KHADI
('66', 354, 5, 7, 623065) Shri Shankerlal Banker has been travelling in the villages, in order to ascertain the possibilities of self sustained khadi and of the development of other industries.
('66', 354, 5, 8, 623233) Self sustained khadi means khadi spun and woven in the first instance by the villagers for themselves and, wherever possible, out of cotton grown, ginned and carded in the respective villages.
('66', 354, 5, 9, 623426) This is the true mission of khadi.
('66', 354, 5, 10, 623461) The end can only be achieved by persistent human contact with the villagers.
('66', 354, 5, 11, 623538) They should know the dignity and value of work apart even from its economic value.
('66', 354, 5, 12, 623621) Khadi under this scheme will be manufactured to suit the village taste.
('66', 354, 5, 13, 623693) Bleaching, even washing, will be avoided, for every villager will wash for himself or herself.
('66', 354, 5, 14, 623788) Khadi thus produced will be cheaper than any cloth if its durability is taken into account.
('66', 354, 5, 15, 623880) The town khadi carries all the incidental charges, e.
('66', 354, 5, 16, 623934) g., extra processes, stocking, transport, rents, commissions.
('66', 354, 5, 17, 623996) The village khadi eliminates all these charges.
('66', 354, 5, 18, 624044) The towns and cities should rely for their supplies on the surplus that may be saved after village use.
('66', 354, 5, 19, 624148) Hence no khadi store should be run at a loss.
('66', 354, 5, 20, 624194) A. I. S. A. stores should aim primarily at quality, never at mere show, masquerading under the name of art.
('66', 354, 5, 21, 624302) Who knows what true art is?
('66', 354, 5, 22, 624330) At best it is a relative term.
('66', 354, 5, 23, 624361) A. I. S. A. stores should be original, should introduce village art in towns and have confidence that they will win the day.
('66', 354, 5, 24, 624486) Every piece of khadi must be strong and durable.
('66', 354, 5, 25, 624535) We must not procure fineness at the cost of durability Flimsiness will kill khadi in the end.
('66', 354, 5, 26, 624629) If we cannot produce fine counts without sacrificing strength, we must own our inability.
('66', 354, 5, 27, 624719) I have noticed, often enough to frighten me out of bleaching, that bleached khadi gives way almost at the first wear.
('66', 354, 5, 28, 624837) It is not suggested that this is true in every case.
('66', 354, 5, 29, 624890) It is enough for my purpose to be able to say that cases of bleached khadi having proved undurable have been frequent enough to cut out customers.
('66', 354, 5, 30, 625037) Let all Khadi Bhandars, therefore, revise their standard in so far as it may be necessary in the light of what I have said here.
('66', 355, 0, 1, 625166) 356 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('66', 355, 1, 2, 625208) what is true of khadi is more or less true of tanning and other village industries.
('66', 355, 1, 3, 625292) Workers must not, without considerable experience, interfere with the old tools, old methods and old patterns.
('66', 355, 1, 4, 625403) They will be safe if they think of improvements retaining intact the old existing background.
('66', 355, 1, 5, 625497) They will find that it is true economy.
('66', 355, 2, 6, 625537) Harijan, 29 3 1935
('66', 355, 3, 7, 625556) 524. TEMPLE ENTRY
('66', 355, 4, 8, 625574) A few days ago a conference of the Pallas of Kulitalai taluk in Trichinopoly District was held, at which the following two resolutions were passed:
('66', 355, 5, 9, 625722) 1. That this Conference views with regret and great disappointment the attitude evinced by the Mahatma towards the Temple Entry Bill in the Assembly and, therefore, requests him to withdraw his present views on the subject and to kindly see that this subject is brought into the Assembly at any cost, irrespective of results thereof.
('66', 355, 6, 10, 626056) 2. That this Conference has intended to request all the members of the Depressed Classes of the country either to convert themselves as Muslims or Christians, if the Mahatma is not pleased to change his present views on the Temple Entry Bill or to agitate for a separate electorate to the Depressed Classes as it has been awarded by the Premier of the British Cabinet.
('66', 355, 6, 11, 626425) I like the first resolution.
('66', 355, 6, 12, 626454) I wish all Harijans will take the same interest in the temple entry question as this conference seems to have done.
('66', 355, 6, 13, 626570) Then my task would be less difficult than it now is.
('66', 355, 6, 14, 626623) Whether it is difficult or easy, I shall pursue the course I think best in order to have every public Hindu temple thrown open to Harijans.
('66', 355, 6, 15, 626763) For, in my opinion, untouchability cannot be claimed to have been removed, unless all temples are accessible to Harijans as they are to other Hindus.
('66', 355, 6, 16, 626913) But the second resolution gives away the whole case for temple entry, so far as the conference is concerned.
('66', 355, 6, 17, 627022) Men who threaten to leave their religion, because some other men, pretending to be of the same faith as they, prevent them from entering temples, have little religion about them.
('66', 355, 6, 18, 627201) Such men cannot be said to be actuated by the religious spirit.
('66', 355, 6, 19, 627265) Temples are houses of worship.
('66', 355, 6, 20, 627296) They are for allwho believe in them.
('66', 355, 6, 21, 627333) Religious persecution is not a thing of today.
('66', 355, 6, 22, 627380) It is as ancient as religion itself.
('66', 355, 6, 23, 627417) It tries and purifies the persecuted who prove themselves staunch in their faith.
('66', 355, 6, 24, 627499) If Harijans can patiently bear persecution, they are bound to come triumphant in the end.
('66', 356, 0, 1, 627589) VOL. 66 : 16 DECEMBER, 1934 24 APRIL, 1935 357
('66', 356, 1, 2, 627636) But the threat to desert the faith they have uncomplainingly professed from time immemorial, if their right of temple entry is not recognized, puts them out of court.
('66', 356, 1, 3, 627803) Sanatanists probably do not care if Harijans leave the Hindu fold.
('66', 356, 1, 4, 627870) Reformers will be nonplussed if they have no case to fight for.
('66', 356, 1, 5, 627934) Fortunately, there are tens of thousands of Harijans whose faith remains unshakable in spite of persecution.
('66', 356, 1, 6, 628043) Religion is an essentially personal matter.
('66', 356, 1, 7, 628087) It is one between oneself and one’s God.
('66', 356, 1, 8, 628128) It should never be made a matter of bargain.
('66', 356, 1, 9, 628173) I would respectfully advise the leading spirits behind the conference of the Pallas of Kulitalai to treat the question of temple entry on its merits and not to confuse the issue by the threat contained in their second resolution.
('66', 356, 1, 10, 628403) Harijan, 29 3 1935
('66', 356, 2, 11, 628422) 525. NOTES
('66', 356, 3, 12, 628433) A GENEROUS DONATION
('66', 356, 4, 13, 628453) During Thakkar Bapa’s tour in Travancore, we received on behalf of the Central Sangh, from Shri Parmeswaran Pillai, President of the local Harijan Sevak Sangh, a donation of a portion of his ground for Harijan Ashram.
('66', 356, 4, 14, 628671) It is situated at Vithura Nedumangad.
('66', 356, 4, 15, 628709) The following brief speech 1 he made at the meeting announcing the gift sufficiently describes it.
('66', 356, 4, 16, 628808) It is now over fourteen years since a school was started here.
('66', 356, 4, 17, 628871) Ten months ago I rebuilt the school house at a cost of about Rs. 800. The school has now three classes with a total attendance of 75. Of these, 40 are Harijans.
('66', 356, 4, 18, 629032) Of these Harijans 34 are boys and 6 girls.
('66', 356, 4, 19, 629075) The number of Kani children in the school now is 16. I have long thought that a school of this kind cannot fully serve its purpose without being made part of an ashram where one or two workers will stay all the time and undertake daily a programme of co ordinated Harijan uplift work.
('66', 356, 4, 20, 629360) I have, therefore, now put up a small building for the Ashram.
('66', 356, 4, 21, 629423) I have also set apart 10 acres of land for the Ashram, 8_ acres of which are planted with about 2,000 cashewnut trees.
('66', 356, 4, 22, 629542) These trees will begin to bear in another 2 years, and as cashewnuts are fetching a good price, this will constitute a tangible item of income.
('66', 356, 4, 23, 629686) I intend taking at once 5 Harijan boys, including 3 Kanis, as residential students in the Ashram.
('66', 356, 4, 24, 629784) A worker has been appointed and he will stay with the boys in the Ashram.
('66', 356, 4, 25, 629858) After 6 months I propose to take 5 more boys, making the total of residential students 1 0 .
('66', 356, 5, 26, 629951) 1 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('66', 357, 0, 1, 629988) 358 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('66', 357, 1, 2, 630030) Thinking that an institution of this kind will work better as part of the Harijan Sevak Sangh, I have handed over the school, the Ashram building and the ten acres of land to the Kerala Board of the Harijan Sevak Sangh .
('66', 357, 1, 3, 630251) I congratulate the donor for his generous gift and hope that the Harijans will make good use of the Ashram which is to receive the personal care and affection of the donor.
('66', 357, 2, 4, 630424) PAISA FUND
('66', 357, 3, 5, 630435) Paisa Fund is a unique institution in India, if not in the world.
('66', 357, 3, 6, 630501) Its creator, Shri Antaji D. Kale, is a poor man.
('66', 357, 3, 7, 630550) Twenty five years ago, he conceived the idea of establishing what might be otherwise called a poor man’s fund.
('66', 357, 3, 8, 630661) For he meant literally to collect paisas—quarter annas—for the promotion of industries and thus help the poor.
('66', 357, 3, 9, 630772) Its visible monument is the Talegaon Glass Works near Poona, which have been a means of providing decent livelihood to hundreds of young men.
('66', 357, 3, 10, 630914) The committee of this Fund celebrated the other day its silver jubilee amid the blessings of many friends.
('66', 357, 3, 11, 631021) I wish this enterprise, brilliant as it has been, a still more brilliant career.
('66', 357, 3, 12, 631102) The committee have issued a sumptuous and readable volume, in commemoration of the silver jubilee, which gives a history of the whole enterprise and a fund of information about glass works throughout India.
('66', 357, 3, 13, 631309) It can be had on application to the Secretary, 626, Shanvar, Poona 2.
('66', 357, 4, 14, 631379) BUFFALO MILK FAT V. COW MILK FAT
('66', 357, 5, 15, 631412) Dr. Godbole, professor of Industrial Chemistry in the Benares Hindu University, has sent me at my request an elaborate and critical analysis of these two fats.
('66', 357, 5, 16, 631572) It is far too technical for the lay reader.
('66', 357, 5, 17, 631616) I shall gladly lend it to any student of this important subject.
('66', 357, 5, 18, 631681) Meanwhile I content myself with giving his conclusions.
('66', 357, 6, 19, 631737) I. Cow butter fat is known to have iodine in its composition, whereas no data are available on this point in the case of buffalo butter fat.
('66', 357, 7, 20, 631878) Both cow butter fat and buffalo butter fat contain vitamins A and D; but cow butter fat is richer in vitamin A, while the other is richer in vitamin D.
('66', 357, 8, 21, 632030) Butter fat as such is any time better than tallow, lard or vegetable ghee.
('66', 357, 9, 22, 632105) Cow butter fat is richer than the buffalo butter fat in the total assimilable and digestible part and is, therefore, comparatively more suitable for children and weaklings.
('66', 357, 10, 23, 632278) V. From an economic point of view, the buffalo is a better butter producing machine than the cow.
('66', 358, 0, 1, 632376) VOL. 66 : 16 DECEMBER, 1934 24 APRIL, 1935 359
('66', 358, 1, 2, 632423) We are of opinion that it is worth while trying physiological experiments in India on oils like sesame, cocoanut, etc., which are rich in assimilables, although poor in vitamins.
('66', 358, 2, 3, 632602) Of the two butter fats, cow’s is in a sense nearer to the composition of human body fat than the buffalo butter fat.

('66', 366, 1, 2, 644391) 540. LETTER TO HATIM ALVI
('66', 366, 2, 3, 644417) March 31, 1935
('66', 366, 3, 4, 644432) I have your second letter and now the pamphlet 1. I have gone through the letter carefully.
('66', 366, 3, 5, 644524) Your case is undoubtedly strong.
('66', 366, 3, 6, 644557) I feel flattered by your compliment that there is no domestic circle to which I do not belong.
('66', 366, 3, 7, 644652) Even so, my duty would often compel non interference.
('66', 366, 3, 8, 644706) So long as there are divisions even in the same family, they will have to be respected.
('66', 366, 3, 9, 644794) We are one vast human family.
('66', 366, 3, 10, 644824) You have gone further, and rightly.
('66', 366, 3, 11, 644860) All God’s creation is one family.
('66', 366, 3, 12, 644894) But we accept our limitations.
('66', 366, 3, 13, 644925) In this quarrel of yours I am quite sure that you ought not to invite outside aid—outside the Borah group.
('66', 366, 3, 14, 645032) If you break through the fence, you have no complaint to make.
('66', 366, 3, 15, 645095) If you recognize Borahs as a distinct group, the quarrel should be adjusted among the members of the group.
('66', 366, 3, 16, 645203) Any extension of the doctrine is sure to land us in trouble.
('66', 366, 3, 17, 645264) Then, were you right in disregarding excommunication?
('66', 366, 3, 18, 645318) Mind, I am not examining the position from the legal standpoint.
('66', 366, 3, 19, 645383) It is the moral that concerns me.
('66', 366, 3, 20, 645417) From the ahimsa standpoint, you should have respected the order of excommunication.
('66', 366, 3, 21, 645501) There is too much violence in the air.
('66', 366, 3, 22, 645540) Your object was and is to convert the high priest and if not him, at least the fellow Borahs.
('66', 366, 3, 23, 645634) This you could have done without forcing the entry into the mosque.
('66', 366, 3, 24, 645702) Your motive is triumph of truth, not assertion of rights.
('66', 366, 3, 25, 645760) I wonder if what I have said appeals to your reason.
('66', 366, 5, 26, 645813) From the manuscript of Mahadev Desai’s Diary.
('66', 366, 5, 27, 645859) Courtesy: Narayan Desai
('66', 366, 6, 28, 645883) 1 Issued by the Borah Young Men’s Association giving details of the dispute between the reformers and the orthodox of the Borah community.

('66', 366, 6, 30, 646090) The Mullah excommunicated them for holding such views but they regained their right of entry into the mosque by a legal verdict.

('66', 379, 3, 8, 662752) 568. LETTER TO AGATHA HARRISON
('66', 379, 4, 9, 662783) WARDHA, April 4, 1935
('66', 379, 5, 10, 662805) MY DEAR AGATHA,
('66', 379, 6, 11, 662821) I have your maid.
('66', 379, 6, 12, 662839) I am supporting your suggestion about sending Rajaji.
('66', 379, 6, 13, 662893) 1 But I must confess to you I have no faith in these deputations.
('66', 379, 6, 14, 662959) The British policy is fixed and rigid.
('66', 379, 6, 15, 662998) They want to carry their Bill at any cost.
('66', 379, 6, 16, 663041) They will placate any opinion but the advanced Indian political opinion.
('66', 379, 6, 17, 663114) They honestly believe that if they give the Indian politicians an inch, they will want an ell and grumble even when they get their ell.
('66', 379, 6, 18, 663250) This belief is not only honest, it is well founded.
('66', 379, 6, 19, 663302) The Indian wants his independence as of right.
('66', 379, 6, 20, 663349) The official says he has no right save that of being governed.
('66', 379, 6, 21, 663412) The official has the firm opinion that India is incapable of governing herself.
('66', 379, 6, 22, 663492) Hence whatever he concedes is given grudgingly.
('66', 379, 6, 23, 663540) Hence no advance will satisfy the Indian advanced politician.
('66', 379, 6, 24, 663602) He may take it only to agitate for more.
('66', 379, 6, 25, 663643) The policy has now been definitely adopted of never conceding to the popular demand.
('66', 379, 6, 26, 663728) They will give only what they honestly think is proper.
('66', 379, 6, 27, 663784) This does not irritate me.
('66', 379, 6, 28, 663811) We have to develop internal strength to take what we need.
('66', 379, 6, 29, 663870) Now see what is happening here.
('66', 379, 6, 30, 663902) Read the enclosed latest ordinance—a whole population being degraded for the sake ofcrushing a few “terrorists”.
('66', 379, 6, 31, 664015) They won’t attempt to know why young men and women are ready to throw away their lives.
('66', 379, 6, 32, 664103) They are now doing what they have never dared before.
('66', 379, 6, 33, 664157) They have evolved a new philosophy.
('66', 379, 6, 34, 664193) Things will right themselves but not by your importing even our best men.
('66', 379, 6, 35, 664267) You must plough the lonely furrow for the time being.

('66', 386, 4, 20, 675046) 580. THE EXTENT OF MEDICAL AID
('66', 386, 5, 21, 675077) With the commencement of the activities of the A. I. V. I. A., medical aid finds a prominent, if not almost an exclusive, place on the programme of many workers.
('66', 386, 5, 22, 675239) The aid consists in distributing among the villagers free medicines, allopathic, ayurvedic, unani or homoeo pathic, or all combined.
('66', 386, 5, 23, 675372) Druggists selling these medicines are quite ready to oblige workers approaching them for a few medicines, which cost them a trifle and which, in their opinion, may, if they look at the gift selfishly; bring them more buyers.
('66', 386, 5, 24, 675597) The poor patients become the victims of well intentioned but ill informed or over enthusiastic workers.
('66', 386, 5, 25, 675701) More than three fourths of these drugs are not only useless but imperceptibly, if not perceptibly, harmful to the bodies into which they are put.
('66', 386, 5, 26, 675847) Where they do bring some temporary relief to the patients, their substitutes are as a rule to be found in the village bazaar.
('66', 386, 5, 27, 675973) Medical men of the West are slowly but surely finding out that the less drugs they prescribe the better it is for their patients.
('66', 386, 5, 28, 676103) The best of them never keep their patients in ignorance of what is prescribed.
('66', 386, 5, 29, 676182) Instead of overloading their prescriptions, they give some simple harmless drug.
('66', 386, 5, 30, 676263) The best part of their work consists in steadying their
('66', 387, 0, 1, 676319) 388 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('66', 387, 1, 2, 676361) patients, removing their fears and insisting on careful nursing and a change of diet.
('66', 387, 1, 3, 676447) They are more and more veering round to the belief that nature is the best healer.
('66', 387, 1, 4, 676530) Therefore, A. I. V. I. A. is leaving medical relief of the kind I have described severely alone.
('66', 387, 1, 5, 676627) Its primary care is education in matters of health as well as of economy.
('66', 387, 1, 6, 676701) Are not both interrelated?
('66', 387, 1, 7, 676728) Does not health mean wealth for the millions?
('66', 387, 1, 8, 676774) There bodies, not their intellects, are the primary instruments of wealth.
('66', 387, 1, 9, 676849) The Association, therefore, seeks to teach people how to prevent disease.
('66', 387, 1, 10, 676923) It is well known that the food of the millions is very deficient in its nourishing value.
('66', 387, 1, 11, 677013) What they do eat they misuse.
('66', 387, 1, 12, 677043) Their knowledge of hygiene is practically nil.
('66', 387, 1, 13, 677090) Village sanitation is as bad as it well can be.
('66', 387, 1, 14, 677138) If, therefore, these defects can be put right and the people imbibe the simple rules of hygiene, most of the ailments they suffer from must disappear without further effort or any outlay of money.
('66', 387, 1, 15, 677335) Hence the Association does not contemplate opening dispensaries.
('66', 387, 1, 16, 677400) Investigations are now being made to find out what the villages can supply in the shape of drugs.
('66', 387, 1, 17, 677498) Satisbabu’s cheap remedies are an effort in that direction.
('66', 387, 1, 18, 677558) But incredibly simple though they are, he is experimenting with a view to making drastic reduction in the number of these remedies, without diminishing their efficacy.
('66', 387, 1, 19, 677726) He is studying the bazaar drugs and testing them and comparing them with the corresponding drugs in the British pharmacopoeia.
('66', 387, 1, 20, 677853) The desire is to wean the simple villagers from the awe of my sterious pills and infusions.
('66', 387, 2, 21, 677945) Harijan, 5 4 1935
('66', 387, 3, 22, 677963) 581. PRIESTHOOD AND UNTOUCHABILITY
('66', 387, 4, 23, 677998) A correspondent from Sibasagar writes: 1
('66', 387, 5, 24, 678039) When I was touring in Assam last year in the Harijan cause, I had understood that the tea garden coolies were regarded as untouchables and that the Miris were also almost so regarded.
('66', 387, 5, 25, 678223) Be that as it may, it is a serious question whether, where the priests exploit the superstition of the people and where innocent birds and animals are offered as sacrifice, it is right to agitate for the entry of Harijans to
('66', 387, 6, 26, 678448) 1 The letter to not reproduced here.
('66', 387, 6, 27, 678485) The correspondent had reported about a temple at Dergaon, Assam, where innocent birds and animals were offered as sacrifice and which barred the entry of tea labourers and Miris because they were regarded as untouchables.
('66', 388, 0, 1, 678707) VOL. 66 : 16 DECEMBER, 1934 24 APRIL, 1935 389
('66', 388, 1, 2, 678754) such a temple.
('66', 388, 1, 3, 678769) No doubt temple reform is a separate question.
('66', 388, 1, 4, 678816) Entry of Harijans into temples cannot await reform.
('66', 388, 1, 5, 678868) But I would draw the line at temples where animal sacrifices are offered.
('66', 388, 1, 6, 678942) I would not touch these temples till animal sacrifices are stopped.
('66', 388, 1, 7, 679010) Inward corruption in temples cannot affect the devotee who knows nothing about it.
('66', 388, 1, 8, 679093) But with animal sacrifice every worshipper is intimately connected.
('66', 388, 1, 9, 679161) For, he or she hasto offer such sacrifice.
('66', 388, 1, 10, 679204) And a Harijan admitted for the first time in such a temple would naturally be expected to bring some poor bird or animal as sacrifice.
('66', 388, 1, 11, 679339) He may or may not be a meat eater, but who will make himself responsible for the sin of teaching an unsophisticated Harijan that God expects His worshippers to propitiate Him with the blood of innocent dumb animals who have never sinned, who have no sense of sin?
('66', 388, 1, 12, 679603) I wish that the leaders of Assam will purge the Dergaon temple of the stain of bloody sacrifice.
('66', 388, 1, 13, 679700) Let no one retort that the beginning should be made, not with an unknown temple like that of Dergaon, but it should be with the temple of Kali.
('66', 388, 1, 14, 679844) Most reforms have had their origin in small beginnings.
('66', 388, 1, 15, 679900) The citadel of Kali will fall by its own weight, if the minor temples wash themselves clean of innocent blood.
('66', 388, 2, 16, 680011) Harijan, 5 4 1935

('66', 395, 1, 2, 690373) 591. LETTER TO CHANDULAL
('66', 395, 2, 3, 690398) April 6, 1935
('66', 395, 3, 4, 690412) BHAI CHANDULAL,
('66', 395, 4, 5, 690428) It is good that you asked the question.
('66', 395, 4, 6, 690468) There is nothing wrong in my believing that no one can feel as strongly as I. It is no more than an expression of one’s own strong feeling.
('66', 395, 4, 7, 690608) I do not believe that anyone else can have greater love for my mother than I have.
('66', 395, 4, 8, 690691) Do you find anything wrong with this statement?
('66', 395, 4, 9, 690739) The same is true of the other sentence.
('66', 395, 4, 10, 690779) There could be millions of people who practise more austere penance.
('66', 395, 4, 11, 690848) But just the same I can say that I do not know of any such, can’t I?
('66', 395, 4, 12, 690917) Would you look upon it as claiming omniscience I said that I hadn’t heard anyone speak the language of the seers?
('66', 395, 4, 13, 691031) There could be millions speaking the language of the seers, but must I not say it if I have not met any?
('66', 395, 4, 14, 691136) If you don’t follow, ask again.
('66', 395, 5, 15, 691168) Blessings from BAPU

('66', 397, 1, 2, 692847) 595. LETTER TO KANU GANDHI
('66', 397, 2, 3, 692874) WARDHA, April 7, 1935
('66', 397, 3, 4, 692896) KANAIYO,
('66', 397, 4, 5, 692905) How foolish you are!
('66', 397, 4, 6, 692926) When you first suspected that I was displeased with you, you could have had your doubt resolved immediately.
('66', 397, 4, 7, 693035) In the instances which you have cited, there was no question at all of my being displeased.
('66', 397, 4, 8, 693127) I take work from you that is hard enough, and that as exactingly as I can, because I am pleased with you.
('66', 397, 4, 9, 693233) I am not at all angry with you.
('66', 397, 4, 10, 693265) If I were, I would say so immediately and not hide the fact from you.
('66', 397, 4, 11, 693335) You have, therefore, no cause to feel unhappy or disheartened.
('66', 397, 4, 12, 693398) You need not believe that you will never be able to learn English.
('66', 397, 4, 13, 693465) And even if you cannot, why should you give way to despair?
('66', 397, 4, 14, 693525) Is there anything else to make you feel despondent?
('66', 397, 4, 15, 693577) You need not hide anything from me.
('66', 397, 4, 16, 693613) I am fully satisfied with you.
('66', 397, 4, 17, 693644) You have given me no cause to feel dissatisfied.
('66', 397, 4, 18, 693693) You need not, therefore, leave and go away somewhere else.
('66', 397, 4, 19, 693752) After this, do you want any explanation about the instances which upset you?
('66', 397, 4, 20, 693829) I am returning your letter.
('66', 397, 5, 21, 693857) Blessings from BAPU [PS.]
('66', 397, 6, 22, 693883) I forgot to reply to one of your questions.
('66', 397, 6, 23, 693927) Your decision to improve your Gujarati thoroughly is perfectly correct.
('66', 397, 6, 24, 693999) Master the grammar.
('66', 397, 6, 25, 694019) English will then come of itself.
('66', 397, 6, 26, 694053) If you make a systematic study of Gujarati, you will be able to learn any other language without much difficulty.
('66', 397, 6, 27, 694167) You should do your best to memorize the eighteen chapters [of the Gita].
('66', 397, 6, 28, 694240) Give more time to the study of Sanskrit.
('66', 397, 6, 29, 694281) You should have informed me about Purushottam immediately.
('66', 397, 7, 30, 694340) From a microfilm of the Gujarati: M.M.U./II

('66', 399, 4, 11, 696068) That is why it is invincible.

('66', 399, 4, 13, 696138) It is not mere philosophizing, though.

('66', 399, 4, 15, 696211) I place before you whatever thoughts come to me.
('66', 399, 4, 16, 696260) As you know, I never wish to hide any thought of mine from you.

('66', 404, 1, 2, 702757) 609. DISCUSSION WITH J. P. BHANSALI 1
('66', 404, 2, 3, 702795) [April 8, 1935] 2
('66', 404, 3, 4, 702813) GANDHIJI: Does this diet suit you?
('66', 404, 4, 5, 702848) BHANSALI: Quite.

('66', 413, 4, 12, 716665) If so, you must satisfy your craving.
('66', 413, 4, 13, 716703) You can suppress it only when you feel a strong aversion to worldly pleasures.
('66', 413, 4, 14, 716782) My difficulty is this.
('66', 413, 4, 15, 716805) How can I, who have always advocated renunciation of sex, encourage you to gratify it?
('66', 413, 4, 16, 716892) How can I help you to do so?
('66', 413, 4, 17, 716921) I can tolerate your remarrying.
('66', 413, 4, 18, 716953) But how can you carry on your search for a wife while staying with me?
('66', 413, 4, 19, 717024) If I invited you to come and stay with me, even though I knew your desire to remarry, I did so not with the intention of helping you to get married but with the hope that your staying with me might help your mind to calm down.
('66', 413, 4, 20, 717251) Besides, I also wanted to understand your change of heart.
('66', 413, 4, 21, 717310) I do wish to help you as much as I can.
('66', 413, 4, 22, 717350) But wouldn’t you on your part that I did so only within my limits?
('66', 413, 4, 23, 717417) Think over this andwrite frankly to me now.
('66', 413, 4, 24, 717461) You may say whatever you wish to.
('66', 413, 4, 25, 717495) Are your efforts to give up smoking nearing success, or do you think you will never be able to give it up?
('66', 413, 4, 26, 717602) Do not employ Mirabehn’s labourers in cleaning those buildings or washing the baths.
('66', 413, 4, 27, 717687) Clean whatever you can with your own hands.
('66', 413, 4, 28, 717731) I am not happy about the labourers being employed even in the orchard.

('66', 413, 4, 30, 717857) Avadhesh has informed me of his final decision not to accept the sum of Rs. 15. I felt that day that you were unnecessarily hurting him.
('66', 413, 4, 31, 717994) He had already yielded.
('66', 413, 4, 32, 718018) Where was the need, then, to go on lecturing?

('66', 415, 1, 2, 719555) 631. INTERVIEW TO LORD FARINGDON 1
('66', 415, 2, 3, 719590) [Before April 13, 1935]
('66', 415, 3, 4, 719614) LORD FARINGDON: What is the real object of the Village Industries Associa tion?
('66', 415, 4, 5, 719694) GANDHIJI: To show the people how to turn waste into wealth.
('66', 415, 5, 6, 719754) L. F. How do you propose to achieve it?
('66', 415, 6, 7, 719794) G. By having an army of self effacing workers who will show the people how they can avoid slow starvation.
('66', 415, 6, 8, 719901) There is no other constructive programme before the people.
('66', 415, 7, 9, 719961) L. F. You should need a very large number of workers.
('66', 415, 7, 10, 720015) And how would you be able to get them?
('66', 415, 8, 11, 720054) G. If the moment has come, we shall find the workers.
('66', 415, 9, 12, 720108) L. F. How do you propose to tackle the problem of rural indebtedness?
('66', 415, 10, 13, 720178) G. That we are not dealing with.
('66', 415, 10, 14, 720211) It requires State effort.
('66', 415, 10, 15, 720237) I am just now discovering things people can do without State aid.
('66', 415, 10, 16, 720303) Not that I do not want State aid.
('66', 415, 10, 17, 720337) But I know I cannot get it on my terms.
('66', 415, 11, 18, 720377) Lord Faringdon was anxious to get Gandhiji’s views on the communal question.
('66', 415, 11, 19, 720454) How was it to be solved?
('66', 415, 12, 20, 720479) G. That has just now become insoluble.
('66', 415, 12, 21, 720518) I fear that time alone can solve it.
('66', 415, 12, 22, 720555) If I can persuade the Hindus to give a blank card to the Muslims, the solution can be had today.
('66', 415, 12, 23, 720652) But there is too much mutual distrust to admit of any such heroic solution in the immediate future.

('66', 415, 14, 25, 720771) 632. NO DISAPPOINTMENT
('66', 415, 15, 26, 720794) Har Dayal Nag, probably the oldest leader at work in all India, writes: 2
('66', 415, 16, 27, 720868) I feel disappointed to notice want of sufficient rally round you in the work of your All India Village Industries Association.
('66', 415, 16, 28, 720995) I have been studying the economic aspect of the problem of village industries since the beginning of my public life.
('66', 415, 16, 29, 721112) Your programme does not enthuse me much simply because I miss in it that economic aspect.
('66', 415, 17, 30, 721202) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Notes”.
('66', 415, 17, 31, 721251) Since Gandhiji was observing silence he gave his answers in writing.
('66', 415, 17, 32, 721320) 2 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('66', 416, 0, 1, 721357) VOL. 66 : 16 DECEMBER, 1934 24 APRIL, 1935 417
('66', 416, 1, 2, 721404) Imagine for a while that India is flooded with cottage made goods; but manufacture of goods without consumers or purchasers is nothing but a loss.
('66', 416, 1, 3, 721551) The hand loom can produce khaddar but it cannot produce its buyer.
('66', 416, 1, 4, 721618) My painful experience is that many of those who spin do not wear any cloth made out of their self spun.
('66', 416, 1, 5, 721722) The gur producer may taste a bit of it for the sake of lip loyalty to the country, but will he mix it with his tea or milk?
('66', 416, 1, 6, 721846) Will the owner of a village shoe factory use rough shoes of his own factory in preference to fine pleasurable cheap imported shoes?
('66', 416, 1, 7, 721978) The Indian cottagers will never eschew foreign goods unless and until they are taught to learn that no foreign goods can be cheaper than the goods which they can produce with their own raw materials and spare labour and for their own use.
('66', 416, 1, 8, 722217) Har Dayalbabu has earned his rest, and no one will complain if he retires from all public work.
('66', 416, 1, 9, 722313) But like his three competitors, Pandit Malaviyaji, Abbas Tyabji and Vijayaraghavachariar, he insists on working.
('66', 416, 1, 10, 722426) He can, therefore, expect no indulgence from critics on the ground of age.
('66', 416, 1, 11, 722501) I know he wants none.
('66', 416, 1, 12, 722523) His body and his intellect remain unimpaired and are ever at the disposal of the nation.
('66', 416, 1, 13, 722612) Let me then tell him that those who are actually working have no sense of disappointment.
('66', 416, 1, 14, 722702) The ground is so new that it takes long to prepare.
('66', 416, 1, 15, 722754) The workers are not able to cope with what they have on their hands.
('66', 416, 1, 16, 722823) I suggest then that Har Dayalbabu has the sense of disappointment for the very reason he has given.
('66', 416, 1, 17, 722923) He pleads guilty to the charge of neglect of duty.
('66', 416, 1, 18, 722974) If he had, as is his wont, taken up thework, he would no doubt have found it very difficult but he would certainly not have been disappointed.
('66', 416, 1, 19, 723117) He misses the economic aspect because he has not worked to see it.
('66', 416, 1, 20, 723184) Having been immersed in Harijan work, I discovered that if India was not to perish, we had to begin with the lowest rung of the ladder.
('66', 416, 1, 21, 723320) If that was rotten, all work done at the top or at the intermediate rungs was bound ultimately to fail.
('66', 416, 1, 22, 723424) There is more than the economic aspect in the programme before the country.
('66', 416, 1, 23, 723500) To provide nourishing food for the nation in the manner sketched in the programme is to give it both money and health.
('66', 416, 1, 24, 723619) For the villagers to pound their own rice and eat it unpolished whole, means saving at least thirty crores of rupees per year and promoting health.
('66', 416, 1, 25, 723767) But the tragedy of it is that we have no such thing as unpolished whole rice to be had in the ordinary bazaar.
('66', 416, 1, 26, 723878) And the Association has to wait some days before it can give a clear lead to the
('66', 417, 0, 1, 723959) 418 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('66', 417, 1, 2, 724001) nation.
('66', 417, 1, 3, 724009) The nation requires education as to the food to be taken and the manner in which it has to be prepared.
('66', 417, 1, 4, 724113) This is no programme of preparing shoddy goods in the villages and forcing them on unwilling buyers.
('66', 417, 1, 5, 724214) There is to be no competition, foredoomed to failure, with foreign or swadeshi corresponding articles.
('66', 417, 1, 6, 724317) The villagers are to be their own buyers.
('66', 417, 1, 7, 724359) They will primarily consume what they produce.
('66', 417, 1, 8, 724406) For they are ninety per cent of the population.
('66', 417, 1, 9, 724454) They will manufacture for the cities what the latter want and what they can usefully manufacture.
('66', 417, 1, 10, 724552) Most undoubtedly people will be advised to use gur for their milk and tea.
('66', 417, 1, 11, 724627) They will be told, as they are being told, that it is a superstition to think that gur taken in milk or tea is injurious to health.
('66', 417, 1, 12, 724759) One correspondent says that on his wife beginning to take gur with her tea instead of sugar she lost her constipation.
('66', 417, 1, 13, 724878) I am not surprised, because gur has a mild laxative effect which sugar certainly has not.
('66', 417, 1, 14, 724968) The middle class people have exploited the villages.
('66', 417, 1, 15, 725021) Some of them are now making reparation by making them realize their dignity and importance in the national evolution.
('66', 417, 1, 16, 725139) Then take the question of sanitation.
('66', 417, 1, 17, 725177) Proper attention to it gives the country two rupees per year per head.
('66', 417, 1, 18, 725248) That means sixty crores of rupees per annum in addition to better health and greater efficiency.
('66', 417, 1, 19, 725345) The present programme is the foundation of an all round improvement in the tottering condition of the seven lacs of India’s villages.
('66', 417, 1, 20, 725479) It is work that is long overdue.
('66', 417, 1, 21, 725512) It has to be done, no matter what India’s political condition is.
('66', 417, 1, 22, 725578) It includes every class of villagers from the scavenger to the sowcar.
('66', 417, 1, 23, 725649) It is work in which all partiescan whole heartedly join.
('66', 417, 1, 24, 725706) Its future is assured if a supply of workers can be assured.
('66', 417, 2, 25, 725767) Harijan, 13 4 1935
('66', 417, 3, 26, 725786) 633. HARIJANS AND PIGS
('66', 417, 4, 27, 725809) Seth Achalsingh of Agra wrote to me two months ago a letter describing a scene he had witnessed for the first time in his life.
('66', 417, 4, 28, 725937) He had seen pigs, with their mouths gagged, being roasted alive by Harijans.
('66', 417, 4, 29, 726014) I was horrified by the description.
('66', 417, 4, 30, 726050) But I know that pigs are used as food by Sikhs, and also by thousands of Hindus in Andhra Desha.
('66', 417, 4, 31, 726147) It is possible that pig flesh is eaten in the other parts of India by non Harijans.
('66', 417, 4, 32, 726231) The only thing that can be said with certainty is that, apart from vegetarians, Mussalmans alone never eat pig’s flesh.
('66', 418, 0, 1, 726351) VOL. 66 : 16 DECEMBER, 1934 24 APRIL, 1935 419
('66', 418, 1, 2, 726398) Co workers in Wardha, who have been eyewitnesses, tell me that humaner people suffocate pigs to death and immediately proceed to roast them whole.
('66', 418, 1, 3, 726545) Those who are devoid altogether of the humane instinct roast them alive.
('66', 418, 1, 4, 726618) A party, armed with powerful lathis, surrounds the fire to which the poor animal is consigned, and hits him with lathis as, writhing in pain, he is trying to run out of the burning fire.
('66', 418, 1, 5, 726805) Here is the reply received from Sjt.
('66', 418, 1, 6, 726842) Bapineedu to whom I referred for information as to the practice in Andhra.
('66', 418, 2, 7, 726917) “In killing pigs, various methods are adopted in various places of Andhra, but all the methods are extremely cruel.
('66', 418, 2, 8, 727033) They are as follows:
('66', 418, 3, 9, 727054) 1. A pig is caught, and its legs are tied fast with a long rope.
('66', 418, 3, 10, 727119) Then another cord is tied very tightly round its mouth above the nostrils.
('66', 418, 3, 11, 727194) This disables the animal from breathing, and it dies after some time due to asphyxiation.
('66', 418, 3, 12, 727284) This method is most common.
('66', 418, 4, 13, 727312) 2. As stated in the former paragraph the animal’s legs are tied fast, and, instead of tying another cord round its mouth, it is submerged in water, and allowed to die of drowning.
('66', 418, 5, 14, 727492) 3. A third method is to tie its legs, and to pierce it with a spear and hold it thus till it dies.
('66', 418, 5, 15, 727591) The pig, being a very sturdy animal, does not die easily, and suffers for a long time.
('66', 418, 6, 16, 727678) 4. Another method is that its forelegs and hind legs are tied separately and two persons hold them tightly after laying the pig upside down.
('66', 418, 6, 17, 727819) A third man then beats it to death by dealing blows on its chest.
('66', 418, 6, 18, 727885) The animal suffers much more terribly in this case than in the previous cases.
('66', 418, 7, 19, 727964) I am also informed that nowadays some people shoot it with a gun, but it is very rare.
('66', 418, 8, 20, 728051) Harijans eat pork rather rarely on account of its being dear.
('66', 418, 8, 21, 728113) But it is an indispensable item on the menu on festive occasions.
('66', 418, 8, 22, 728179) In some places, Harijans purchase them at a very young age, and rear them till they are fit to be slaughtered.
('66', 418, 8, 23, 728290) Then the whole village combines itself, and purchases the animal from the owner.
('66', 418, 8, 24, 728371) After it is killed, it is shared among the whole village, its cost being borne by them equally.”
('66', 418, 9, 25, 728468) Bapineedu supplements his letter with an American bulletin entitled “We can kill a hog”.
('66', 418, 9, 26, 728557) I had to perform the painful task of reading the bulletin containing for me the most repelling description of how pigs are killed for meat.
('66', 418, 9, 27, 728697) There is not much to choose in the methods described above.
('66', 418, 9, 28, 728757) If one is to consider the degrees of cruelty, the pig seems to require the most cruelty before it can be killed.
('66', 418, 9, 29, 728870) My purpose in writing this is to show that Harijans are the least offenders in this matter, not, I admit, from choice but from sheer necessity.
('66', 419, 0, 1, 729014) 420 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('66', 419, 1, 2, 729056) question raised by Seth Achalsingh therefore resloves itself into one not of Harijan reform but of broad humanitarian reform.
('66', 419, 1, 3, 729182) We must not take up any stick that comes our way to beat the poor Harijan with.
('66', 419, 1, 4, 729262) But the reform is not the less urgent because it does not specially concern Harijans.
('66', 419, 1, 5, 729348) If our sense of right and wrong had not become blunt, we would recognize that animals had rights, no less than men.
('66', 419, 1, 6, 729464) This education of the heart is the proper function of humanitarian leagues.
('66', 419, 1, 7, 729540) I know that the lower creation groans under the arrogant lordship of man.
('66', 419, 1, 8, 729614) He counts no cruelty too repulsive when he wants to satisfy his appetite, whether lawful or unlawful.
('66', 419, 2, 9, 729716) Harijan, 13 4 1935
('66', 419, 3, 10, 729735) 634. NOTES
('66', 419, 4, 11, 729746) FULL REPENTANCE
('66', 419, 5, 12, 729762) Some time ago I referred in these columns to the case of a young man from Bahraich who was living on public charity.
('66', 419, 5, 13, 729879) 1 As has already been stated, he returned to me fully repentant.
('66', 419, 5, 14, 729944) He is still at Maganwadi regularly working with us and doing his share of physical labour.
('66', 419, 5, 15, 730035) He will soon earn his fare for going to Bahraich.
('66', 419, 5, 16, 730085) But having found himself in Maganwadi, he does not want to leave as soon as he has earned his fare.
('66', 419, 5, 17, 730185) He proposes to learn something and benefit by his stay in our midst.
('66', 419, 5, 18, 730254) His friends in Bahraich have been pained over the criticism of his conduct.
('66', 419, 5, 19, 730330) Avadhesh, for that is the young man’s name, admits the justness of my criticism though he says in extenuation that he had no guilty conscience when he was travelling and living on charity as, he says, is the custom among Ramanujis.
('66', 419, 5, 20, 730562) But now that he has discovered his error, he promises never to repeat it.
('66', 419, 5, 21, 730636) He has thus turned the error to good account and purged himself of any stigma that might have been brought on him by my criticism.
('66', 419, 5, 22, 730767) It is to be wished that many others, who like Avadhesh are living on charity, will profit by his example and like him turn over a new leaf of the book of life.
('66', 419, 5, 23, 730927) To err is human; it is noble after discovery to correct the error and determine never to repeat it.
('66', 419, 6, 24, 731027) A RESULT OF UNTOUCHABILITY
('66', 419, 7, 25, 731054) The readers of Harijan are familiar with the story of the
('66', 419, 8, 26, 731112) 1 Vide “Notes”, 1 3 1935, sub title “A Shame”
('66', 420, 0, 1, 731158) VOL. 66 : 16 DECEMBER, 1934 24 APRIL, 1935 421
('66', 420, 1, 2, 731205) persecutions of Harijans by Nattars in Karaikudi.
('66', 420, 1, 3, 731255) Now comes a similar story from Rajputana.
('66', 420, 1, 4, 731297) Khudi is a little village attached to Sikar, an understate to Jaipur.
('66', 420, 1, 5, 731367) The letters that have come to me allege that on 28th March last a horde of Rajputs surrounded a marriage party of Jats and delivered a terrible lathi charge on the defenceless Jats for their effrontery in taking the bridegroom in procession on horseback.
('66', 420, 1, 6, 731622) The custom in this part of the world seems to have been that the Jats should not on ceremonial occasions make use of elephants or horses.
('66', 420, 1, 7, 731760) It was believed that the matter was adjusted between the rival parties and that the Jats could make use of these animals for riding on any occasion.
('66', 420, 1, 8, 731909) But events seem to have shown that whosoever made the pact could not compel its observance by the Rajputs as a whole.
('66', 420, 1, 9, 732027) It is said that the charge was preceded by the premeditated murder of a Jat.
('66', 420, 1, 10, 732104) Over 40 persons are reported to have been seriously injured during the charge, one of the victims having succumbed to the injuries.
('66', 420, 1, 11, 732236) Let us hope that the State authorities will carry on full investigation into the matter and afford due protection to the poor Jats in the exercise of rights common to all humanity.
('66', 420, 1, 12, 732417) What concerns us here is the fact that this senseless persecution is a direct result of untouchability—the belief that God has created beings of whom some are superior to others, so much so that in the extreme limit the inferior beings become untouchable or even unseeable.
('66', 420, 1, 13, 732691) The alleged persecution of the Jats of Khudi is a species of untouchability different only in degree from the form familiar to the readers of Harijan.
('66', 420, 1, 14, 732842) If we succeed in dealing with the extreme form, the rest will certainly disappear.
('66', 420, 1, 15, 732925) It is therefore necessary to deal with the fiend in a summary and most expeditious manner.
('66', 420, 2, 16, 733016) A REWARD OF SERVICE
('66', 420, 3, 17, 733036) A worker of Darbhanga writes:
('66', 420, 4, 18, 733066) During the Holi holidays I went to my village.
('66', 420, 4, 19, 733113) Finding the streets very dirty, I thought I would clean them, and accordingly I invited the young men to turn the holiday to good account by helping me to clean up the dirt.
('66', 420, 4, 20, 733287) About thirty of them responded.
('66', 420, 4, 21, 733319) Shovels in hand we worked for four hours, gathered the dirt and buried it in a pit.
('66', 420, 4, 22, 733403) We thought we had done a good day’s work.
('66', 420, 4, 23, 733445) Not so thought the village elders.
('66', 420, 4, 24, 733480) They thought that we had degraded ourselves by becoming scavengers—untouchables of the worst type.
('66', 420, 4, 25, 733579) So they met and pronounced an order of excommunication against all who had done the work.
('66', 420, 4, 26, 733669) I am glad to say that the young men are not frightened.
('66', 421, 0, 1, 733725) 422 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('66', 421, 1, 2, 733767) This worker and his young helpers deserve warm congratula tions for their very meritorious service.
('66', 421, 1, 3, 733867) The order of excommunication shows with what ignorance reformers have to deal.
('66', 421, 1, 4, 733946) The only way to bear down the opposition is on the one hand not to resent persecution and on the other to persevere in the service regardless of personal consequences.
('66', 421, 1, 5, 734114) Workers may be sure that if they preserve their equanimity and continue the service, those who are cursing them today will be blessing them tomorrow when they realize what a precious and noble service scavenging is.
('66', 421, 1, 6, 734330) It will presently come to be regarded as a service of the highest order.
('66', 421, 2, 7, 734403) ABOUT NIGHT SOIL PITS
('66', 421, 3, 8, 734425) A correspondent asks:
('66', 421, 4, 9, 734447) 1. what is the length of time that should lapse before a pit one foot deep could be dug in the same place for a second time, for evacuation?
('66', 421, 4, 10, 734588) 2. Usually fields are ploughed immediately after paddy is sown.
('66', 421, 4, 11, 734652) If night soil is buried in the fields about a week prior to sowing, will it not come up to the surface when the field is ploughed and thus contaminate the feet of the workmen and of the bulls?
('66', 421, 4, 12, 734845) (1) When superficial burial takes place, according to Poore’s formula, seeds may be safely sown after a fortnight’s at the most.
('66', 421, 4, 13, 734974) The same soil will used for further burial after a year’s use.
('66', 421, 4, 14, 735037) (2) The question of soiling the feet, whether of human beings or of cattle can never arise, as nothing can or should be sown without the night soil being turned into good sweet smelling manure, which one handles freely without any hesitation.
('66', 421, 5, 15, 735280) Harijan, 13 4 1935
('66', 421, 6, 16, 735299) 635. SILENT WORK
('66', 421, 7, 17, 735316) Jayaramdas, an old Ashram inmate from Ceylon, through whom I have endeavoured to keep myself somewhat in touch with the recent outbreak of virulent malaria in Ceylon, writes: 1
('66', 421, 8, 18, 735493) I am glad to be able to state that the epidemic is now on the wane and we have closed 6 out of the 11 convalescent homes.
('66', 421, 8, 19, 735615) The following number of patients have been attended to by us without a single casualty.
('66', 421, 9, 20, 735703) 1 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('66', 421, 9, 21, 735740) 2 The table is not reproduced.
('66', 421, 9, 22, 735771) 1896 patients were admitted, 1729 were cured and released 167 were still under treatment.
('66', 422, 0, 1, 735861) VOL. 66 : 16 DECEMBER, 1934 24 APRIL, 1935 423
('66', 422, 1, 2, 735908) The number of volunteers now working is 85 composed of 21 Bhikkus and 64 laymen; besides we have 12 Bhikkus and 78 laymen as helpers.

('66', 422, 2, 17, 737165) An object lesson is being taught us by Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel who has just now buried himself in Borsad where plague has broken out.
('66', 422, 2, 18, 737300) Assisted by Dr. Bhasker Patel and a band of volunteers, he is giving medical aid to those in need.
('66', 422, 2, 19, 737399) But his enduring work consists in doing scavenging work.
('66', 422, 2, 20, 737456) One by one, he is cleaning, theinfected villages; he is bringing people out of their dark houses and inducing them to live in the open, in their fields, while he is opening out roofs and letting in light, sunshine and air, removing debris, clearing out filth, disinfecting insanitary places and destroying vermin.
('66', 422, 2, 21, 737770) He is flooding the villagers with crisply written leaflets giving them instruction in preventive measures.
('66', 422, 2, 22, 737877) He has made no appeal for funds or volunteers.
('66', 422, 2, 23, 737924) Volunteers have been recruited locally.
('66', 422, 2, 24, 737964) All villages are not plague infected.

('66', 434, 9, 25, 754044) 659. LETTER TO PREMABEHN KANTAK
('66', 434, 10, 26, 754076) April 18, 1935
('66', 434, 11, 27, 754091) PREMA, Today is the last day of my silence.
('66', 434, 11, 28, 754135) During this period I disposed of considerable arrears of work.
('66', 434, 11, 29, 754198) I got your letter only today.
('66', 434, 11, 30, 754228) What you say about your coming here is correct.
('66', 434, 11, 31, 754276) Do I force anybody to eat rice, jaggery, onions, etc.?
('66', 434, 11, 32, 754331) I only point out the virtues and defects of the things people eat.
('66', 434, 11, 33, 754398) I consume tamarind when eating uncooked vegetables.
('66', 434, 11, 34, 754450) I soak it in water and squeeze out the nutritive elements in it.
('66', 434, 11, 35, 754515) Even raw vegetables I have to get crushed before eating.
('66', 434, 11, 36, 754572) Onion occupies an important place in the diet of the village
('66', 435, 0, 1, 754633) 436 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('66', 435, 1, 2, 754675) people.
('66', 435, 1, 3, 754683) It is the one vegetable that is of inestimable value for them.
('66', 435, 1, 4, 754746) While it is present in their diet, they don’t very much need ghee, etc.
('66', 435, 1, 5, 754818) I, therefore, have included it in our food on an experimental basis.
('66', 435, 1, 6, 754887) Those who like eat it.
('66', 435, 1, 7, 754910) I have indeed revised my view about onions to this extent, that those who eat them as medicine will not find them an obstacle to the practice of brahmacharya.
('66', 435, 1, 8, 755069) I have no evidence for this, however.

('66', 438, 1, 2, 758460) 667. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('66', 438, 2, 3, 758492) April 19, 1935
('66', 438, 3, 4, 758507) My silence 2 was taken just with a view to clearing off heavy arrears, but I now see that that was but one of the many good things I have got out of it.
('66', 438, 3, 5, 758660) As I do nothing except with an ultimate spiritual end in view, this silence obviously carried with it its spiritual advantage.
('66', 438, 3, 6, 758787) Silence is essential for one whose life is an incessant search for truth.
('66', 438, 3, 7, 758861) But such silence is a much more serious affair than this.
('66', 438, 3, 8, 758919) Even writing as a means of communication must stop.
('66', 438, 3, 9, 758971) Truth would speak, if it must, in every act and not through the written word.
('66', 438, 3, 10, 759049) I had a letter the other day from Vinoba who wrote in connection with the slivers which Bhau had made for me and which I had warmly praised.
('66', 438, 3, 11, 759190) Vinoba wrote: “Bhau of course deserves all the praise you have given him, but I want your slivers to be still better.
('66', 438, 3, 12, 759308) The cotton that he has used is not unbaled cotton.
('66', 438, 3, 13, 759359) You should use no other cotton.
('66', 438, 3, 14, 759391) It will have an effect all its own.” I had a sure proof of this some days ago when Nanibehn, who had gone to Nanded to study the processes of fine spinning, came here and gave me some of her specially prepared slivers from unpressed cotton.
('66', 438, 3, 15, 759632) When I tried these, the difference was great.
('66', 438, 3, 16, 759678) The thread did not break at all.
('66', 438, 3, 17, 759711) Not that I spun with extra care, but the cotton had been cleaned and carded with exquisite care.
('66', 438, 3, 18, 759808) I am trying to show what care truth requires and that action is more eloquent than speech.
('66', 438, 3, 19, 759899) Some years ago in Calcutta I contented myself with telling my auidence that they must listen to the silent speech of my fingers which were plying the takli.
('66', 438, 3, 20, 760056) There is another merit in silence which these four weeks demonstrated to me unmistakably.
('66', 438, 3, 21, 760146) I am prone to anger like anyone else, but I can successfully suppress it.
('66', 438, 3, 22, 760220) Well, I found out that silence helps one to suppress one’s anger as perhaps nothing else does.
('66', 438, 3, 23, 760315) How is one to give vent to one’s wrath if one is silent?
('66', 438, 3, 24, 760372) Not by eyes.
('66', 438, 3, 25, 760385) Surely not by physical violence, when one is pledged to non violence.
('66', 438, 3, 26, 760455) Not by writing, for the wrath would disappear in the very process of writing.
('66', 438, 3, 27, 760533) There are a number of other uses of silence that I could mention, but these should suffice.
('66', 438, 3, 28, 760625) Let me tell you that I was not
('66', 438, 4, 29, 760656) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Notes” 2 Gandhiji had been on four weeks’ silence from March 22 and had just broken it.

('66', 439, 1, 2, 760827) looking forward to the termination of this silence.
('66', 439, 1, 3, 760879) I was dreading it, and I should often like to go into silence, if not quite for a month or months, at least for brief periods.

('66', 439, 7, 10, 761231) 669. DISCUSSION WITH J. P. BHANSALI 2
('66', 439, 8, 11, 761269) [Before April 20, 1935] 3
('66', 439, 9, 12, 761295) GANDHIJI: As you sit in your meditation, are you troubled by extraneous thoughts?
('66', 439, 10, 13, 761377) BHANSALI: No, never.
('66', 439, 11, 14, 761398) G. Never during the day?
('66', 439, 12, 15, 761423) B. Not so.
('66', 439, 12, 16, 761434) Whilst I am not engaged in my meditation, I think of the talks we are having, and I put your questions to myself again and again.
('66', 439, 13, 17, 761564) G. You do.
('66', 439, 13, 18, 761575) Well, then, you said the other day that when you see all the surrounding misery, you are considerably agitated.
('66', 439, 13, 19, 761687) Don’t you feel like doing your little bit to lessen it?
('66', 439, 14, 20, 761743) B. No, though it may seem strange.
('66', 439, 15, 21, 761778) G. But, then, what is the meaning of being agitated?
('66', 439, 16, 22, 761831) B. I feel the misery myself, but also feel that I am powerless to do anything.
('66', 439, 17, 23, 761910) G. When a thorn pierces your foot, you pull it out, don’t you?
('66', 439, 18, 24, 761973) B. Yes.
('66', 439, 19, 25, 761981) G. When you feel hungry, you eat, don’t you?
('66', 439, 20, 26, 762026) B. I do.
('66', 439, 21, 27, 762035) 1 The report in the source is dated April 20. 2 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Letter” 3 In the manuscript of Mahadev Desai’s Diary this is reported under April 10.
