('66', 441, 5, 11, 764835) Of course I should love to trudge about like you from one end of the country to the other; and, if my body allowed it, I should like to live on uncooked flour and neem leaves.
('66', 441, 5, 12, 765011) But I find there is a serious flaw in your way of life.
('66', 441, 5, 13, 765067) As a seeker after truth, if I find that yours is the true way, it would be my duty to adopt it.
('66', 441, 5, 14, 765163) On the other hand, if I feel that there is some serious error in it, it is my duty to draw your attention to it.
('66', 441, 5, 15, 765276) As I have told you I have no quarrel with your flour or with your neem leaves.
('66', 441, 5, 16, 765355) What I cannot understand is that you should ignore a vital condition of our very existence, I mean the principle of sacrifice with which we are born.
('66', 441, 6, 17, 765505) B. I should like you to make this a little clearer.
('66', 441, 7, 18, 765557) G. You know that the Gita says that he who eats without offering the daily sacrifice steals his food.

('66', 441, 8, 22, 765826) I wondered if I had any right to eat my flour and neem leaves, as I did no work.
('66', 441, 9, 23, 765907) G. Yes, you have heard it.
('66', 441, 9, 24, 765934) But the world accepts the principle and acts up to it, e.g., Jain munis and sannyasis.
('66', 441, 9, 25, 766021) They live on alms, but they do so because they persuade themselves that they are offering sufficient sacrifice in the shape of the teaching they impart.

('66', 442, 10, 25, 767926) 670. WAGES OF SIN
('66', 442, 11, 26, 767944) ‘The wages of sin is death,’ says the Bible.
('66', 442, 11, 27, 767989) That by reason of our sin of untouchability we are daily courting economic death is exemplified by a letter received from a correspondent in Rajputana.
('66', 442, 11, 28, 768141) In a Hindi letter he says in substance:
('66', 442, 12, 29, 768181) “Here, in our parts, wherever I look I find bones of animals strewing the paths.
('66', 442, 12, 30, 768262) No one cares to collect them.
('66', 442, 12, 31, 768292) Village surroundings therefore look like neglected crematoria.
('66', 442, 12, 32, 768355) Dogs make worse what is already so bad.
('66', 442, 12, 33, 768395) You have written now and again on this subject in the pages of Harijan.
('66', 442, 12, 34, 768467) Will you not give summary instructions for guiding Harijan, and even village workers?
('66', 442, 12, 35, 768553) It will be useless if you advise us to send the bones to some bonegrinding mill; for the expense would be prohibitive.
('66', 442, 12, 36, 768672) Then you have to consider the religious prejudice against the use of articles made of bones, etc.” The waste that is going on in this country is truly terrific.
('66', 442, 12, 37, 768833) If, however, an economist were to work out figures of waste caused by
('66', 443, 0, 1, 768903) 444 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('66', 443, 1, 2, 768945) the curse of untouchability, they will be staggering.
('66', 443, 1, 3, 768999) The wages we are paying for the luxury of committing the sin of untouchability will comfortably feed the starving millions.
('66', 443, 1, 4, 769123) It is no small waste deliberately to stunt the mental and moral growth, and to make the least economic use, of one sixth of the population of India.
('66', 443, 1, 5, 769272) But to state the problem in such large terms baffles one.
('66', 443, 1, 6, 769330) For workers who need not think in terms of millions, either of money or men, it is simple enough.
('66', 443, 1, 7, 769428) Religious values have to change.
('66', 443, 1, 8, 769461) In a country like India, where animal life is held sacred, we must learn to regard as sacred the use, other than for food, of all parts of naturally dead animals.
('66', 443, 1, 9, 769624) Harijan workers I regard as having advanced to the position here set forth.
('66', 443, 1, 10, 769700) If they have, they would collect all the bones they thus see strewn about on village paths and put them by till they receive further instructions.
('66', 443, 1, 11, 769847) I am trying to find out easy methods of grinding bones to powder.
('66', 443, 1, 12, 769913) To turn them into manure seems to me to be the cheapest method of disposal.
('66', 443, 1, 13, 769989) Experiments are being made by Satisbabu of Khadi Pratisthan to find out the best way open to villagers of making the most economic use of all parts of carcasses.
('66', 443, 1, 14, 770151) I hope to acquaint the readers of Harijan with the result of Satisbabu’s researches.
('66', 443, 2, 15, 770236) Harijan, 20 4 1935
('66', 443, 3, 16, 770255) 671. A WORKING SUB COMMITTEE
('66', 443, 4, 17, 770284) Most committees or sub committees are appointed to make investigations.
('66', 443, 4, 18, 770356) But I have come across a sub committee that was appointed to take prompt action.
('66', 443, 4, 19, 770437) A. A. Paul, the Hon.
('66', 443, 4, 20, 770458) General Secretary of the Federation of International Fellowships, sends me a report of a sub committee appointed by the Federation to deal with rural indebtedness in a confined area in Karnataka.
('66', 443, 4, 21, 770654) From the report of the sub committee I take the following interesting particulars: 1
('66', 443, 5, 22, 770739) The extortion evil is like the weather; everybody talks about it, but nobody does anything about it.
('66', 443, 5, 23, 770840) Eight months ago our International Fellowship awoke to the menace of this evil to the life of our under privileged village brethren.
('66', 443, 5, 24, 770973) This is not to say that this menace is peculiar to the villages, but due to the generally defenceless position of the villager, with the ranks of privilege arrayed against him, he is especially victimized.
('66', 443, 5, 25, 771179) Our attention was directed to a certain village which had a vicious nest of extortioners.
('66', 443, 5, 26, 771269) The chief
('66', 443, 6, 27, 771279) 1 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('66', 444, 0, 1, 771316) VOL. 66 : 16 DECEMBER, 1934 24 APRIL, 1935 445
('66', 444, 1, 2, 771363) one had come there with next to nothing a few years ago and now owned the only storied building in the place, with almost everybody in his debt.
('66', 444, 1, 3, 771508) His prevailing rate of interest was 75% per annum.
('66', 444, 1, 4, 771559) Roving Pathans extorted up to 300%.
('66', 444, 2, 5, 771595) Finally, a committee was appointed with two leaders, one a Muslim and the other a Hindu, volunteering to serve.
('66', 444, 2, 6, 771707) The next step was to get from one of our Matric students, resident in the village, a long list of debtors; with particulars of their debts.
('66', 444, 2, 7, 771847) After studying this, our committee visited the village and questioned each debtor.
('66', 444, 2, 8, 771930) In the case of those whose testimony at their own risk showed that they had paid back the principal plus a decent rate of interest, our pleader members served a free legal notice on their behalf, acknowledging no further debt.
('66', 444, 2, 9, 772157) At the same time, the debtors stopped payments.
('66', 444, 2, 10, 772205) About fifty such notices were served in course of time.
('66', 444, 2, 11, 772261) The movement of rebellion spread to other villages, even without the process of legal notice.
('66', 444, 2, 12, 772355) We found it necessary to send a carefully written note of warning to the Police Sub Inspector as well as the money lender, enclosing the annual report of our Fellowship, which gave a more or less imposing array of names of members.
('66', 444, 3, 13, 772587) During the last eight months approximately a hundred debtors have been relieved, and thousands of rupees turned into the building of their families.
('66', 444, 4, 14, 772736) After prejudicing their cases by not replying to the legal notice for six months, the extortioners have at last filed three or four suits.
('66', 444, 4, 15, 772875) But they are at a great disadvantage, as the evidence at hand shows, in the fact of their high handed and careless methods of doing business.
('66', 444, 5, 16, 773017) The latest development, and the most encouraging one in view of the initial apathy, is the fact that a formerly sceptical pleader friend is quietly getting together a group of the more idealistic young pleaders for the formation of a Legal Aid Society.
('66', 444, 5, 17, 773270) He has a vision of taking such pleaders (who ordinarily rot around the bar room waiting for touts to stir up a case) to the surrounding villages where, through various means of propaganda, they will awaken the villagers, especially the debtors, to their legal rights, and offer them very reasonable and incorruptible legal aid.
('66', 444, 5, 18, 773598) This is, happily, in line with Gandhiji’s recent call to village reconstruction.
('66', 444, 5, 19, 773679) It is our conviction that the vigilance on the part of the privileged classes, such as those who compose our International Fellowship, is the price of liberty for these victims of extortion.
('66', 444, 5, 20, 773870) This is an example to copy.
('66', 444, 5, 21, 773898) No capital expenditure was required here.
('66', 444, 5, 22, 773940) All that was evidently necessary was to hearten thevillagers and tell their creditors (while such was the case) that most of them had paid more than was due by them.
('66', 444, 5, 23, 774106) Harijan, 20 4 1935

('66', 445, 1, 2, 774167) 672. SELF SUSTAINED KHADI
('66', 445, 2, 3, 774193) Mysore has always appreciated the worth of hand spinning as an aid to the farmer.
('66', 445, 2, 4, 774275) It runs several such centres.
('66', 445, 2, 5, 774305) The managers keep themselves in touch with the A. I. S. A. so as to keep their centres abreast of the latest researches and improvements made by the Association.
('66', 445, 2, 6, 774467) The following letter from the Badanval Spinning Circle addressed to the Secretary, A. I. S. A., will be read with interest:
('66', 445, 3, 7, 774591) I beg to inform you that Government sanction was received to pursue a policy of developing local market: and for popularizing khadi in villages.
('66', 445, 3, 8, 774736) This was in accordance with the new policy which was followed to keep pace with the changes introduced by the A.I.S.A. Khadi cloth is given at cost price to bonafide weavers and spinners of this Circle.
('66', 445, 3, 9, 774939) Since the month of November, 1934, work was started in this direction.
('66', 445, 3, 10, 775010) Till now we have sold just over Rs. 2,000 worth of khadi to about a thousand spinners.
('66', 445, 3, 11, 775097) We issue cloth and recover the value thereof in weekly instalments at the time of yarn purchase.
('66', 445, 3, 12, 775194) From April onwards, we propose to launch the sales again.
('66', 445, 3, 13, 775252) Our aim is to sell another Rs. 2,000 worth of khadi, this time mainly consisting of village sarees.
('66', 445, 3, 14, 775352) We find that the programme is working quite normally here.
('66', 445, 3, 15, 775411) Similar encouraging reports are coming from many quarters.
('66', 445, 3, 16, 775470) I would suggest to the workers that now that the true message of khadi has been understood they should take all the steps simultaneously.
('66', 445, 3, 17, 775608) A commencement has to be made with cotton growing with a fair knowledge of the conditions of cotton cultivation.
('66', 445, 3, 18, 775721) It should be possible to grow cotton for village use almost anywhere.
('66', 445, 3, 19, 775791) Concentration in the most favourable soil is necessary when the ambition is to supply the world.
('66', 445, 3, 20, 775888) But the reverse holds good where the ambition is to supply the village need.
('66', 445, 3, 21, 775965) A corner in a field can easily grow rough cotton for the village farmer; or a village may grow cotton for itself in co operation.
('66', 445, 3, 22, 776095) If this is done, it is simple enough to see that no imported cloth can beat cloth thus produced locally, either in cost or durability.
('66', 445, 3, 23, 776230) The process induces the greatest conservation of energy.
('66', 445, 3, 24, 776287) Under such ideal conditions ginning, carding and spinning become pleasurable and simple.
('66', 445, 3, 25, 776376) The spinning wheels, too, require overhauling.
('66', 445, 3, 26, 776423) There is greatwaste of energy when the revolutions of the spindle are not up to the standard.
('66', 445, 3, 27, 776517) With this however, I propose to deal shortly in an article specially devoted to it.

('66', 465, 1, 2, 820606) 685. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, INDORE 1
('66', 465, 2, 3, 820646) April 23, 1935
('66', 465, 3, 4, 820661) The bulk of those who have come here are citizens of Indore.
('66', 465, 3, 5, 820722) There are people from the villages too, but the majority are from Indore.
('66', 465, 3, 6, 820796) You must have seen the exhibition which untimely rain has unfortunately spoilt.
('66', 465, 3, 7, 820876) It was organized in order to remind the city dweller of his duty to the villager.
('66', 465, 3, 8, 820958) We have been oblivious of it all these years, but we can ill afford to be so now.
('66', 465, 3, 9, 821040) We may not know it, but it is certain that we are slowly perishing individually and as a nation.
('66', 465, 3, 10, 821137) It is no use laying the blame at other people’s door—the Government, the State, or the Zemindar.
('66', 465, 3, 11, 821234) They are certainly respons ible for our sorry plight, but we are no less responsible, and we had better bethink ourselves of our responsibility.
('66', 465, 3, 12, 821379) The reason why our average life rate is deplorably low, the reason why we are getting more and more impoverished is that we have neglected our 700,000 villages.
('66', 465, 3, 13, 821540) We have indeed thought of them, but only to the extent of exploiting them.
('66', 465, 3, 14, 821615) We read thrilling accounts of the glory that was India, and of the land that was flowing with milk and honey; but today it is a land of starving millions.
('66', 465, 3, 15, 821770) We are sitting in this fine pandal under a blaze of electric lights, but we do not know that we are burning these lights at the expense of the poor.
('66', 465, 3, 16, 821919) We have no right to use the lights if we forget that we owe these to them.
('66', 465, 3, 17, 821994) There is a difference between the civilization of the East—the civilization of India—and that of the West.
('66', 465, 3, 18, 822101) It is not generally realized wherein the difference lies.
('66', 465, 3, 19, 822159) Our geography is different, our history is different, our ways of living are different.
('66', 465, 3, 20, 822247) Our continent, though vast, is a speck on the globe, but it is the most thickly populated, barring China.
('66', 465, 3, 21, 822353) Well, now, the economics and civilization of a country where the pressure of population on land is greatest are and must be different from those of a country where the pressure is least.
('66', 465, 3, 22, 822540) Sparsely populated America may have need of machinery.
('66', 465, 3, 23, 822595) India may not need it at all.
('66', 465, 3, 24, 822625) Where there are millions upon millions of units of idle labourit is no use thinking of labour saving devices.
('66', 465, 3, 25, 822735) If someone devised a machine which saved us the trouble of using our hands to

('66', 466, 1, 2, 823102) eat, eating would cease to be a pleasure, it would become a torture.
('66', 466, 1, 3, 823171) The reason of our poverty is the extinction of our industries and our consequent unemployment.
('66', 466, 1, 4, 823266) Some years ago India’s agricultural population was said to be 70 per cent.
('66', 466, 1, 5, 823341) Today it is said to be 90 per cent.
('66', 466, 1, 6, 823377) It does not mean that 90 per cent are agriculturists, but that, instead of 70 per cent who depended on land, 90 per cent are now driven to depend on land.
('66', 466, 1, 7, 823532) In other words, whereas there were industries and crafts enough to feed the 20 per cent some time ago, these are no longer there and the people have thus been thrown on land.
('66', 466, 1, 8, 823707) They thus steal their living, not because they want to, but because there is no more land.
('66', 466, 1, 9, 823798) Not that there is not enough land to feed our 35 crores.
('66', 466, 1, 10, 823855) It is absurd to say that India is overpopulated and that the surplus population must die.
('66', 466, 1, 11, 823945) I am sure that if all the land that is available was properly utilized and made to yield up to its capacity, it would surely maintain the whole population.
('66', 466, 1, 12, 824101) Only we have got to be industrious and to make two blades of grass grow where one grows today.
('66', 466, 1, 13, 824196) The remedy is to identify ourselves with the poor villager and to help him make the land yield its plenty, help him produce what we need, and confine ourselves to use what he produces, live as he lives, and persuade him to take to more rational ways of diet and living.
('66', 466, 1, 14, 824466) We eat mill ground flour, and even the poor villager walks with a head load of half a maund grain to have it ground in the nearest flour mill.
('66', 466, 1, 15, 824609) Do you know that in spite of the plenty of food stuffs we produce, we import wheat from outside and we eat the ‘superfine’ flour from Australia?
('66', 466, 1, 16, 824754) We will not use our hand ground flour, and the poor villager also foolishly copies us.
('66', 466, 1, 17, 824841) We thus turn wealth into waste, nectar into poison.
('66', 466, 1, 18, 824893) For whole meal is the proper meal.
('66', 466, 1, 19, 824928) Mill ground flour is vitaminless flour, mill ground flour kept for days is not only not vitaminless, but poison.
('66', 466, 1, 20, 825041) But we will not exert ourselves to produce flour which we must eat fresh every day, and will pay for less nutritious things and purchase ill health into the bargain.
('66', 466, 1, 21, 825207) This is not any abstruse economic truth, it is a fact which is daily happening before our eyes.
('66', 466, 1, 22, 825303) The same is the case with rice and gur and oil.
('66', 466, 1, 23, 825351) We will eat rice, polished of its substance, and eat less nutritious sugar and pay more for it than more nutritious gur.
('66', 466, 1, 24, 825472) We have suffered thevillage oilman to be driven to extinction and we eat adulterated oils.
('66', 466, 1, 25, 825563) We idolize the cow, but kill her by slow degress.
('66', 466, 1, 26, 825613) We eat honey and kill the honey bee, with the result that honey is such a rare commodity today
('66', 467, 0, 1, 825708) 468 THE COLLECECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('66', 467, 1, 2, 825752) that it is only available to a ‘Mahatma’ like me or to those who must have it from the physician as a vehicle for the drugs he prescribes.
('66', 467, 1, 3, 825891) If we took the trouble of learning scientific and harmless bee keeing, we should get it cheaper and our children would get out of it all the carbohydrates they need.
('66', 467, 1, 4, 826057) In all our dietetics we mistake the shadow for the substance, preferring bone white sugar to rich brown gur and pale white bread to rich brown bran bread.
('66', 467, 1, 5, 826212) We are said to be a nation of daily bathers.
('66', 467, 1, 6, 826257) That we are, to be sure, but we are none the better for it.
('66', 467, 1, 7, 826317) For we bathe with unclean water, we foul our tanks and rivers with filth and use that water for drinking and bath.
('66', 467, 1, 8, 826432) We lawyers and degree holders and doctors will not learn the elementary principles of sanitation and hygiene.
('66', 467, 1, 9, 826542) We have not yet devised the most economic method of disposal of our evacuations and we turn our open healthy spaces into breeding grounds of disease.
('66', 467, 1, 10, 826692) I implore you to throw off your inertia, to bestir yourselves to study these elementary facts and live more rational lives and learn how to turn waste into wealth.
('66', 467, 1, 11, 826856) I have told you simple truths which we would soon realize and act up to if we threw off the inertia of ages.
('66', 467, 1, 12, 826965) But we have shunned body labour to the detriment of our brains, and thus rest content with the irrational way of diet and living.
('66', 467, 1, 13, 827095) Let us pull ourselves together and resolve to make our bodies and brains more active.
('66', 467, 1, 14, 827181) I thank you for the patient attention you have given me.
('66', 467, 2, 15, 827238) Harijan, 11 5 1935
('66', 467, 3, 16, 827257) 686. SPEECH AT MEETING OF GUJARATIS 1
('66', 467, 4, 17, 827295) INDORE, [April 24, 1935] 2
('66', 467, 5, 18, 827322) I am glad that my visit should have been instrumental in the ending of the two factions said to have been existing amongst you.
('66', 467, 5, 19, 827450) But I would now ask you to go a step further.
('66', 467, 5, 20, 827496) You must think of the interests of the area where you earn your living.
('66', 467, 5, 21, 827568) You must not think of sending out the whole of your savings to your families, but should use a portion for the Marathi and Hindi speaking people among
('66', 467, 6, 22, 827719) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s report “Other Functions at Indore”.
('66', 467, 6, 23, 827788) The Gujaratis of Indore had organized a function in Gandhiji’s honour and presented him a purse.
('66', 467, 6, 24, 827885) 2 The date is supplied from Gandhijini Dinwari.
('66', 468, 0, 1, 827933) VOL. 60 : 16 DECEMBER, 1934 24 APRIL, 1935 469
('66', 468, 1, 2, 827980) whom you live.
('66', 468, 1, 3, 827995) It is wrong to think that business is incompatible with ethics.
('66', 468, 1, 4, 828059) I know that it is perfectly possible to carry on one’s business profitably and yet honestly and truthfully.
('66', 468, 1, 5, 828167) The plea that business and ethics never agree is advanced only by those who are actuated by nothing higher than narrow self interest.
('66', 468, 1, 6, 828301) He who will serve his own ends will do so by all kinds of questionable means, but he who will earn to serve the community will never sacrifice truth or honesty.
('66', 468, 1, 7, 828462) You must bear in mind that you have the right to earn as much as you like, but not the right to spend as much as you like.
('66', 468, 1, 8, 828585) Anything that remains after the needs of a decent living are satisfied belongs to the community.
('66', 468, 1, 9, 828682) There should be no Gujarati here who is ignorant of Hindi.
('66', 468, 1, 10, 828741) When I say this I am thinking of women too.
('66', 468, 1, 11, 828785) For they must associate with Hindi speaking women here and give their share in the work of general social uplift.
('66', 468, 2, 12, 828899) The Gujarati Youth League asked for permission to take part in the function by separate speeches.
('66', 468, 2, 13, 828997) To them Gandhiji said: Would it not be better that I give you a couple of minutes than that you take a couple of minutes for speech making?
('66', 468, 2, 14, 829137) Well, I should like to leave you a message of silence.
('66', 468, 2, 15, 829192) Speech without the backing of experience based on action will lack chastity and refinement.
('66', 468, 2, 16, 829284) I would ask you to curb your tongues and make use of your hands and feet forthe service of the community.
('66', 468, 2, 17, 829390) After you have done so for a few years, you will speak the speech that counts and never fails.

('66', 470, 3, 4, 830770) ABSTRACT OF THE PROCEEDINGS OF THE BOARD OF MANAGEMENT OF ALL INDIA VILLAGE INDUSTRIES ASSOCIATION 1
('66', 470, 4, 5, 830871) The following six persons shall be a permanent Board of Trustees, who shall hold funds and properties on behalf of the Association and shall disburse them in accordance with the instructions of the Board of Management, provided, however, that if the said instructions are, in the opinion of the Trustees, in conflict with the object of the Association or with the best interest thereof, there shall be a joint meeting of the Board of Management and the Trustees and that if, in spite of the joint meeting, two thirds of the Trustees disapprove of the instructions of the Board of Management, then such instructions would be deemed to have lapsed:
('66', 470, 5, 6, 831518) (1) Sjt.
('66', 470, 5, 7, 831527) Shrikrishnadas Jaju, Treasurer (Wardha) (2) Sjt.
('66', 470, 5, 8, 831576) J. C. Kumarappa (Wardha) (3) Sjt.
('66', 470, 5, 9, 831610) Jamnalal Bajaj (Wardha) (4) Dr. Khan Saheb (N.W.F.) (5) Mr. Gopichand (Lahore) (6) Sjt.
('66', 470, 5, 10, 831698) Vaikunth L. Mehta (Bombay)
('66', 470, 6, 11, 831725) In the event of a vacancy occurring by reason of resignation, death or otherwise, such vacancy shall be filled in by the remaining Trustees from amongst the ordinary members of five years’ standing or if, at the time of the vacancy occurring, the Association has not been in existence for that period, then from the list of members then in existence and registered on or before the 31st day of March, 1935. 7. The following shall be the Foundation Members and shall also be the first Board of Management to hold office for seven years from this, the 3rd of February 1935, along with such members as may be co opted in the manner hereinafter provided:

('66', 471, 2, 8, 832855) After the expiry of the term of office of the first Board of Management succeeding Boards shall be elected every three years by Ordinary Members of at least three years’ standing from amongst themselves.
('66', 471, 2, 9, 833059) Each member of the Board shall be jointly and severally responsible for the enforcement of the policy of the Association and shall, therefore, be expected, to the best of his ability, when the Board is not in session, to represent it and enforce its policy and programme within his sphere of influence.
('66', 471, 2, 10, 833362) 8. Any persons who subscribes to the pledge hereto annexed, who is recommended by a Member of the Board of Management and whose admission is approved by the said Board, shall be an Ordinary Member of the Association.
('66', 471, 2, 11, 833579) 9. Agents may be selected out of Ordinary Members by the Board for representing it without any pay in a village, villages or district and shall be chosen for their knowledge of the area of their jurisdictions, for their organizing ability and known influence within their area, and shall be subject to the Bye laws defining their duties.
('66', 471, 2, 12, 833917) 10. Honorary workers shall be workers other than Agents or Ordinary Members and shall be approved by a Member of the Board or an Agent.
('66', 471, 2, 13, 834053) Such workers shall perform some tangible service of the Association.
('66', 471, 2, 14, 834122) 11. Paid Workers shall be chosen by the Board or persons duly authorized thereto, subject to the confirmation of the Board, and shall give their whole time and attention to the work of the Association.
('66', 471, 2, 15, 834324) 12. Any person who sympathizes with the object of the Association and pays an annual subscription of not less than Rs. 100 shall be an Associate, and one who pays a lump sum of Rs. 1,000 may be enrolled as a Life Associate.

('66', 471, 3, 19, 834908) AFFILIATION
('66', 471, 4, 20, 834920) The following rules for affiliation were framed and passed: 1. Institutions, which have as one of their objects the promotion of
('66', 472, 0, 1, 835049) VOL.66: 16 DECEMBER, 1934 24 APRIL, 1935 473
('66', 472, 1, 2, 835094) village industries and the welfare of the villagers and in whose constitution and rules there is nothing that is repugnant to the ideals of this Association, may be affiliated on theirundertaking to abide by the rules and regulations framed or to be, from time to time, framed on this behalf by the Board of Management under Bye law No.
('66', 472, 1, 3, 835431) 8. 2. Such affiliated institutions will be subject to the inspection and supervision of this Association.
('66', 472, 1, 4, 835537) 3. Every three months, they shall submit a report of work done during that period.
('66', 472, 1, 5, 835620) 4. Affiliation fees will not be less than Rs. 12 per year.
('66', 472, 1, 6, 835679) 5. Such affiliated institutions will be entitled to receive free copies of all literature published by this Association, and advice and guidance whenever sought.
('66', 472, 2, 7, 835841) CERTIFICATION
('66', 472, 3, 8, 835855) The following rules for certification were framed and passed: 1. The institutions and persons, who are prepared to deal in village manufactures coming within the province of this Association and who undertake to abide by the Rules and Regulations framed or to be, from time to time, framed on this behalf by the Board of Management may be certified.
('66', 472, 3, 9, 836205) 2. Such certified organizations will be subject to the inspection and supervision of this Association and shall furnish from time to time such information as may be received by the Central Office in regard to their dealings periodically when called upon to do so.
('66', 472, 3, 10, 836469) Officers and employees of certified institutions and certified dealers will be expected to live up to the ideal of the All India Village Industries Association.
('66', 472, 3, 11, 836630) 3. They shall pay such fees as may be prescribed by the Board or any one authorized by the Board for the purpose.
('66', 472, 3, 12, 836744) 4. Such organizations will be entitled to receive free copies of all literature published by this Association, and advice and guidance whenever sought.
('66', 472, 4, 13, 836896) MISCELLANEOUS
('66', 472, 5, 14, 836910) It was decided to supply, free of charge, a copy of the Harijan each (English, Hindi or Gujarati) to such Agents and workers as may apply.
('66', 472, 5, 15, 837049) It was resolved that, out of the annual subscriptions received by the Associates enlisted by an Agent, 75% should be allotted to the work in that district, unless it be earmarked by the donor for a specific area or purpose.
('66', 472, 5, 16, 837273) Vaikunthrai L. Mehta of Bombay, Babu Braj Kishore Prasad of Bihar and Mr. Gopichand Bhargava of Lahore were co opted members of the Board of Management.
